text: The Sundering of the Ways
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Long ago there was a little land, over which ruled a regulus or
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: kinglet, who was called King Peter, though his kingdom was but little.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: He had four sons whose names were Blaise, Hugh, Gregory and Ralph: of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: these Ralph was the youngest, whereas he was but of twenty winters and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: one; and Blaise was the oldest and had seen thirty winters.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Now it came to this at last, that to these young men the kingdom of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: their father seemed strait; and they longed to see the ways of other
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: men, and to strive for life.  For though they were king's sons, they
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: had but little world's wealth; save and except good meat and drink, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: enough or too much thereof; house-room of the best; friends to be merry
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: with, and maidens to kiss, and these also as good as might be; freedom
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: withal to come and go as they would; the heavens above them, the earth
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: to bear them up, and the meadows and acres, the woods and fair streams,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and the little hills of Upmeads, for that was the name of their country
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and the kingdom of King Peter.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: So having nought but this little they longed for much; and that the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: more because, king's sons as they were, they had but scant dominion
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: save over their horses and dogs: for the men of that country were
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: stubborn and sturdy vavassors, and might not away with masterful
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: doings, but were like to pay back a blow with a blow, and a foul word
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: with a buffet.  So that, all things considered, it was little wonder if
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: King Peter's sons found themselves straitened in their little land:
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: wherein was no great merchant city; no mighty castle, or noble abbey of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: monks:  nought but fair little halls of yeomen, with here and there a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: franklin's court or a shield-knight's manor-house; with many a goodly
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: church, and whiles a house of good canons, who knew not the road to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Rome, nor how to find the door of the Chancellor's house.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: So these young men wearied their father and mother a long while with
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: telling them of their weariness, and their longing to be gone: till at
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: last on a fair and hot afternoon of June King Peter rose up from the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: carpet which the Prior of St. John's by the Bridge had given him (for
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: he had been sleeping thereon amidst the grass of his orchard after his
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: dinner) and he went into the hall of his house, which was called the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: High House of Upmeads, and sent for his four sons to come to him.  And
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: they came and stood before his high-seat and he said:
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Sons, ye have long wearied me with words concerning your longing for
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: travel on the roads; now if ye verily wish to be gone, tell me when
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: would ye take your departure if ye had your choice?"
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: They looked at one another, and the three younger ones nodded at Blaise
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the eldest:  so he began, and said:  "Saving the love and honour that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: we have for thee, and also for our mother, we would be gone at once,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: even with the noon's meat still in our bellies.  But thou art the lord
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: in this land, and thou must rule.  Have I said well, brethren?"  And
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: they all said "Yea, yea." Then said the king; "Good! now is the sun
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: high and hot; yet if ye ride softly ye may come to some good harbour
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: before nightfall without foundering your horses.  So come ye in an
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: hour's space to the Four-want-way, and there and then will I order your
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: departure."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: The young men were full of joy when they heard his word; and they
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: departed and went this way and that, gathering such small matters as
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: each deemed that he needed, and which he might lightly carry with him;
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: then they armed themselves, and would bid the squires bring them their
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: horses; but men told them that the said squires had gone their ways
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: already to the Want-way by the king's commandment: so thither they went
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: at once a-foot all four in company, laughing and talking together
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: merrily.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: It must be told that this Want-way aforesaid was but four furlongs from
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the House, which lay in an ingle of the river called Upmeads Water
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: amongst very fair meadows at the end of the upland tillage; and the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: land sloped gently up toward the hill-country and the unseen mountains
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: on the north; but to the south was a low ridge which ran along the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: water, as it wound along from west to east.  Beyond the said ridge, at
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: a place whence you could see the higher hills to the south, that

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the north beyond the Want-way King Peter was lord over a good stretch
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: of land, and that of the best; yet was he never a rich man, for he had
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: who held their manors of him, or whom he waged.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: son also; therefore, being a man of peace, he rode therein but seldom,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: though his sons, the three eldest of them, had both ridden therein and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

text: So came those young men to the Want-ways, and found their father
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: sitting there on a heap of stones, and over against him eight horses,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

text: Now spake King Peter:  "Fair sons, ye would go on all adventure to seek
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: a wider land, and a more stirring life than ye may get of me at home:
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: so be it!  But I have bethought me, that, since I am growing old and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: which of you shall ride and which abide.  For so it is that ye are
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: diverse of your conditions; but the evil conditions which one of you
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: lacks the other hath, and the valiancy which one hath, the other lacks.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: stout rider and lifter, but headstrong and foolhardy, and over
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: bounteous a skinker; and Gregory is courteous and many worded, but
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: sluggish in deed; though I will not call him a dastard.  As for Ralph,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: he is fair to look on, and peradventure he may be as wise as Blaise, as
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: know little or nothing, whereas he is but young and untried.  Yet may
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: he do better than you others, and I deem that he will do so.  All
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: gone, and be called King of Upmeads.

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

text: right well.

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

author: Morris, William

text: cloak, and gat lightly into the saddle, and so shook her reins and rode
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: away east toward Hampton, and left Ralph standing there downcast and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: pondering many things.  It was still so early in the summer morning,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and he knew so little what to do, that presently he turned and walked
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: back to his lair amongst the hazels, and there he lay down, and his
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: thoughts by then were all gone back again to the lovely lady whom he
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: had delivered, and he wondered if he should ever see her again, and,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: sooth to say, he sorely desired to see her.  Amidst such thoughts he
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: fell asleep again, for the night yet owed him something of rest, so
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: young as he was and so hard as he had toiled, both body and mind,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: during the past day.

text: Now Must Ralph Ride For It
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: When he awoke again the sun was shining through the hazel leaves,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: though it was yet early; he arose and looked to his horse, and led him
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: out of the hazel copse and stood and looked about him; and lo! a man
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: coming slowly through the wood on Ralph's right hand, and making as it
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: seemed for the want-way; he saw Ralph presently, and stopped, and bent
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: a bow which he held in his hand, and then came towards him warily, with
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the arrow nocked.  But Ralph went to meet him with his sword in his
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: sheath, and leading Falcon by the rein, and the man stopped and took
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the shaft from the string: he had no armour, but there was a little axe
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and a wood-knife in his girdle; he was clad in homespun, and looked
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: like a carle of the country-side.  Now he greeted Ralph, and Ralph gave
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: him the sele of the day, and saw that the new-comer was both tall and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: strong, dark of skin and black-haired, but of a cheerful countenance.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: He spake frank and free to Ralph, and said: "Whither away, lord, out of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the woodland hall, and the dwelling of deer and strong-thieves? I would
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: that the deer would choose them a captain, and gather head and destroy
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the thieves--and some few others with them."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Said Ralph:  "I may scarce tell thee till I know myself.  Awhile ago I
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: was minded for the Burg of the Four Friths; but now I am for Hampton
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: under Scaur."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Yea?" said the carle, "when the Devil drives, to hell must we."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "What meanest thou, good fellow?" said Ralph, "Is Hampton then so evil
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: an abode?"  And indeed it was in his mind that the adventure of the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: lady led captive bore some evil with it.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Said the carle:  "If thou wert not a stranger in these parts I need not
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: to answer thy question; but I will answer it presently, yet not till we
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: have eaten, for I hunger, and have in this wallet both bread and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: cheese, and thou art welcome to a share thereof, if thou hungerest
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: also, as is most like, whereas thou art young and fresh coloured."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "So it is," said Ralph, laughing, "and I also may help to spread this
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: table in the wilderness, since there are yet some crumbs in my wallet.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Let us sit down and fall to at once."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "By your leave, Sir Gentleman," said the carle, "we will go a few yards
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: further on, where there is a woodland brook, whereof we may drink when
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: my bottle faileth."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Nay, I may better that," said Ralph, "for I have wherewithal."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Nevertheless," said the carle, "we will go thither, for here is it too
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: open for so small a company as ours, since this want-way hath an ill
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: name, and I shall lead thee whereas we shall be somewhat out of the way
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: of murder-carles. So come on, if thou trusteth in me."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Ralph yeasaid him, and they went together a furlong from the want-way
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: into a little hollow place wherethrough ran a clear stream betwixt
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: thick-leaved alders.  The carle led Ralph to the very lip of the water
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: so that the bushes covered them; there they sat down and drew what they
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: had from their wallets, and so fell to meat; and amidst of the meat the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: carle said:
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Fair Knight, as I suppose thou art one, I will ask thee if any need
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: draweth thee to Hampton?"
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Said Ralph:  "The need of giving the go-by to the Burg of the Four
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Friths, since I hear tell that the folk thereof be robbers and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: murderers."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Thou shalt find that out better, lord, by going thither; but I shall
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: tell thee, that though men may slay and steal there time and time
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: about, yet in regard to Hampton under Scaur, it is Heaven, wherein men
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: sin not.  And I am one who should know, for I have been long dwelling
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: in Hell, that is Hampton; and now am I escaped thence, and am minded
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: for the Burg, if perchance I may be deemed there a man good enough to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: ride in their host, whereby I might avenge me somewhat on them that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: have undone me: some of whom meseemeth must have put in thy mouth that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: word against the Burg.  Is it not so?"
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Maybe," said Ralph, "for thou seemest to be a true man." No more he
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: spake though he had half a mind to tell the carle all the tale of that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: adventure; but something held him back when he thought of that lady and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: her fairness.  Yet again his heart misgave him of what might betide
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: that other maiden at Hampton, and he was unquiet, deeming that he must
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: needs follow her thither.  The carle looked on him curiously and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: somewhat anxiously, but Ralph's eyes were set on something that was not
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: there; or else maybe had he looked closely on the carle he might have
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: deemed that longing to avenge him whereof he spoke did not change his
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: face much; for in truth there was little wrath in it.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Now the carle said:  "Thou hast a tale which thou deemest unmeet for my
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: ears, as it well may be.  Well, thou must speak, or refrain from
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: speaking, what thou wilt; but thou art so fair a young knight, and so
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: blithe with a poor man, and withal I deem that thou mayest help me to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: some gain and good, that I will tell thee a true tale: and first that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the Burg is a good town under a good lord, who is no tyrant nor
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: oppressor of peaceful men; and that thou mayest dwell there in peace as
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: to the folk thereof, who be good folk, albeit they be no dastards to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: let themselves be cowed by murder-carles.  And next I will tell thee
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: that the folk of the town of Hampton be verily as harmless and innocent
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: as sheep; but that they be under evil lords who are not their true
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: lords, who lay heavy burdens on them and torment them even to the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: destroying of their lives: and lastly I will tell thee that I was one
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: of those poor people, though not so much a sheep as the more part of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: them, therefore have these tyrants robbed me of my croft, and set
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: another man in my house; and me they would have slain had I not fled to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the wood that it might cover me.  And happy it was for me that I had
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: neither wife, nor chick, nor child, else had they done as they did with
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: my brother, whose wife was too fair for him, since he dwelt at Hampton;
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: so that they took her away from him to make sport for them of the Dry
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Tree, who dwell in the Castle of the Scaur, who shall be thy masters if
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: thou goest thither.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "This is my tale, and thine, I say, I ask not; but I deem that thou
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: shalt do ill if thou go not to the Burg either with me or by thyself
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: alone; either as a guest, or as a good knight to take service in their
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: host."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: had betaken her to so evil a dwelling.  So he said:
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Friend, I know not that I must needs be a partaker in the strife
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: betwixt Hampton and the Burg, or go either to one or the other of these
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and then go on mine own errands?"
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Burg, which is called Apthorp; but it is an open place, not fenced, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: hurt thee in the Burg, a town which is under good and strong law, if
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: adventures, as may well be, thou shalt soon find them there ready to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: hand.  I rede thee come with me to the Burg; for, to say sooth, I shall
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: find it somewhat easier to enter therein if I be in the company of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: thee, a knight and a lord."

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

text: Therewith he smote his horse with his heel and they went forward at a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: smart trot, for the horses were unwearied, and the wood thereabouts of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: beech and clear of underwood; and Roger seemed to know his way well,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and made no fumbling over it.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Four hours or more gone, the wood thinned and the beeches failed, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: they came to a country, still waste, of little low hills, stony for the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: more part, beset with scraggy thorn-bushes, and here and there some
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: other berry-tree sown by the birds.  Then said Roger: "Now I deem us
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: well out of the peril of them of the Burg, who if they follow the chase
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: as far as the sundering of us and the others, will heed our slot
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: nothing, but will follow on that of the company: so we may breathe our
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: horses a little, though their bait will be but small in this rough
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: waste:  therein we are better off than they, for lo you, saddle bags on
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: my nag and meat and drink therein."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: So they lighted down and let their horses graze what they could, while
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: they ate and drank; amidst which Ralph again asked Roger of whither
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: they were going.  Said Roger:  "I shall lead thee to a good harbour,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and a noble house of a master of mine, wherein thou mayst dwell certain
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: days, if thou hast a mind thereto, not without solace maybe."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "And this master," said Ralph, "is he of the Dry Tree?" Said Roger:  "I
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: scarce know how to answer thee without lying: but this I say, that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: whether he be or not, this is true; amongst those men I have friends
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and amongst them foes; but fate bindeth me to them for a while."  Said
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Ralph reddening: "Be there any women amongst them?"  "Yea, yea," quoth
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Roger, smiling a little, "doubt not thereof."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "And that Lady of the Dry Tree," quoth Ralph, reddening yet more, but
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: holding up his head, "that woman whereof the Burgher spoke so bitterly,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: threatening her with torments and death if they might but lay hold of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: her; what wilt thou tell me concerning her?" "But little," said Roger,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "save this, that thou desirest to see her, and that thou mayest have
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: thy will thereon if thou wilt be guided by me."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Ralph hearkened as if he heeded little what Roger said; but presently
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: he rose up and walked to and fro in short turns with knit brows as one
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: pondering a hard matter.  He spake nought, and Roger seemed to heed him
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: nothing, though in sooth he looked at him askance from time to time,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: till at last he came and lay down again by Roger, and in a while he
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: spake: "I wot not why ye of the Dry Tree want me, or what ye will do
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: with me; and but for one thing I would even now ride away from thee at
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: all adventure."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Roger said:  "All this ye shall learn later on, and shalt find it but a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: simple matter; and meanwhile I tell thee again that all is for thy gain
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and thy pleasure.  So now ride away if thou wilt; who hindereth thee?
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: certes not I."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Nay," said Ralph, "I will ride with thee first to that fair house; and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: afterwards we shall see what is to hap."  "Yea," quoth Roger, "then let
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: us to horse straightway, so that we may be there if not before dark
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: night yet at least before bright morn; for it is yet far away."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

text: Ralph Cometh to the House of Abundance
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Therewithal they gat to horse and rode away through that stony land,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: wherein was no river, but for water many pools in the bottoms, with
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: little brooks running from them.  But after a while they came upon a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: ridge somewhat high, on the further side whereof was a wide valley
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: well-grassed and with few trees, and no habitation of man that they
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: might see.  But a wide river ran down the midst of it; and it was now
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: four hours after noon.  Quoth Roger:  "The day wears and we shall by no
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: means reach harbour before dark night, even if we do our best: art thou
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: well used to the water, lord?"  "Much as a mallard is," said Ralph.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Said Roger:  "That is well, for though there is a ford some mile and a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: half down stream, for that same reason it is the way whereby men mostly
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: cross the water into the wildwood; and here again we are more like to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: meet foes than well-wishers; or at the least there will be question of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: who we are, and whence and whither; and we may stumble in our answers."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Said Ralph: "There is no need to tarry, ride we down to the water."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: So did they, and took the water, which was deep, but not swift.  On the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: further side they clomb up a hill somewhat steep; at the crown they
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: drew rein to give their horses breath, and Ralph turned in his saddle
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and looked down on to the valley, and as aforesaid he was clear-sighted
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and far-sighted; now he said: "Fellow-farer, I see the riding of folk
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: down below there, and meseems they be spurring toward the water; and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: they have weapons: there! dost thou not see the gleam?"
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "I will take thy word for it, fair sir," said Roger, "and will even
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: spur, since they be the first men whom we have seen since we left the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: thickets." And therewith he went off at a hand gallop, and Ralph
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: followed him without more ado.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: They rode up hill and down dale of a grassy downland, till at last they
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: saw a wood before them again, and soon drew rein under the boughs; for
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: now were their horses somewhat wearied.  Then said Ralph:  "Here have
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: we ridden a fair land, and seen neither house nor herd, neither
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: sheep-cote nor shepherd.  I wonder thereat."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Said Roger:  "Thou wouldst wonder the less didst thou know the story of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: it." "What story?" said Ralph.  Quoth Roger:  "A story of war and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: wasting." "Yea?" said Ralph, "yet surely some bold knight or baron hath
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: rights in the land, and might be free to build him a strong house and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: gather men to him to guard the shepherds and husbandmen from burners
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and lifters." "Sooth is that," said Roger; "but there are other things
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: in the tale." "What things?" said Ralph.  Quoth Roger:  "Ill hap and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: sorrow and the Hand of Fate and great Sorcery."  "And dastards withal?"
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: said Ralph.  "Even so," said Roger, "yet mingled with valiant men.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Over long is the tale to tell as now, so low as the sun is; so now ride
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: we on with little fear of foemen.  For look you, this wood, like the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: thickets about the Burg of the Four Friths, hath an evil name, and few
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: folk ride it uncompelled; therefore it is the safer for us.  And yet I
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: will say this to thee, that whereas awhile agone thou mightest have
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: departed from me with little peril of aught save the stumbling on some
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: of the riders of the Burg of the Four Friths, departing from me now
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: will be a hard matter to thee; for the saints in Heaven only know
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: whitherward thou shouldest come, if thou wert to guide thyself now.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: This a rough word, but a true one, so help me God and Saint Michael!
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: What sayest thou; art thou content, or wilt thou cast hard words at me
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: again?"
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: So it was that for all that had come and gone Ralph was light-hearted
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and happy; so he laughed and said: "Content were I, even if I were not
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: compelled thereto.  For my heart tells me of new things, and marvellous
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and joyous that I shall see ere long."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "And thine heart lieth not," said Roger, "for amidst of this wood is
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the house where we shall have guesting to-night, which will be to thee,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: belike, the door of life and many marvels.  For thence have folk sought
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: ere now to the WELL AT THE WORLD'S END."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Ralph turned to him sharply and said:  "Many times in these few days
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: have I heard that word.  Dost thou know the meaning thereof?  For as to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: me I know it not."  Said Roger:  "Thou mayest well be as wise as I am
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: thereon: belike men seek to it for their much thriving, and oftenest
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: find it not.  Yet have I heard that they be the likeliest with whom all
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: women are in love."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Ralph held his peace, but Roger noted that he reddened at the word.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Now they got on horseback again, for they had lighted down to breathe
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: their beasts, and they rode on and on, and never was Roger at fault:
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: long was the way and perforce they rested at whiles, so that night fell
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: upon them in the wood, but the moon rose withal.  So night being fairly
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: come, they rested a good while, as it would be dawn before moonset.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Then they rode on again, till now the summer night grew old and waned,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: but the wood hid the beginnings of dawn.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: At last they came out of the close wood suddenly into an open plain,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and now, as the twilight of the dawn was passing into early day, they
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: saw that wide grassy meadows and tilled fields lay before them, with a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: little river running through the plain; and amidst the meadows, on a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: green mound, was a white castle, strong, and well built, though not of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the biggest.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Roger pointed to it, and said, "Now we are come home," and cried on his
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: wearied beast, who for his part seemed to see the end of his journey.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: They splashed through a ford of the river and came to the gate of the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: castle as day drew on apace; Roger blew a blast on a great horn that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: hung on the gate, and Ralph looking round deemed he had never seen
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: fairer building than in the castle, what he could see of it, and yet it
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: was built from of old.  They waited no long while before they were
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: answered; but whereas Ralph looked to see armed gatewards peer from the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: battlements or the shot window, and a porter espying them through a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: lattice, it happened in no such way, but without more ado the wicket
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: was opened to them by a tall old woman, gaunt and grey, who greeted
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: them courteously: Roger lighted down and Ralph did in likewise, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: they led their horses through the gate into the court of the castle;
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the old woman going before them till they came to the hall door, which
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: she opened to them, and taking the reins of their horses led them away
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: to the stable, while those twain entered the hall, which was as goodly
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: as might be.  Roger led Ralph up to a board on the dais, whereon there
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: of any kind did they see; the old woman only, coming back from the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: on Ralph, and seemed as if she would have spoken to him, but as often,

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: So when they were well nigh done with their meat Ralph spake to the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: carline and said:  "Belike the lord or the lady of this house are abed
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and we shall not see them till the morrow?"
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: lord nor lady in the castle as now, nor belike will there be to-morrow
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: themselves."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

text: we two lie in the same chamber?"
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

text: for the man are two different things."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: followed the carline nothing loth, who led him to a fair chamber over
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

author: Morris, William

text: could tell thee; and yet not all, for time would fail us therefor--and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: grown over with high grass and another somewhat bigger, wherein were
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: goats.  There was a woman at the door of the house and she spinning,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: yet clad in glittering raiment, and with jewels on her neck and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: fingers; this was the first thing that I remember, but all as it were a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

text: of rain, that I was afraid, and being so near to the house, I hastened
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: thither, driving the goats, and when I had tethered them in the shed of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the croft, I crept trembling up to the house, and when I was at the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: door, heard the clack of the loom in the weaving-chamber, and deemed
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: that the woman was weaving there, but when I looked, behold there was
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William
