title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and the shed opening and changing, and the sley coming home in due
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: order.  Therewithal I heard a sound as of one singing a song in a low
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: voice, but the words I could not understand: then terror seized on my
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: heart, but I stepped over the threshold, and as the door of the chamber
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: was open, I looked aside and saw therein the woman sitting stark naked
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: on the floor with a great open book before her, and it was from her
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: mouth that the song was coming: grim she looked, and awful, for she was
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: a big woman, black-haired and stern of aspect in her daily wont,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: speaking to me as few words as might be, and those harsh enough, yea
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: harsher than when I was but little.  I stood for one moment afraid
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: beyond measure, though the woman did not look at me, and I hoped she
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: had not seen me; then I ran back into the storm, though it was now
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: wilder than ever, and ran and hid myself in the thicket of the wood,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: half-dead with fear, and wondering what would become of me.  But
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: finding that no one followed after me, I grew calmer, and the storm
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: also drew off, and the sun shone out a little before his setting: so I
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: sat and spun, with fear in my heart, till I had finished my tale of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: thread, and when dusk came, stole back again to the house, though my
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: legs would scarce bear me over the threshold into the chamber.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "There sat the woman in her rich attire no otherwise than her wont, nor
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: did she say aught to me; but looked at the yarn that I had spun, to see
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: that I had done my task, and nodded sternly to me as her wont was, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: I went to bed amongst my goats as I was used to do, but slept not till
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: towards morning, and then images of dreadful things, and of miseries
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: that I may not tell thee of, mingled with my sleep for long.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "So I awoke and ate my meat and drank of the goats' milk with a heavy
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: heart, and then went into the house; and when I came into the chamber
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the woman looked at me, and contrary to her wont spoke to me, and I
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: shook with terror at her voice; though she said naught but this: 'Go
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: fetch thy white goat and come back to me therewith.' I did so, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: followed after her, sick with fear; and she led me through the wood
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: into a lawn which I knew well, round which was a wall, as it were, of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: great yew trees, and amidst, a table of stone, made of four uprights
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and a great stone plank on the top of them; and this was the only thing
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: in all the wood wherein I was used to wander which was of man's
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: handiwork, save and except our house, and the sheds and fences about it.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "The woman stayed and leaned against this stonework and said to me: 'Go
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: about now and gather dry sticks for a fire.'  I durst do naught else,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and said to myself that I should be whipped if I were tardy, though,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: forsooth, I thought she was going to kill me; and I brought her a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: bundle, and she said, 'Fetch more.' And when I had brought her seven
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: bundles, she said:  'It is enough: stand over against me and hearken.'
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: So I stood there quaking; for my fear, which had somewhat abated while
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: I went to and fro after the wood, now came back upon me tenfold.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "She said:  'It were thy due that I should slay thee here and now, as
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: thou slayest the partridges which thou takest in thy springes: but for
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: certain causes I will not slay thee.  Again, it were no more than thy
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: earnings were I to torment thee till thou shouldst cry out for death to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: deliver thee from the anguish; and if thou wert a woman grown, even so
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: would I deal with thee.  But thou art yet but a child, therefore I will
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: keep thee to see what shall befall betwixt us.  Yet must I do somewhat
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: to grieve thee, and moreover something must be slain and offered up
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: here on this altar, lest all come to naught, both thou and I, and that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: which we have to do.  Hold thy white goat now, which thou lovest more
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: than aught else, that I may redden thee and me and this altar with the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: blood thereof.'
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "I durst do naught but obey her, and I held the poor beast, that licked
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: my hands and bleated for love of me: and now since my terror and the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: fear of death was lessened at her words, I wept sore for my dear friend.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "But the woman drew a strong sharp knife from her girdle and cut the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: beast's throat, and dipped her fingers in the blood and reddened both
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: herself and me on the breast, and the hands, and the feet; and then she
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: turned to the altar and smote blood upon the uprights, and the face of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the stone plank.  Then she bade me help her, and we laid the seven
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: faggots on the alter, and laid the carcase of the goat upon them: and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: she made fire, but I saw not how, and set it to the wood, and when it
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: began to blaze she stood before it with her arms outspread, and sang
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: loud and hoarse to a strange tune; and though I knew not the words of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: her song, it filled me with dread, so that I cast myself down on the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: ground and hid my face in the grass.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "So she went on till the beast was all burned up and the fire became
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: naught but red embers, and then she ceased her song and sank down upon
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the grass, and laid her head back and so fell asleep; but I durst not
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: move from the place, but cowered in the grass there, I know not how
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: long, till she arose and came to me, and smote me with her foot and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: cried:  'Rise up, fool! what harm hast thou?  Go milk thy goats and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: lead them to pasture.'  And therewith she strode away home, not heeding
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: me.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "As for me, I arose and dealt with my goats as she bade me; and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: presently I was glad that I had not been slain, yet thenceforth was the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: joy of my life that I had had amongst my goats marred with fear, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the sounds of the woodland came to me mingled with terror; and I was
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: sore afraid when I entered the house in the morning and the evening,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and when I looked on the face of the woman; though she was no harder to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: me than heretofore, but maybe somewhat softer.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "So wore the autumn, and winter came, and I fared as I was wont,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: setting springes for fowl and small-deer. And for all the roughness of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the season, at that time it pleased me better than the leafy days,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: because I had less memory then of the sharpness of my fear on that day
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: of the altar.  Now one day as I went under the snow-laden trees, I saw
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: something bright and big lying on the ground, and drawing nearer I saw
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: that it was some child of man:  so I stopped and cried out, 'Awake and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: arise, lest death come on thee in this bitter cold,' But it stirred
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: not; so I plucked up heart and came up to it, and lo! a woman clad in
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: fair raiment of scarlet and fur, and I knelt down by her to see if I
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: might help her; but when I touched her I found her cold and stiff, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: dead, though she had not been dead long, for no snow had fallen on her.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: It still wanted more than an hour of twilight, and I by no means durst
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: go home till nightfall; so I sat on there and watched her, and put the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: hood from her face and the gloves from her hands, and I deemed her a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: goodly and lovely thing, and was sorry that she was not alive, and I
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: wept for her, and for myself also, that I had lost her fellowship.  So
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: when I came back to the house at dark with the venison, I knew not
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: whether to tell my mistress and tyrant concerning this matter; but she
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: looked on me and said at once: 'Wert thou going to tell me of something
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: that thou hast seen?' So I told her all, even as it was, and she said
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: to me: 'Hast thou taken aught from the corpse?'  'Nay,' said I. 'Then
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: must I hasten,' she said, 'and be before the wolves.' Therewith she
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: took a brand from the fire, and bade me bear one also and lead her:  so
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: did I easily enough, for the moon was up, and what with moon and snow,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: it was well nigh as bright as the day.  So when we came to the dead
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: woman, my mistress kneeled down by her and undid the collar of her
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: cloak, which I had not touched, and took something from her neck
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: swiftly, and yet I, who was holding the torch, saw that it was a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: necklace of blue stones and green, with gold between--Yea, dear
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Champion, like unto thine as one peascod is to another," quoth she.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: And therewith the distressfulness of her face which had worn Ralph's
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: heart while she had been telling her tale changed, and she came, as it
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: were, into her new life and the love of him again, and she kissed him
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and laid her cheek to his and he kissed her mouth.  And then she
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: fetched a sigh, and began with her story again.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "My mistress took the necklace and put it in her pouch, and said as to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: herself:  'Here, then, is another seeker who hath not found, unless one
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: should dig a pit for her here when the thaw comes, and call it the Well
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: at the World's End: belike it will be for her as helpful as the real
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: one.' Then she turned to me and said:  'Do thou with the rest what thou
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: wilt,' and therewith she went back hastily to the house.  But as for
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: me, I went back also, and found a pick and a mattock in the goat-house,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and came back in the moonlight and scraped the snow away, and dug a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Wore the winter thence with naught that I need tell of, only I thought
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: much of the words that my mistress had spoken.  Spring came and went,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and summer also, well nigh tidingless.  But one day as I drave the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: goats from our house there came from the wood four men, a-horseback and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: weaponed, but so covered with their armour that I might see little of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: their faces.  They rode past me to our house, and spake not to me,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: though they looked hard at me; but as they went past I heard one say:
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: 'If she might but be our guide to the Well at the World's End!' I durst
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: not tarry to speak with them, but as I looked over my shoulder I saw
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: them talking to my mistress in the door; but meseemed she was clad but
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: in poor homespun cloth instead of her rich apparel, and I am
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: far-sighted and clear-sighted. After this the autumn and winter that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Now I had outgrown my old fear, and not much befell to quicken it: and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: ever I was as much out of the house as I could be.  But about this time
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: my mistress, from being kinder to me than before, began to grow harder,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and ofttimes used me cruelly:  but of her deeds to me, my friend, thou
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: shalt ask me no more than I tell thee.  On a day of May-tide I fared
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: abroad with my goats, and went far with them, further from the house
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: than I had been as yet.  The day was the fairest of the year, and I
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: rejoiced in it, and felt as if some exceeding great good were about to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: befall me; and the burden of fears seemed to have fallen from me.  So I
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: went till I came to a little flowery dell, beset with blossoming
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: whitethorns and with a fair stream running through it; a place somewhat
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: like to this, save that the stream there was bigger.  And the sun was
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: hot about noontide, so I did off my raiment, which was rough and poor,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and more meet for winter than May-tide, and I entered a pool of the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: clear water, and bathed me and sported therein, smelling the sweet
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: scent of the whitethorns and hearkening to the song of the many birds;
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and when I came forth from the water, the air was so soft and sweet to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: me, and the flowery grass so kind to my feet, and the May-blooms fell
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: upon my shoulders, that I was loth to do on my rough raiment hastily,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and withal I looked to see no child of man in that wilderness: so I
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: sported myself there a long while, and milked a goat and drank of the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: milk, and crowned myself with white-thorn and hare-bells; and held the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: blossoms in my hand, and felt that I also had some might in me, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: that I should not be a thrall of that sorceress for ever.  And that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: day, my friend, belike was the spring-tide of the life and the love
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: that thou holdest in thy kind arms.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "But as I abode thus in that fair place, and had just taken my rock and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: spindle in hand that I might go on with my task and give as little
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: occasion as I might for my mistress to chastise me, I looked up and saw
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: a child of man coming down the side of the little dale towards me, so I
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: sprang up, and ran to my raiment and cast them on me hastily, for I was
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: ashamed; and when I saw that it was a woman, I thought at first that it
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: was my mistress coming to seek me; and I thought within myself that if
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

text: "I had stayed my feet some six paces from the threshold, and my heart
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: beat quick, but the sick fear and cowering had left me, though the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: horror of her grew in my heart.  My goats had all gone off quietly to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: their house, and there was nothing betwixt me and her.  In clearing
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: from my sleeve the arm of me which held the knife, the rough clasp
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the cloth had fallen and left my bosom bare, so that I knew that the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: collar was clearly to be seen.  So we stood a moment, and I had no
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: words, but she spake at last in a hard, snarling voice, such as she
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: oftenest used to me, but worse.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "'Now at last the time has come when thou art of no more use to me; for
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: I can see thee what thou hast got for thyself.  But know now that thou
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: hast not yet drunk of the Well at the World's End, and that it will not
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: avail thee to flee out of this wood; for as long as I live thou wilt
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: not be able to get out of reach of my hand; and I shall live long: I
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: shall live long.  Come, then, and give thyself up to me, that I may
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: deal with thee as I threatened when I slew thy friend the white goat;
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: for, indeed, I knew then that it would come to this.'
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "She had but twice or thrice spoken to me so many words together as
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: this; but I answered never a word, but stood watching her warily.  And
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: of a sudden she gave forth a dreadful screaming roar, wherewith all the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: wood rang again, and rushed at me; but my hand came from behind my
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: back, and how it was I know not, but she touched me not till the blade
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: had sunk into her breast, and she fell across my feet, her right hand
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: clutching my raiment.  So I loosed her fingers from the cloth,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: shuddering with horror the while, and drew myself away from her and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: stood a little aloof, wondering what should happen next.  And indeed I
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: scarce believed but she would presently rise up from the ground and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: clutch me in her hands, and begin the tormenting of me.  But she moved
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: no more, and the grass all about her was reddened with her blood; and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: at last I gathered heart to kneel down beside her, and found that she
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: no more breathed than one of those conies or partridges which I had
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: been used to slay for her.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Then I stood and considered what I should do, and indeed I had been
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: pondering this all the way from the Dale thereto, in case I should
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: escape my mistress.  So I soon made up my mind that I would not dwell
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: in that house even for one night; lest my mistress should come to me
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: though dead, and torment me.  I went into the house while it was yet
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: light, and looked about the chamber, and saw three great books there
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: laid on the lectern, but durst not have taken them even had I been able
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: to carry them; nor durst I even to look into them, for fear that some
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: spell might get to work in them if they were opened; but I found a rye
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: loaf whereof I had eaten somewhat in the morning, and another
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: untouched, and hanging to a horn of the lectern I found the necklace
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: which my mistress had taken from the dead woman.  These I put into my
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: scrip, and as to the necklace, I will tell thee how I bestowed it later
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: on.  Then I stepped out into the twilight which was fair and golden,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and full fain I was of it.  Then I drove the goats out of their house
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and went my way towards the Dale of Lore, and said to myself that the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: summer dark had quite prevailed, and slept sweetly and softly amongst
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Lo thou, beloved," she said, "thou hast seen me in the wildwood with
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: little good quickened in me:  doth not thine heart sink at the thought
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: of thy love and thy life given over to the keeping of such an one?"  He
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: smiled in her face, and said: "Belike thou hast done worse than all
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: thou hast told me: and these days past I have wondered often what there
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: was in the stories which they of the Burg had against thee: yet sooth
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: to say, they told little of what thou hast done: no more belike than
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: being their foe."  She sighed and said: "Well, hearken; yet shall I not
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: tell thee every deed that I have been partaker in.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "I sat in the Dale that next day and was happy, though I longed to see
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: that fair man again:  sooth to say, since my mistress was dead,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: everything seemed fairer to me, yea even mine own face, as I saw it in
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the pools of the stream, though whiles I wondered when I should have
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: another mistress, and how she would deal with me; and ever I said I
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: would ask the carline when she came again to me.  But all that day she
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: came not:  nor did I marvel thereat.  But when seven days passed and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: still she came not, I fell to wondering what I should do:  for my bread
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: was all gone, and I durst not go back to the house to fetch meal;
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: though there was store of it there.  Howbeit, I drank of the milk of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the goats, and made curds thereof with the woodland roots, and ate of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the wood-berries like as thou hast done, friend, e'en now.  And it was
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: easier for me to find a livelihood in the woods than it had been for
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: most folk, so well as I knew them.  So wore the days, and she came not,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and I began to think that I should see the wise carline no more, as
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: indeed fell out at that time; and the days began to hang heavy on my
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: hands, and I fell to thinking of that way to the west and the peopled
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: parts, whereof the carline had told me; and whiles I went out of the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Dale and went away hither and thither through the woods, and so far,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: that thrice I slept away out of the Dale: but I knew that the peopled
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: parts would be strange to me and I feared to face them all alone.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Thus wore the days till July was on the wane, and on a morning early I
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: awoke with unwonted sounds in mine ears; and when my eyes were fairly
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: open I saw a man standing over me and a white horse cropping the grass
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: hard by.  And my heart was full and fain, and I sprang to my feet and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: showed him a smiling happy face, for I saw at once that it was that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: fair man come back again.  But lo! his face was pale and worn, though
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: he looked kindly on me, and he said:  'O my beloved, I have found thee,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: but I am faint with hunger and can speak but little.' And even
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: therewith he sank down on the grass.  But I bestirred myself, and gave
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: him milk of my goats, and curds and berries, and the life came into him
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: again, and I sat down by him and laid his head in my lap, and he slept
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: a long while; and when he awoke (and it was towards sunset) he kissed
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: my hands and my arms, and said to me:  'Fair child, perhaps thou wilt
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: come with me now; and even if thou art a thrall thou mayest flee with
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: me; for my horse is strong and fat, though I am weak, for he can make
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: his dinner on the grass.'
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Then he laughed and I no less; but I fed him with my poor victual
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: again, and as he ate I said:  'I am no mistress's thrall now; for the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: evening of the day whereon I saw thee I slew her, else had she slain
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: me.' 'The saints be praised,' said he:  'Thou wilt come with me, then?'
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: 'O yea,' said I. Then I felt shamefaced and I reddened; but I said: 'I
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: have abided here many days for a wise woman who hath taught me many
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: things; but withal I hoped that thou wouldst come also.'
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Then he put his arms about my shoulders and loved me much; but at last
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: he said:  'Yet is it now another thing than that which I looked for,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: when I talked of setting thee by me on the golden throne.  For now am I
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: a beaten man; I have failed of that I sought, and suffered shame and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: hunger and many ills.  Yet ever I thought that I might find thee here
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: or hereby.' Then a thought came into my mind, and I said:  'Else maybe
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: thou hadst found what thou soughtest, and overcome the evil things.'
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: 'Maybe,' he said; 'it is now but a little matter.'"
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "As for me, I could have no guess at what were the better things he had
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: meant for me, and my heart was full of joy, and all seemed better than
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: well.  And we talked together long till the day was gone.  Then we
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: kissed and embraced each other in the Dale of Lore, and the darkness of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: summer seemed but short for our delight."

text: Ralph stayed her speech now, and said:  "When I asked of thee in the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Land of Abundance, there were some who seemed to say that thou hast let
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: more men love thee than one: and it was a torment to me to think that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: even so it might be.  But now when thine own mouth telleth me of one of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: them it irks me little.  Dost thou think it little-hearted in me?"
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "O friend," she said, "I see that so it is with thee that thou wouldst
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: find due cause for loving me, whatever thou foundest true of me.  Or
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: dost thou deem that I was another woman in those days?  Nay, I was not:
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: I can see myself still myself all along the way I have gone." She was
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: silent a little, and then she said:  "Fear not, I will give thee much
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: cause to love me.  But now I know thy mind the better, I shall tell
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: thee less of what befell me after I left the wilderness; for whatever I
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: did and whatever I endured, still it was always I myself that was
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: there, and it is me that thou lovest.  Moreover, my life in the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: wilderness is a stranger thing to tell thee of than my dealings with
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the folk, and with Kings and Barons and Knights.  But thereafter thou
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: shalt hear of me what tales thou wilt of these matters, as the days and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the years pass over our heads.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Now on the morrow we would not depart at once, because there we had
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: some victual, and the king's son was not yet so well fed as he should
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: be; so we abode in that fair place another day, and then we went our
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: to it for victual; whiles I sat behind my knight a-horseback, whiles he
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: led the beast while I rode alone, and not seldom I went afoot, and that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: nowise slowly, while he rode the white horse, for I was as light-foot

author: Morris, William

text: then as now.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "And of the way we went I will tell thee nought as now, because sure it
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: is that if we both live, thou and I shall tread that road together, but
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: not told clearly that thou hadst been there." "Yea," she said, because
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the said book was made not by my friends but my foes, and they would
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

text: which has come of mere chance-hap.

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Hearken now," she said, "till I tell thee in few words what befell me
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: before I came to drink the Water of the Well.  After we had passed long
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: deserts of wood and heath, and gone through lands exceeding evil and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: perilous, and despaired of life for the horror of those places, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: seen no men, we came at last amongst a simple folk who dealt kindly
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: with us, yea, and more.  These folk seemed to me happy and of good
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: wealth, though to my lord they seemed poor and lacking of the goods of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the world.  Forsooth, by that time we lacked more than they, for we
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: were worn with cold and hunger, and hard life: though for me, indeed,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: happy had been the days of my wayfaring, but my lord remembered the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: days of his riches and the kingdom of his father, and the worship of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: mighty men, and all that he had promised me on the happy day when I
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: first beheld him: so belike he was scarce so happy as I was.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "It was springtime when we came to that folk; for we had worn through
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the autumn and winter in getting clear of the wilderness.  Not that the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: way was long, as I found out afterwards, but that we went astray in the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: woodland, and at last came out of it into a dreadful stony waste which
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: we strove to cross thrice, and thrice were driven back into the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: greenwood by thirst and hunger; but the fourth time, having gotten us
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: store of victual by my woodcraft, we overpassed it and reached the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: peopled country.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Yea, spring was on the earth, as we, my lord and I, came down from the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: desolate stony heaths, and went hand and hand across the plain, where
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: men and women of that folk were feasting round about the simple roofs
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and woodland halls which they had raised there.  Then they left their
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: games and sports and ran to us, and we walked on quietly, though we
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: knew not whether the meeting was to be for death or life.  But that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: kind folk gathered round us, and asked us no story till they had fed
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: us, and bathed us, and clad us after their fashion.  And then, despite
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the nakedness and poverty wherein they had first seen us, they would
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: have it that we were gods sent down to them from the world beyond the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: mountains by their fathers of old time; for of Holy Church, and the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Blessed Trinity, and the Mother of God they knew no more than did I at
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: that time, but were heathen, as the Gentiles of yore agone.  And even
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: when we put all that Godhood from us, and told them as we might and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: could what we were (for we had no heart to lie to such simple folk),
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: their kindness abated nothing, and they bade us abide there, and were
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: our loving friends and brethren.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "There in sooth had I been content to abide till eld came upon me, but
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: my lord would not have it so, but longed for greater things for me.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Though in sooth to me it seemed as if his promise of worship of me by
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the folk had been already fulfilled; for when we had abided there some
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: while, and our beauty, which had been marred by the travail of our
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: way-faring, had come back to us in full, or it maybe increased
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: somewhat, they did indeed deal with us with more love than would most
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: men with the saints, were they to come back on the earth again; and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: their children would gather round about me and make me a partaker of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: their sports, and be loth to leave me; and the faces of their old folk
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: would quicken and gladden when I drew nigh: and as for their young men,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: it seemed of them that they loved the very ground that my feet trod on,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: though it grieved me that I could not pleasure some of them in such
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: wise as they desired.  And all this was soft and full of delight for my
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: soul: and I, whose body a little while ago had been driven to daily
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: toil with evil words and stripes, and who had known not what words of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: thanks and praise might mean!
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "But so it must be that we should depart, and the kind folk showed us
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: how sore their hearts were of our departure, but they gainsaid us in
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: nowise, but rather furthered us all they might, and we went our ways
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: from them riding on horned neat (for they knew not of horses), and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: driving one for a sumpter beast before us; and they had given us bows
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and arrows for our defence, and that we might get us venison.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "It is not to be said that we did not encounter perils; but thereof I
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: will tell thee naught as now.  We came to other peoples, richer and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: mightier than these, and I saw castles, and abbies, and churches, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: walled towns, and wondered at them exceedingly.  And in these places
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: folk knew of the kingdom of my lord and his father, and whereas they
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: were not of his foes (who lay for the more part on the other side of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: his land), and my lord could give sure tokens of what he was, we were
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: treated with honour and worship, and my lord began to be himself again,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and to bear him as a mighty man.  And here to me was some gain in that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: poverty and nakedness wherewith we came out of the mountains and the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: raiment of the simple folk; for had I been clad in my poor cloth and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: goat-skins of the House of the Sorcerer, and he in his brave attire and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: bright armour, they would have said, it is a thrall that he is assotted
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: of, and would have made some story and pretence of taking me from him;
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: but they deemed me a great lady indeed, and a king's daughter,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: according to the tale that he told them.  Forsooth many men that saw me
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: desired me beyond measure, and assuredly some great proud man or other
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: would have taken me from my lord, but that they feared the wrath of his
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: father, who was a mighty man indeed.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Yea, one while as we sojourned by a certain town but a little outside
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the walls, a certain young man, a great champion and exceeding
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: masterful, came upon me with his squires as I was walking in the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: meadows, and bore me off, and would have taken me to his castle, but
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: that my lord followed with a few of the burghers, and there was a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: battle fought, wherein my lord was hurt; but the young champion he
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: slew; and I cannot say but I was sorry of his death, though glad of my
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: deliverance.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Again, on a time we guested in a great baron's house, who dealt so
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: foully by us that he gave my lord a sleeping potion in his good-night
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: cup, and came to me in the dead night and required me of my love; and I
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: would not, and he threatened me sorely, and called me a thrall and a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: castaway that my lord had picked up off the road: but I gat a knife in
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: my hand and was for warding myself when I saw that my lord might not
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: wake:  so the felon went away for that time.  But on the morrow came
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: two evil men into the hall whom he had suborned, and bore false witness
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: that I was a thrall and a runaway.  So that the baron would have held
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: me there (being a mighty man) despite my lord and his wrath and his
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: grief, had not a young knight of his house been, who swore that he
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: would slay him unless he let us go; and whereas there were other
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: knights and squires there present who murmured, the baron was in a way
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: compelled.  So we departed, and divers of the said knights and squires
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: went with us to see us safe on the way.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "But this was nigh to the kingdom of my lord's father, and that felon
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: baron I came across again, and he was ever after one of my worst foes.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Moreover, that young champion who had first stood up in the hall rode
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: with us still, when the others had turned back; and I soon saw of him
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: that he found it hard to keep his eyes off me; and that also saw my
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: lord, and it was a near thing that they did not draw sword thereover:
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: yet was that knight no evil man, but good and true, and I was
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: exceedingly sorry for him; but I could not help him in the only way he
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: would take help of me.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Lo you, my friend, the beginnings of evil in those long past days, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the seeds of ill-hap sown in the field of my new life even before the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: furrow was turned.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Well, we came soon into my lord's country, and fair and rich and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: lovely was it in those days; free from trouble and unpeace, a happy
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: abode for the tillers of the soil, and the fashioners of wares.  The
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: tidings had gone to the king that my lord was come back, and he came to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: meet him with a great company of knights and barons, arrayed in the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: noblest fashion that such folk use; so that I was bewildered with their
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: glory, and besought my lord to let me fall back out of the way, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: perchance he might find me again.  But he bade me ride on his right
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: hand, for that I was the half of his life and his soul, and that my
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: friends were his friends and my foes his foes.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Then there came to me an inkling of the things that should befall, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: I saw that the sweet and clean happiness of my new days was marred, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: had grown into something else, and I began to know the pain of strife
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and the grief of confusion:  but whereas I had not been bred
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: delicately, but had endured woes and griefs from my youngest days, I
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: was not abashed, but hardened my heart to face all things, even as my
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: lord strove to harden his heart:  for, indeed, I said to myself that if
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: I was to him as the half of his life, he was to me little less than the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: whole of my life.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "It is as if it had befallen yesterday, my friend, that I call to mind
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: how we stood beside our horses in the midst of the ring of great men
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: clad in gold and gleaming with steel, in the meadow without the gates,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the peace and lowly goodliness whereof with its flocks and herds
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: feeding, and husbandmen tending the earth and its increase, that great
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and noble array had changed so utterly.  There we stood, and I knew
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: that the eyes of all those lords and warriors were set upon me
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: wondering.  But the love of my lord and the late-learned knowledge of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: my beauty sustained me.  Then the ring of men opened, and the king came
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: forth towards us; a tall man and big, of fifty-five winters, goodly of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: body and like to my lord to look upon.  He cast his arms about my lord,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and kissed him and embraced him, and then stood a little aloof from him
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and said: 'Well, son, hast thou found it, the Well at the World's End?'
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "'Yea,' said my lord, and therewith lifted my hand to his lips and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: kissed it, and I looked the king in his face, and his eyes were turned
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: to me, but it was as if he were looking through me at something behind
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: me.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Then he said:  'It is good, son:  come home now to thy mother and thy
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: kindred.'  Then my lord turned to me while the king took no heed, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: no man in the ring of knights moved from his place, and he set me in
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the saddle, and turned about to mount, and there came a lord from the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: ring of men gloriously bedight, and he bowed lowly before my lord, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: held his stirrup for him: but lightly he leapt up into the saddle, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: took my reins and led me along with him, so that he and the king and I
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: went on together, and all the baronage and their folk shouted and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: tossed sword and spear aloft and followed after us.  And we left the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: meadow quiet and simple again, and rode through the gate of the king's
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: chief city, wherein was his high house and his castle, the

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "When we came to the King's House, my lord followed his father into the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: hall, where sat his mother amongst her damsels: she was a fair woman,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and looked rather meek than high-hearted; my lord led me up to her, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: she embraced and kissed him and caressed him long; then she turned
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: about to me and would have spoken to me, but the king, who stood behind
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: us, scowled on her, and she forebore; but she looked me on somewhat
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: kindly, and yet as one who is afeard.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Thus it went for the rest of the day, and my lord had me to sit beside
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: him in the great hall when the banquet was holden, and I ate and drank
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: with him and beheld all the pageants by his side, and none meddled with
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: me either to help or to hinder, because they feared the king.  Yet many
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: eyes I saw that desired my beauty.  And so when night came, he took me
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: to his chamber and his bed, as if I were his bride new wedded, even as
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: it had been with us on the grass of the wilderness and the bracken of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the wildwood.  And then, at last, he spake to me of our case, and bade
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: me fear not, for that a band of his friends, all-armed, was keeping
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: watch and ward in the cloister without.  And when I left the chamber on
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the morrow's morn, there were they yet, all in bright armour, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: amongst them the young knight who had delivered me from the felon
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: baron, and he looked mournfully at me, so that I was sorry for his
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: sorrow.

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

text: "And I knew now that the king was minded to slay me, else had he bidden
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: thrust me from my lord's side.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "So wore certain days; and on the seventh night, when we were come into
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: our chamber, which was a fair as any house outside of heaven, my lord
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: spake to me in a soft voice, and bade me not do off my raiment.  'For,'
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: said he, 'this night we must flee the town, or we shall be taken and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: cast into prison to-morrow; for thus hath my father determined.' I
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: kissed him and clung to him, and he no less was good to me.  And when
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: which he had made ready, and beneath was the city wall; and that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: company of knights, amongst whom was the young knight abovesaid, had
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: taken a postern thereby, and were abiding us armed and with good
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: horses.  So we came into the open country, and rode our ways with the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: mind to reach a hill-castle of one of those young barons, and to hold
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: ourselves there in despite of the king.  But the king had been as wary
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: as we were privy, and no less speedy than we; and he was a mighty and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: deft warrior, and he himself followed us on the spur with certain of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: his best men-at-arms. And they came upon us as we rested in a woodside
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: not far from our house of refuge: and the king stood by to see the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: battle with his sword in his sheath, but soon was it at an end, for
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: though our friends fought valiantly, they were everyone slain or hurt,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and but few escaped with bare life; but that young man who loved me so
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: sorely crept up to me grievously hurt, and I did not forbear to kiss
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: him once on the face, for I deemed I should soon die also, and his
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: blood stained my sleeve and my wrist, but he died not as then, but
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: lived to be a dear friend to me for long.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "So we, my lord and I, were led back to the city, and he was held in
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: ward and I was cast into prison with chains and hunger and stripes.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William
