title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: be forgotten utterly; but there were many of the king's knights who
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: murmured at this, and would not forget me; so the king being
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: constrained, had me brought forth to be judged by his bishops of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: sorcery for the beguiling of my lord.  Long was the tale to me then,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: but I will not make it long for thee; as was like to be, I was brought
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: in guilty of sorcery, and doomed to be burned in the Great Square in
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: three days time.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Nay, my friend, thou hast no need to look so troubled; for thou seest
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: that I was not burned.  This is the selfsame body that was tied to the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: stake in the market place of the king's city many a year ago.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "For the friends of my lord, young men for the most part, and many who
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: had been fain to be my friends also, put on their armour, and took my
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: lord out of the courteous prison wherein he was, and came to the Great
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Square whenas I stood naked in my smock bound amid the faggots; and I
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: saw the sheriffs' men give back, and great noise and rumour rise up
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: around me:  and then all about me was a clear space for a moment and I
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: heard the tramp of the many horse-hoofs, and the space was full of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: weaponed men shouting, and crying out, 'Life for our Lord's Lady!'
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: me a horse and I mounted, lest the worst should come and we might have
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: to flee.  So I could see much of what went on; and I saw that all the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: unarmed folk and lookers-on were gone, but at our backs was a great
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: crowd of folk with staves and bows who cried out, 'Life for the Lady!'
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: But before us was naught but the sheriffs' sergeants and a company of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: knights and men-at-arms, about as many as we were, and the king in
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: front of them, fully armed, his face hidden by his helm, and a royal
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: surcoat over his hauberk beaten with his bearing, to wit, a silver
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: tower on a blue sky bestarred with gold.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "And now I could see that despite the bills and bows behind us the king
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: was going to fall on with his folk; and to say sooth I feared but
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: little and my heart rose high within me, and I wished I had a sword in
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: my hand to strike once for life and love.  But lo! just as the king was
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: raising his sword, and his trumpet was lifting the brass to his lips,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Host (as now I know it was) under a golden canopy, and he stood between
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the two companies and faced the king, while his folk sang loud and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: sweet about him.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Then the spears went up and from the rest, and swords were sheathed,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and there went forth three ancient knights from out of the king's host
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and came up to him and spake with him.  Then he gat him away unto his
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: High House; and the three old knights came to our folk, and spake with
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the chiefs; but not with my lord, and I heard not what they said.  But
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: my lord came to me in all loving-kindness and brought me into the house
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: of one of the Lineage, and into a fair chamber there, and kissed me,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and made much of me; and brought me fair raiment and did it on me with
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: his own hands, even as his wont was to be for my tire-maiden.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Then in a little while came those chiefs of ours and said that truce
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: had been hanselled them for this time, but on these terms, that my lord
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and I and all those who had been in arms, and whosoever would, that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: feared the king's wrath, should have leave to depart from his city so
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: that they went and abode no nearer than fifty miles thereof till they
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: should know his further pleasure.  Albeit that whosoever would go home
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: peaceably might abide in the city still and need not fear the king's
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: wrath if he stirred no further: but that in any case the Sorceress
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: should get her gone from those walls.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "So we rode out of the gates that very day before sunset; for it was
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: now midsummer again, and it was three hours before noon that I was to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: have been burned; and we were a gallant company of men-at-arms and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: knights; yet did I be-think me of those who were slain on that other
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: day when we were taken, and fain had I been that they were riding with
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: us; but at least that fair young man was in our company, though still
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: weak with his hurts: for the prison and the process had worn away
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: wellnigh two months.  True it is that I rejoiced to see him, for I had
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: deemed him dead.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Dear friend, I pray thy pardon if I weary thee with making so long a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: tale of my friends of the past days; but needs must I tell thee
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: somewhat of them, lest thou love that which is not.  Since truly it is
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: myself that I would have thee to love, and none other.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Many folk gathered to us as we rode our ways to a town which was my
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: lord's own, and where all men were his friends, so that we came there
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: with a great host and sat down there in no fear of what the king might
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: do against us.  There was I duly wedded to my lord by a Bishop of Holy
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Church, and made his Lady and Queen; for even so he would have it.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "And now began the sore troubles of that land, which had been once so
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: peaceful and happy; the tale whereof I may one day tell thee; or rather
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: many tales of what befell me therein; but not now; for the day weareth;
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and I still have certain things that I must needs tell thee.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "We waged war against each other, my lord and the king, and whiles one,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and whiles the other overcame.  Either side belike deemed that one
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: battle or two would end the strife; but so it was not, but it endured
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: year after year, till fighting became the chief business of all in the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: land.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "As for me, I had many tribulations.  Thrice I fled from the stricken
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: field with my lord to hide in some stronghold of the mountains.  Once
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: was I taken of the foemen in the town where I abode when my lord was
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: away from me, and a huge slaughter of innocent folk was made, and I was
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: cast into prison and chains, after I had seen my son that I had borne
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: to my lord slain before mine eyes.  At last we were driven clean out of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the Kingdom of the Tower, and abode a long while, some two years, in
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the wilderness, living like outlaws and wolves' heads, and lifting the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: spoil for our livelihood.  Forsooth of all the years that I abode about
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the Land of Tower those were the happiest.  For we robbed no poor folk
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and needy, but rewarded them rather, and drave the spoil from rich men
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and lords, and hard-hearted chapmen-folk: we ravished no maid of the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: tillers, we burned no cot, and taxed no husbandman's croft or acre, but
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: defended them from their tyrants.  Nevertheless we gat an ill name wide
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: about through the kingdoms and cities; and were devils and witches to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the boot of thieves and robbers in the mouths of these men; for when
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the rich man is hurt his wail goeth heavens high, and none may say he
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: heareth not.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Now it was at this time that I first fell in with the Champions of the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Dry Tree; for they became our fellows and brothers in arms in the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: wildwood: for they had not as yet builded their stronghold of the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Scaur, whereas thou and I shall be in two days time.  Many a wild deed
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: did our folk in their company, and many that had been better undone.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Whiles indeed they went on journeys wherein we were not partakers, as
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: when they went to the North and harried the lands of the Abbot of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Higham, and rode as far even as over the Downs to Bear Castle and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: out of the Wood Perilous to the northward; and lifted little save in
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the lands of our own proper foemen, the friends of the king.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Now I say not of the men of the Dry Tree that they were good and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: peaceable men, nor would mercy hold their hands every while that they
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: were hard bestead and thrust into a corner.  Yet I say now and once for
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: all that their fierceness was and is but kindness and pity when set
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: against the cruelty of the Burg of the Four Friths; men who have no
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: friend to love, no broken foe to forgive, and can scarce be kind even
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: to themselves: though forsooth they be wise men and cautelous and well
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: living before the world, and wealthy and holy."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: face and she set her teeth; and she was as one beside herself till
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Dear friend, when thou knowest what these men are and have been thou
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: wilt bless thy friend Roger for leading thee forth from the Burg by
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: night and cloud, whatever else may happen to thee.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Well, we abode in the wildwood, friends and good fellows from the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: first; and that young man, though he loved me ever, was somewhat healed
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: of the fever of love, and was my faithful friend, in such wise that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: neither I nor my lord had aught to find fault with in him.  Meanwhile
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: we began to grow strong, for many joined us therein who had fled from
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: their tyrants of the good towns and the manors of the baronage, and at
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: into the Kingdom of the Tower, and raise his banner in the wealthy
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: land, and the fair cities.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Moreover, his father, the King of the Tower, died in his bed in these
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: days, and no word of love or peace had passed between them since that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: morning when I was led out to be burned in the Great Square.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "So we came forth from the forest, we, and the Champions of the Dry
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Tree; and made the tale a short one.  For the king, the mighty warrior
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and wise man, was dead: and his captains of war, some of them were
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: dead, and some weary of strife; and those who had been eager in debate
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: were falling to ask themselves wherefore they had fought and what was
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: to do that they should still be fighting; and lo! when it came to be
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: looked into, it was all a matter of the life and death of one woman, to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: wit me myself, and why should she not live, why should she not sit upon
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the throne with the man who loved her?
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Therefore when at last we came out from the twilight of the woods into
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the sunny fields of the Land of the Tower, there was no man to naysay
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: us; nay, the gates of the strong places flew open before the wind of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: our banners, and the glittering of our spears drew the folk together
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: with the houses hung with green boughs and the maidens casting flowers
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: before our feet, and I sat a crowned Queen upon the throne high raised
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: on the very place where erst I stood awaiting the coming of the torch
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: to the faggots which were to consume me.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "There then began the reign of the Woman of the Waste; for so it was,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: that my lord left to my hands the real ruling of the kingdom, though he
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: wore the crown and set the seal to parchments.  As to them of the Dry
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Tree, though some few of them abode in the kingdom, and became great
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: old life of the Wood, as we had found them living it aforetime.  But or
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: ever they went, the leaders of them came before me, and kissed my feet,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "And now my lord and I, we set ourselves to heal the wounds which war
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: had made in the land:  and hard was the work, and late the harvest; so
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and chiefly the women who had lost husband, lover, son or brother, who
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the old king's wrath against me, which was the cause of all?  About
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: even as ye saw them.  But the days and the years wore, and wealth came
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: back to the mighty of the land, and fields flourished and the acres
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: was called happy again.

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "But for me I was not so happy:  and I looked back fondly to the days
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: of the greenwood and the fellowship of the Dry Tree, and the days
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: my lord the king's cloak: but therewith tales concerning me began to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: from of old and sent by the lords of hell to wreck that fair Land of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

text: abroad, and that still chiefly by the women:  for yet most men looked
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: back.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Now amidst these things as I was walking pensively in my garden one
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: them bring her.  And when she came I looked on her, and deemed that I
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: had seen her aforetime:  she was not old, but of middle age, of dark
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: red hair, and brown eyes somewhat small: not a big woman, but well
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: fashioned of body, and looking as if she had once been exceeding dainty
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: into my mind, and I sent away the folk who were thereby before I said
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: more to her.  Then she spake again:  'Even so I guessed it would be
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: that thou wouldst grow great amongst women.'
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "But I said, 'What is this? and when have I known thee before-time?'
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: She smiled and said naught; and my mind went back to those old days,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and I trembled, and the flesh crept upon my bones, lest this should be
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the coming back in a new shape of my mistress whom I had slain.  But
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the woman laughed, and said, as if she knew my thoughts: 'Nay, it is
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: not so:  the dead are dead; fear not:  but hast thou forgotten the Dale
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: of Lore?'
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "'Nay,' said I, 'never; and art thou then the carline that learned me
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: lore?  But if the dead come not back, how do the old grow young again?
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: for 'tis a score of years since we two sat in the Dale, and I longed
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: for many things.'
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Said the woman:  'The dead may not drink of the Well at the World's
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: End; yet the living may, even if they be old; and that blessed water
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: folk for a long while again after they have drunken.' 'And hast thou
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: drunken?' said I.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "'Yea,' she said; 'but I am minded for another draught.'  I said: 'And
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: this I will tell thee, that all that here is done, is done by me.'
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: already.' 'Thou shalt have no less,' said the woman.  Then she kissed
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "So wore the months, and ere the winter had come befell an evil thing,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

text: Long he stood letting these thoughts run through his mind, but at last
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: when it was now midmorning, he stirred and gat him slowly down the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: green slope, and for very pity of himself the tears brake out from him
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: as he crossed the stream and came into the bushy valley.  There he
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: stayed his feet a little, and said to himself:  "And whither then am I
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: going?" He thought of the Castle of Abundance and the Champions of the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Dry Tree, of Higham, and the noble warriors who sat at the Lord Abbot's
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: board, and of Upmeads and his own folk:  but all seemed naught to him,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and he thought:  "And how can I go back and bear folk asking me
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: curiously of my wayfarings, and whether I will do this, that, or the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: other thing." Withal he thought of that fair damsel and her sweet mouth
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: in the hostelry at Bourton Abbas, and groaned when he thought of love
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and its ending, and he said within himself:  "and now she is a wanderer
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: about the earth as I am;" and he thought of her quest, and the chaplet
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: of dame Katherine, his gossip, which he yet bore on his neck, and he
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: deemed that he had naught to choose but to go forward and seek that he
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: was doomed to; and now it seemed to him that there was that one thing
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: to do and no other.  And though this also seemed to him but weariness
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and grief, yet whereas he had ever lightly turned him to doing what
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: work lay ready to hand; so now he knew that he must first of all get
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: him out of that wilderness, that he might hear the talk of folk
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: concerning the Well at the World's End, which he doubted not to hear
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: again when he came into the parts inhabited.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: So now, with his will or without it, his feet bore him on, and he
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: followed up the stream which the Lady had said ran into the broad river
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: called the Swelling Flood; "for," thought he, "when I come thereabout I
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: shall presently find some castle or good town, and it is like that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: either I shall have some tidings of the folk thereof, or else they will
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: compel me to do something, and that will irk me less than doing deeds
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: of mine own will."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: He went his ways till he came to where the wood and the trees ended,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and the hills were lower and longer, well grassed with short grass, a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: down country fit for the feeding of sheep; and indeed some sheep he
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: saw, and a shepherd or two, but far off.  At last, after he had left
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the stream awhile, because it seemed to him to turn and wind round over
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: much to the northward, he came upon a road running athwart the down
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: country, so that he deemed that it must lead one way down to the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Swelling Flood; so he followed it up, and after a while began to fall
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: in with folk; and first two Companions armed and bearing long swords
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: over their shoulders: he stopped as they met, and stared at them in the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: face, but answered not their greeting; and they had no will to meddle
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: with him, seeing his inches and that he was well armed, and looked no
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: craven: so they went on.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Next he came on two women who had with them an ass between two
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: panniers, laden with country stuff; and they were sitting by the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: wayside, one old and the other young.  He made no stay for them, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: though he turned his face their way, took no heed of them more than if
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: they were trees; though the damsel, who was well-liking and somewhat
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: gaily clad, stood up when she saw his face anigh, and drew her gown
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: skirt about her and moved daintily, and sighed and looked after him as
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: he went on, for she longed for him.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Yet again came two men a-horseback, merchants clad goodly, with three
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: carles, their servants, riding behind them; and all these had weapons
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and gave little more heed to him than he to them.  But a little after
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: they were gone, he stopped and said within himself: "Maybe I had better
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: have gone their way, and this road doubtless leadeth to some place of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: resort."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: But even therewith he heard horsehoofs behind him, and anon came up a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: man a-horseback, armed with jack and sallet, a long spear in his hand,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and budgets at his saddle-bow, who looked like some lord's man going a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: message.  He nodded to Ralph, who gave him good-day; for seeing these
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: folk and their ways had by now somewhat amended his mind; and now he
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: turned not, but went on as before.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: At last the way clomb a hill longer and higher than any he had yet
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: crossed, and when he had come to the brow and looked down, he saw the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: big river close below running through the wide valley which he had
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: crossed with Roger on that other day.  Then he sat down on the green
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: bank above the way, so heavy of heart that not one of the things he saw
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: gave him any joy, and the world was naught to him.  But within a while
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: he came somewhat to himself, and, looking down toward the river, he saw
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the other side, so he saw clearly that this was the ford of a highway.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: side, and sheep and neat feeding in the meadows, and in short it was
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

text: another world from the desert.

text: Ralph Falleth in With Friends and Rideth to Whitwall
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Ralph looks on to the ford and sees folk riding through the thorp
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: aforesaid and down to the river, and they take the water and are many
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: in company, some two score by his deeming, and he sees the sun
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: glittering on their weapons.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Now he thought that he would abide their coming and see if he might
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: join their company, since if he crossed the water he would be on the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: backward way: and it was but a little while ere the head of them came
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: up over the hill, and were presently going past Ralph, who rose up to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: look on them, and be seen of them, but they took little heed of him.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: So he sees that though they all bore weapons, they were not all
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: men-at-arms, nay, not more than a half score, but those proper men
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: enough.  Of the others, some half-dozen seemed by their attire to be
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: merchants, and the rest their lads; and withal they had many sumpter
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: horses and mules with them.  They greeted him not, nor he them, nor did
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: he heed them much till they were all gone by save three, and then he
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: leapt into the road with a cry, for who should be riding there but
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Blaise, his eldest brother, and Richard the Red with him, both in good
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: case by seeming; for Blaise was clad in a black coat welted with gold,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and rode a good grey palfrey, and Richard was armed well and knightly.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: They knew him at once, and drew rein, and Blaise lighted down from his
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: horse and cast his arms about Ralph, and said: "O happy day! when two
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: of the Upmeads kindred meet thus in an alien land!  But what maketh
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: thee here, Ralph?  I thought of thee as merry and safe in Upmeads?"
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Ralph said smiling, for his heart leapt up at the sight of his kindred:
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Nay, must I not seek adventures like the rest?  So I stole myself away
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: from father and mother."  "Ill done, little lord!" said Blaise,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: stroking Ralph's cheek.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Then up came Richard, and if Blaise were glad, Richard was twice glad,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and quoth he:  "Said I not, Lord Blaise, that this chick would be the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: hardest of all to keep under the coop?  Welcome to the Highways, Lord
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Ralph!  But where is thine horse? and whence and whither is it now?
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Hast thou met with some foil and been held to ransom?"
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Ralph found it hard and grievous and dull work to answer; for now again
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: his sorrow had taken hold of him:  so he said: "Yea, Richard, I have
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: had adventures, and have lost rather than won; but at least I am a free
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: man, and have spent but little gold on my loss."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "That is well," said Richard, "but whence gat ye any gold for
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: spending?" Ralph smiled, but sadly, for he called to mind the glad
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: setting forth and the kind face of dame Katherine his gossip, and he
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: said: "Clement Chapman deemed it not unmeet to stake somewhat on my
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: luck, therefore I am no pauper."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Well," said Blaise, "if thou hast no great errand elsewhere, thou
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: mightest ride with us, brother.  I have had good hap in these days,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: though scarce kingly or knightly, for I have been buying and selling:
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: what matter? few know Upmeads and its kings to wite me with fouling a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: fair name.  Richard, go fetch a horse hither for Lord Ralph's riding,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and we will tarry no longer."  So Richard trotted on, and while they
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: abode him, Ralph asked after his brethren, and Blaise told him that he
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: had seen or heard naught of them.  Then Ralph asked of whither away,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and Blaise told him to Whitwall, where was much recourse of merchants
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: from many lands, and a noble market.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Back then cometh Richard leading a good horse while Ralph was pondering
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: his matter, and thinking that at such a town he might well hear tidings
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: concerning the Well at the World's End.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Now Ralph mounts, and they all ride away together.  On the way, partly
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: for brotherhood's sake, partly that he might not be questioned overmuch
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: himself, Ralph asked Blaise to tell him more of his farings; and Blaise
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: said, that when he had left Upmeads he had ridden with Richard up and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: down and round about, till he came to a rich town which had just been
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: taken in war, and that the Companions who had conquered it were looking
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: for chapmen to cheapen their booty, and that he was the first or nearly
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the first to come who had will and money to buy, and the Companions,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: who were eager to depart, had sold him thieves' penny-worths, so that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: his share of the Upmeads' treasure had gone far; and thence he had gone
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: to another good town where he had the best of markets for his newly
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: cheapened wares, and had brought more there, such as he deemed handy to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: sell, and so had gone on from town to town, and had ever thriven, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: had got much wealth:  and so at last having heard tell of Whitwall as
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: better for chaffer than all he had yet seen, he and other chapmen had
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: armed them, and waged men-at-arms to defend them, and so tried the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: adventure of the wildwoods, and come safe through.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Then at last came the question to Ralph concerning his adventures, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: he enforced himself to speak, and told all as truly as he might,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: without telling of the Lady and her woeful ending.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Thus they gave and took in talk, and Ralph did what he might to seem
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: like other folk, that he might nurse his grief in his own heart as far
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: asunder from other men as might be.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: good store to garnish them.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: came and went; but he heard no word spoken of the Well at the World's
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: was among those who came into the hall, and he talked long with Ralph
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: at whiles; that is to say that he spake, and Ralph made semblance of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: listening.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Now as is aforesaid Richard was old and wise, and he loved Ralph much,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: more belike than Lord Blaise his proper master, whereas he had no mind
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: for chaffer, or aught pertaining to it: so he took heed of Ralph and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: about their business, and he and Ralph were left alone in the Hall, he
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: spake to Ralph and said: "This is no prison, lord."  "Even so," quoth
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: youngling!" quoth Richard; "I deem that it was thus.  Her love for thee
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: was so kind that she would have thee happy after the sundering:
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: therefore she was minded that thou shouldest find the damsel, who as I
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: deem loveth thee, and that thou shouldest love her truly."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: that she was kind indeed.  Even as heaven is kind to them who have died
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

text: martyrs, and enter into its bliss after many torments."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: kindness: for indeed to this young man she had seemed great, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: exalted far above him.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Richard looked at him a while; and then said:  "Now, I pray thee be not
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: wroth with me for the word I have spoken.  But something more shall I
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: say, which shall like thee better.  To wit, when I came back from
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Swevenham on Wednesday I deemed it most like that the Well at the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: World's End was a tale, a coloured cloud only; or that at most if it
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: were indeed on the earth, that thou shouldest never find it.  But now
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: is my mind changed by the hearing of thy tale, and I deem both that the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Well verily is, and that thou thyself shalt find it; and that the wise
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Lady knew this, and set the greater store by thy youth and goodliness,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: as a richer and more glorious gift than it had been, were it as
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: fleeting as such things mostly be.  Now of this matter will I say no
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: more; but I think that the words that I have said, and which now seem
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: so vain to thee, shall come into thy mind on some later day, and avail
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: thee somewhat; and that is why I have spoken them.  But this again is
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: another word, that I have got a right good horse for thee, and other
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: gear, such as thou mayest need for the road, and that Clement's
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: fellowship will meet in Petergate hard by the church, and I will be thy
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: wilt soon be back here."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: because I knew thee desirous of seeking adventures east-away, and knew
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: that my tales would not hinder thee."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

text: it was built and is upheld by the folks that dwell anigh, amongst whom

author: Morris, William

text: be the folk of Cheaping Knowe; and that house is hallowed unto truce,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and no man smiteth another therein; so that we oft come on the mountain
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: strong-thieves there, and there we be blithe together and feast
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: together in good fellowship.  But when there be foemen in that house
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: together, each man or each fellowship departing, hath grace of an hour
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: before his foeman follow.  Such are the customs of that house, and no
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: man breaketh them ever.  But when we depart thence we shall ride all
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: day and sleep amidst the mountains, and if we be not beset that night
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: or the morrow's morn thereof, safe and unfoughten shall we come to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Cheaping Knowe.  Doth that suffice thee as at this time?" "Yea master,"
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: quoth Ralph.

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: On that night they slept in their tents which they had pitched on the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: field of a little thorp beside a water; and there they had meat and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: drink and all things as they needed them.  And in likewise it befell
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: them the next day; but the third evening they set up their tents on a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: little hillside by a road which led into a deep pass, even the entry of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the mountains, a road which went betwixt exceeding high walls of rock.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: For the mountain sides went up steep from the plain.  There they kept
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: good watch and ward, and naught befell them to tell of.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: The next morning they entered the pass, and rode through it up to the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: heaths, and rode all day by wild and stony ways and came at even to a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: grassy valley watered by a little stream, where they guested, watching
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: their camp well; and again none meddled with them.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: As they were departing the next morn Ralph asked of Clement if he yet
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: looked for onset from the waylayers.  Said Clement: "It is most like,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: lord; for we be a rich prey, and it is but seldom that such a company
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: rideth this road.  And albeit that the wild men know not to a day when
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: we shall pass through their country, yet they know the time within a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: four and twenty hours or so.  For we may not hide our journey from all
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: men's hearing; and when the ear heareth, the tongue waggeth.  But art
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: thou yet anxious concerning this matter, son?"  "Yea," said Ralph, "for
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: I would fain look on these miscreants."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "It is like that ye shall see them," said Clement; "but I shall look on
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: it as a token that they are about waylaying us if we come on none of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: them in the Mountain House.  For they will be fearful lest their
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: purpose leak out from unwary lips." Ralph wondered how it would be, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: what might come of it, and rode on, pondering much.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: The road was rough that day, and they went not above a foot-pace the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: more part of the time; and daylong they were going up and up, and it
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: grew cold as the sun got low; though it was yet summer.  At last at the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: top of a long stony ridge, which lay beneath a great spreading
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: mountain, on the crest whereof the snow lay in plenty, Ralph saw a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: house, long and low, builded of great stones, both walls and roof: at
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: sight thereof the men of the fellowship shouted for joy, and hastened
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: on, and Clement spurred up the stony slopes all he might.  But Ralph
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: rode slowly, since he had naught to see to, save himself, so that he
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: was presently left alone.  Now he looks aside, and sees something
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: bright-hued lying under a big stone where the last rays of the sun just
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: caught some corner of it.  So he goes thither, deeming that mayhappen
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: one of the company had dropped something, pouch or clout, or what not,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: in his haste and hurry.  He got off his horse to pick it up, and when
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: he had laid hand on it found it to be a hands-breadth of fine green
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: cloth embroidered with flowers.  He held it in his hand a while
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: wondering where he could have seen such like stuff before, that it
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: should smite a pang into his heart, and suddenly called to mind the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: little hall at Bourton Abbas with the oaken benches and the rush-strewn
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: floor, and this same flower-broidered green cloth dancing about the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: naked feet of a fair damsel, as she moved nimbly hither and thither
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: dighting him his bever.  But his thought stayed not there, but carried
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: him into the days when he was abiding in desire of the love that he won
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: at last, and lost so speedily.  But as he stood pondering he heard
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Clement shouting to him from the garth-gate of that house.  So he leapt
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: on his horse and rode up the slope into the garth and lighted down by
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Clement; who fell to chiding him for tarrying, and said: "There is
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: peril in loitering outside this garth alone; for those Sons of the Rope
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: often lurk hard by for what they may easily pick up, and they be brisk
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and nimble lads."  "What ailed thee?" said Ralph.  "I stayed to look at
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: a flower which called Upmeads to my mind."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Yea lad, yea," quoth Clement, "and art thou so soft as that?  But come
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: thou into the House; it is as I deemed it might be; besides the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: House-warden and his wife there is no soul therein.  Thou shalt yet
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: look on Mick Hangman's sons, as thou desirest."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: So they went into the House, and men had all that they might need.  The
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: warden was an old hoar man, and his wife well-stricken in years; and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: to be, on those strong-thieves, and Clement asked the warden what he
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: had seen of them of late.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: The old carle answered:  "Nay, master Clement, much according to wont:
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: a few beeves driven into our garth; a pack or two brought into the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: hall; and whiles one or two of them come in hither with empty hands for
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: a sleep and a bellyful; and again a captive led in on the road to the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: market.  Forsooth it is now a good few days ago three of them brought
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: in a woman as goodly as mine eyes have ever seen; and she sat on the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: bench yonder, and seemed to heed little that she was a captive and had
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: shackles on her feet after the custom of these men, though indeed her
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: hands were unbound, so that she might eat her meat; and the carle thief
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: made a stout defence with a sword before they might take her, but being
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: taken, she made but little of it."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Would he do her any hurt?" said Ralph.  "Nay, surely," said the carle;
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "doth a man make a hole in a piece of cloth which he is taking to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: market?  Nay, he was courteous to her after his fashion, and bade us
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: give her the best of all we had."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "What like was she?" said Ralph.  Said the carle: "She was somewhat
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: tall, if I am to note such matters, grey-eyed and brown haired, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: great abundance of it.  Her lips very red; her cheeks tanned with the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: sun, but in such wise that her own white and red shone through the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: a ten-acre field when the season hath been good.  Her hands were not
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: stretched out her hand so that the wrist of her came forth from her
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: sleeve it was as white as milk."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: said; so that there be few like her."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William
