author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: suddenly, and said, still looking at him hard; "Well, it is strange!"
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: find her enthralled, and it may be past redemption."

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: somewhat like unto her, yet far goodlier.  But I grieve for thee, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

author: Morris, William

text: a weary way."

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

text: When they rode on again, Ralph rode beside Bull, who was merry and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: blithe now he was full of meat and drink; and he spake anon:  "So thou
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: art a king's son, master?  I deemed from the first that thou wert of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: lineage.  For as for these churls of chapmen, and the sworders whom
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: they wage, they know not the name of their mother's mother, nor have
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: heard one word of the beginner of their kindred; and their deeds are
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: like unto their kinlessness."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "And are thy deeds so good?" said Ralph.  "Are they ill," said Bull,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "when they are done against the foemen?"  Said Ralph: "And are all men
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: your foemen who pass through these mountains?" "All," said Bull, "but
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: they be of the kindred or their known friends."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Well, Bull," said Ralph, "I like thy deeds little, that thou shouldest
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: into toil and weariness and stripes."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Said Bull:  "How much worse do we than the chapmen by his debtor, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the lord of the manor by his villein?"  Said Ralph: "Far worse, if ye
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: did but know it, poor men!"  Quoth Bull: "But I neither know it, nor
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: can know it, nay, not when thou sayest it; for it is not so.  And look
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: you, master, this life of a bought thrall is not such an exceeding evil
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: life; for oft they be dealt with softly and friendly, and have other
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: thralls to work for them under their whips."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Ralph laughed:  "Which shall I make thee, friend Bull, the upper or the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: under?"  Bull reddened, but said naught.  Said Ralph: "Or where shall I
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: sell thee, that I may make the best penny out of my good luck and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: valiancy?"  Bull looked chopfallen: "Nay," said he in a wheedling
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: voice, "thou wilt not sell me, thou?  For I deem that thou wilt be a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: good master to me:  and," he broke into sudden heat hereat, "if I have
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: another master I shall surely slay him whate'er betide."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Ralph laughed again, and said:  "Seest thou what an evil craft ye
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: follow, when thou deemest it better to be slain with bitter torments
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: (as thou shouldest be if thou slewest thy master) than to be sold to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: any master save one exceeding good?"
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Bull held his peace hereat, but presently he said: "Well, be our craft
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: good or evil, it is gainful; and whiles there is prey taken right good,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: which, for my part, I would not sell, once I had my hand thereon."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Yea, women?" said Ralph.  "Even so," said Bull, "such an one was taken
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: by my kinsman Bull Nosy but a little while agone, whom he took down to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the market at Cheaping Knowe, as I had not done if I had once my arms
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: about her.  For she was as fair as a flower; and yet so well built,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: that she could bear as much as a strong man in some ways; and, saith
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Nosy, when she was taken, there was no weeping or screeching in her,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: but patience rather and quietness, and intent to bear all and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: live....Master, may I ask thee a question?"  "Ask on," said Ralph.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Said Bull:  "The pair of beads about thy neck, whence came they?" "They
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: were the gift of a dear friend," said Ralph.  "A woman?" quoth Bull.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Yea," said Ralph.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Now is this strange," said Bull, "and I wot not what it may betoken,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: but this same woman had about her neck a pair of beads as like to thine
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: as if they had been the very same:  did this woman give thee the beads?
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: For I will say this of thee, master, that thou art well nigh as likely
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: a man as she is a woman."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Ralph sighed, for this talk of the woman and the beads brought all the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: story into his mind, so that it was as if he saw it adoing again: the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Lady of the Wildwood led along to death before he delivered her, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: their flight together from the Water of the Oak, and that murder of her
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: in the desert.  And betwixt the diverse deeds of the day this had of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: late become somewhat dim to him.  Yet after his grief came joy that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: this man also had seen the damsel, whom his dream of the night had
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: called Dorothea, and that he knew of her captors; wherefore by his
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: means he might come on her and deliver her.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Now he spake aloud:  "Nay, it was not she that gave them to me, but yet
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: were I fain to find this woman that thou sawest; for I look to meet a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: friend whenas I meet her.  So tell me, dost thou think that I may
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: cheapen her of thy kinsman?"
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Bull shook his head, and said:  "It may be:  or it may be that he hath
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: already sold her to one who heedeth not treasure so much as fair flesh;
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and fair is hers beyond most.  But, lord, I will do my best to find her
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: for thee; as thou art a king's son and no ill master, I deem."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Do that," quoth Ralph, "and I in turn will do what more I may for thee
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: besides making thee free."  And therewith he rode forward that he might
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: get out of earshot, for Bull's tongue seemed like to be long.  And
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: presently he heard laughter behind him, as the carle began jesting and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: talking with the chapman lads.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

text: CHAPTER 23
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Of the Town of Cheaping Knowe
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Now when it was evening they pitched their camp down in the plain
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: fields amidst tall elmtrees, and had their banners still flying over
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the tents to warn all comers of what they were.  But the next morning
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the chapmen and their folk were up betimes to rummage their loads, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: to array their wares for the market; and they gat not to the road
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: before mid-morning. Meantime of their riding Ralph had more talk with
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Bull, who said to him: "Fair lord, I rede thee when thou art in the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: market of Cheaping Knowe, bid master Clement bring thee to the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: thrall-merchant, and trust me that if such a fair image as that we were
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: speaking of hath passed through his hands within these three months, he
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: will remember it; and then thou shalt have at least some tale of what
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: hath befallen her but a little while ago."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: That seemed good rede to Ralph, and when they went on their way he rode
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: beside Clement, and asked him many things concerning Cheaping Knowe;
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and at last about the thrall-market therein.  And Clement said that,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: though he dealt not in such wares, he had often seen them sold, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: knew the master of that market.  And when Ralph asked if the said
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: master would answer questions concerning the selling of men and of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: women, Clement smiled and said: "Yea, yea, he will answer; for as he
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: lives by selling thralls, and every time a thrall is sold by him he
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: maketh some gain by it, it is to his profit that they change masters as
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: often as may be; and when thou askest of the woman whom thou art
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: seeking, he will be deeming that there will be some new chaffer ahead.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: I will bring thee to him, and thou shalt ask him of what thou wilt, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: belike he will tell thee quietly over the wine-cup."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Therewith was Ralph well content, and he grew eager to enter into the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: town.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: They came to the gates a little before sunset, after they had passed
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: through much fair country; but nigh to the walls it was bare of trees
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and thickets, whereas, said Clement, they had been cut down lest they
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: should serve as cover to strong-thieves or folk assailing the town.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: The walls were strong and tall, and a great castle stood high up on a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: hill, about which the town was builded; so that if the town were taken
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: there would yet be another town within it to be taken also.  But the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: town within, save for the said castle, was scarce so fairly builded as
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the worst of the towns which Ralph had seen erst, though there were a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: many houses therein.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Much people was gathered about the gate to see the merchants enter with
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: banners displayed; and Ralph deemed many of the folk fair, such as were
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: goodly clad; for many had but foul clouts to cover their nakedness, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: seemed needy and hunger-pinched. Withal there were many warriors
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: amongst the throng, and most of these bore a token on their sleeves, to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: wit, a sword reddened with blood.  And Clement, speaking softly in
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Ralph's ear, did him to wit that this was the token of the lord who had
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: gotten the castle in those days, and was tyrant of the town; and how
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: that he had so many men-at-arms ready to do his bidding that none in
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the town was safe from him if he deemed it more for his pleasure and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: profit to rob or maim, or torment or slay, than to suffer them to live
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: peaceably.  "But with us chapmen," said Clement, "he will not meddle,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: lest there be an end of chaffer in the town; and verily the market is
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: good."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Thus they rode through the streets into the market place, which was
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: wide and great, and the best houses of the town were therein, and so
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: came to the hostel of the Merchants, called the Fleece, which was a big
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: house, and goodly enough.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: The next morning Clement and the other chapmen went up into the Castle,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: bearing with them gifts out of their wares for the lord, and Clement
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: bade Ralph keep close till he came back, and especially to keep his
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: war-caught thrall, Bull Shockhead, safe at home, lest he be taken from
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: him, and to clothe him in the guise of the chapman lads, and to dock
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: his hair; and even so Ralph did, though Bull were loath thereto.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: About noon the chapmen came back again well pleased; and Clement gave
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Ralph a parchment from the lord, which bade all men help and let pass
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Ralph of Upmeads, as a sergeant of the chapmen's guard, and said withal
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: that now he was free to go about the town if he listed, so that he were
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: back at the hostel of the Fleece by nightfall.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: So Ralph went in company with some of the sergeants and others, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: looked at this and that about the town without hindrance, save that the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: guard would not suffer them to pass further than the bailey of the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Castle.  And for the said bailey, forsooth, they had but little
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: stomach; for they saw thence, on the slopes of the Castle-hill, tokens
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: of the cruel justice of the said lord; for there were men and women
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: there, yea, and babes also, hanging on gibbets and thrust through with
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: sharp pales, and when they asked of folk why these had suffered, they
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: but looked at them as if astonished, and passed on without a word.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: So they went thence, and found the master-church, and deemed it not
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: much fairer than it was great; and it was nowise great, albeit it was
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: strange and uncouth of fashion.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Then they came to great gardens within the town, and they were
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: exceeding goodly, and had trees and flowers and fruits in them which
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Ralph had not seen hitherto, as lemons, and oranges, and pomegranates;
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and the waters were running through them in runnels of ashlar; and the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: weather was fair and hot; so they rested in those gardens till it was
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: evening, and then gat them home to Fleece, where they had good
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: entertainment.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

text: CHAPTER 24
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Ralph Heareth More Tidings of the Damsel
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: The second day, while the merchants saw to their chaffer, most of the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: men-at-arms, and Ralph with them, spent their time again in those
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: goodly gardens; where, indeed, some of them made friends of fair women
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: of the place; in which there was less risk than had been for aliens in
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: some towns, whereas at Cheaping Knowe such women as were wedded
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: according to law, or damsels in the care of their kindred, or slaves
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: who were concubines, had not dared so much as to look on a man.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: The third day time hung somewhat heavy on Ralph's hands, not but that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the Companions were well at ease, but rather because himseemed that he
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: was not stirring in the quest.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: But the next day Clement bade him come see that thrall-merchant
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: aforesaid, and brought him to a corner of the market-place, where was a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: throng looking on at the cheaping.  They went through the throng, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: beside a stone like a leaping-on stone saw a tall man, goodly of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: presence, black bearded, clad in scarlet; and this was the merchant;
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and by him were two of his knaves and certain weaponed men who had
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: brought their wares to the cheaping.  And some of these were arrayed
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: like those foemen of the mountains.  There was a half score and three
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: of these chattels to be sold, who stood up one after other on the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: stone, that folk might cheapen them.  The cheaping was long about,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: because they that had a mind to buy were careful to know what they were
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: buying, like as if they had been cheapening a horse, and most of them
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: before they bid their highest had the chattels away into the merchant's
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: booth to strip them, lest they should buy damaged or unhandsome bodies;
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and this more especially if it were a woman, for the men were already
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: well nigh naked.  Of women four of them were young and goodly, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Ralph looked at them closely; but they were naught like to the woman of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: his quest.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Now this cheaping irked Ralph sorely, as was like to be, whereas, as
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: hath been told, he came from a land where were no thralls, none but
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: vavassors and good yeomen:  yet he abode till all was done, hansel
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: paid, and the thralls led off by their new masters.  Then Clement led
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: him up to the merchant, to whom he gave the sele of the day, and said:
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Master, this is the young knight of whom I told thee, who deemeth that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: a woman who is his friend hath been brought to this market and sold
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: there, and if he might, he would ransom her."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: The merchant greeted Ralph courteously, and bade him and Clement come
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: into his house, where they might speak more privily.  So did they, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: he treated them with honour, and set wine and spices before them, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: bade Ralph say whatlike the woman was.  Ralph did so, and wondered at
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: himself how well and closely he could tell of her, like as a picture
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: painted.  And, moreover, he drew forth that piece of her gown which he
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: had come on by the Mid-Mountain House.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: So when he had done, the merchant, who was a man sober of aspect and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: somewhat slow of speech, said:  "Sir, I believe surely that I have seen
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: this damsel, but she is not with me now, nor have I sold her ever; but
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: hither was she brought to be sold by a man of the mountain folk not
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: very many days ago.  And the man's name was Bull Nosy, or the longnosed
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: man of the kindred of the Bull, for in such wise are named the men of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: that unhappy folk.  Now this was the cause why I might not sell her,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: that she was so proud and stout that men feared her, what she might do
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: if they had her away.  And when some spake to see her body naked, she
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: denied it utterly, saying that she would do a mischief to whomsoever
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: tried it.  So I spake to him who owned her, and asked him if he thought
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: it good to take her a while and quell her with such pains as would
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: spoil her but little, and then bring her to market when she was meeker.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: But he heeded my words little, and led her away, she riding on a horse
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and he going afoot beside her; for the mountain-men be no horsemen."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Said Ralph:  "Dost thou know at all whither he will have led her?" Said
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the merchant:  "By my deeming, he will have gone first of all to the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: town of Whiteness, whither thy Fellowship will betake them ere long:
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: for he will be minded to meet there the Lord of Utterbol, who is for
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: such like wares; and he will either give her to him as a gift, for
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: which he will have a gift in return, or he will sell her to my lord at
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: a price if he dare to chaffer with him.  At least so will he do if he
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: be wise.  Now if the said lord hath her, it will be somewhat more than
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: hard for thee to get her again, till he have altogether done with her;
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: for money and goods are naught to him beside the doing of his will.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: But there is this for thy comfort, that whereas she is so fair a woman,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: she will be well with my lord.  For I warrant me that she will not dare
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: to be proud with him, as she was with the folk here."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Yea," said Ralph, "and what is this lord of Utterbol that all folk,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: men and women, fear him so?"  Said the merchant: "Fair sir, thou must
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: pardon me if I say no more of him.  Belike thou mayst fall in with him;
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and if thou dost, take heed that thou make not thyself great with him."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: So Ralph thanked the merchant and departed with Clement, of whom
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: presently he asked if he knew aught of this lord of Utterbol.  Said
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Clement: "God forbid that I should ever meet him, save where I were
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: many and he few.  I have never seen him; but he is deemed by all men as
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the worst of the tyrants who vex these lands, and, maybe, the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: mightiest."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: So was Ralph sore at heart for the damsel, and anon he spake to Bull
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: again of her, who deemed somewhat, that his kinsman had been minded at
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the first to sell her to the lord of Utterbol.  And Ralph thinks his
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: game a hard one, yet deems that if he could but find out where the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: damsel was, he might deliver her, what by sleight, what by boldness.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: The Fellowship Comes to Whiteness
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Two days thereafter the chapmen having done with their matters in
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Cheaping Knowe, whereas they must needs keep some of their wares for
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: other places, and especially for Goldburg, they dight them to be gone
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and rode out a-gates of a mid-morning with banners displayed.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: It was some fifty miles thence to Whiteness, which lay close underneath
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the mountains, and was, as it were, the door of the passes whereby men
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: rode to Goldburg.  The land which they passed through was fair, both of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: tillage and pasture, with much cattle therein.  Everywhere they saw men
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and women working afield, but no houses of worthy yeomen or vavassors,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: or cots of good husbandmen.  Here and there was a castle or
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: strong-house, and here and there long rows of ugly hovels, or whiles
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: houses, big tall and long, but exceeding foul and ill-favoured, such as
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Ralph had not yet seen the like of.  And when he asked of Clement
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: concerning all this, he said:  "It is as I have told thee, that here be
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: no freemen who work afield, nay, nor villeins either.  All those whom
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: ye have seen working have been bought and sold like to those whom we
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: saw standing on the Stone in the market of Cheaping Knowe, or else were
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: born of such cattle, and each one of them can be bought and sold again,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and they work not save under the whip.  And as for those hovels and the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: long and foul houses, they are the stables wherein this kind of cattle
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: is harboured."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Then Ralph's heart sank, and he said:  "Master Clement, I prithee tell
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: me; were it possible that the damsel whom I seek may be come to such a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: pass as one of these?" "Nay," quoth Clement, "that is little like to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: be; such goodly wares are kept for the adornment of great men's houses.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: True it is that whiles the house-thralls be sent into the fields for
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: their punishment; yet not such as she, unless the master be wholly
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: wearied of them, or if their wrath outrun their wits; for it is more to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the master's profit to chastise them at home; so keep a good heart I
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: bid thee, and maybe we shall have tidings at Whiteness."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: So Ralph refrained his anxious heart, though forsooth his thought was
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: much upon the damsel and of how she was faring.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: It was not till the third day at sunset that they came to Whiteness;
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: for on the last day of their riding they came amongst the confused
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: hills that lay before the great mountains, which were now often hidden
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: from their sight; but whenever they appeared through the openings of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the near hills, they seemed very great and terrible; dark and bare and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: stony; and Clement said that they were little better than they looked
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: from afar.  As to Whiteness, they saw it a long way off, as it lay on a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: long ridge at the end of a valley: and so long was the ridge, that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: behind it was nothing green; naught but the huge and bare mountains.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: The westering sun fell upon its walls and its houses, so that it looked
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: white indeed against those great cliffs and crags; though, said
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Clement, that these were yet a good way off.  Now when, after a long
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: ride from the hither end of the valley, they drew nigh to the town,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Ralph saw that the walls and towers were not very high or strong, for
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: so steep was the hill whereon the town stood, that it needed not.  Here
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: also was no great castle within the town as at Cheaping Knowe, and the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: town itself nothing so big, but long and straggling along the top of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the ridge.  Cheaping Knowe was all builded of stone; but the houses
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: here were of timber for the most part, done over with pargeting and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: whitened well.  Yet was the town more cheerful of aspect than Cheaping
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Knowe, and the folk who came thronging about the chapmen at the gates
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: not so woe-begone, and goodly enough.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Of the lord of Whiteness, Clement told that he paid tribute to him of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Cheaping Knowe, rather for love of peace than for fear of him; for he
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: was no ill lord, and free men lived well under him.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: So the chapmen lodged in the market-place; and in two days time Ralph
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: got speech of the Deacon of the Chapmen of the Town; who told him two
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: matters; first that the lord of Utterbol had not been in Whiteness
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: these six months; and next that the wild man had verily brought the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: damsel into the market; but he had turned away thence suddenly with
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: her, without bringing her to the stone, and that it was most like that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: he would have the lord of Utterbol buy her; who, since he would be
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: deeming that he might easily bend her to his will, would give him the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: better penny for her.  "At the last," quoth the Deacon, "the wild man
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: led her away toward the mountain pass that goeth to Goldburg, the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: damsel and he alone, and she with her hands unbound and riding a little
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: horse." Of these tidings Ralph deemed it good that all traces of her
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: were not lost; but his heart misgave him when he thought that by this
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: time she must surely be in the hands of the lord of Utterbol.

text: They Ride the Mountains Toward Goldburg
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Five days the Fellowship abode at Whiteness, and or ever they departed
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Clement waged men-at-arms of the lord of the town, besides servants to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: look to the beasts amongst the mountains, so that what with one, what
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: with another, they entered the gates of the mountains a goodly company
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: of four score and ten.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Ralph asked of Bull if any of those whom he might meet in these
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: mountains were of his kindred; and he answered, nay, unless perchance
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: there might be some one or two going their peaceful errands there like
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Bull Nosy.  So Ralph armed him with a good sword and a shield, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: would have given him a steel hood also, but he would not bear it,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: saying that if sword and shield could not keep his head he had well
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: earned a split skull.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Seven days they rode the mountains, and the way was toilsome and weary
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: enough, for it was naught but a stony maze of the rocks where nothing
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: living dwelt, and nothing grew, save now and again a little dwarf
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: willow.  Yet was there naught worse to meet save toil, because they
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: were over strong for the wild men to meddle with them, whereas the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: kindreds thereabout were but feeble.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: But as it drew towards evening on the seventh day Ralph had ridden a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: little ahead with Bull alone, if he might perchance have a sight of the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: ending of this grievous wilderness, as Clement said might be, since now
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the way was down-hill, and all waters ran east.  So as they rode, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: it was about sunset, they saw something lying by a big stone under a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: cliff; so they drew nigh, and saw a man lying on his back, and they
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: deemed he was dead.  So Bull went up to him, and leapt off his horse
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: close by him and bent over him, but straightway cast up his arms and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: set up a long wailing whoop, and then another and another, so that they
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: that were behind heard it and came up upon the spur.  But Ralph leapt
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: from his horse, and ran up to Bull and said: "What aileth thee to whoop
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and wail?  Who is it?"  But Bull turned about and shook his head at
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: him, and said:  "It is a man of my kindred, even he that was leading
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: away thy she-friend; and belike she it was that slew him, or why is she
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: not here: Ochone! ahoo! ahoo!"  Therewith fire ran through Ralph's
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: heart, and he bethought him of that other murder in the wilderness, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: he fell to wringing his hands, and cried out:  "Ah, and where is she,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: where is she?  Is she also taken away from me for ever?  O me unhappy!"
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: And he drew his sword therewith, and ran about amongst the rocks and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the bushes seeking her body.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: And therewith came up Clement, and others of the company, and wondered
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: to see Bull kneeling down by the corpse, and to hear him crying out and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: wailing, and Ralph running about like one mad, and crying out now: "Oh!
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: that I might find her!  Mayhappen she is alive yet, and anigh here in
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: some cleft of the rocks in this miserable wilderness.  O my love that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: hast lain in mine arms, wouldst thou not have me find her alive?  But
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: if she be dead, then will I slay myself, for as young as I am, that I
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: may find thee and her out of the world, since from the world both ye
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: are gone."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Then Clement went up to Ralph, and would have a true tale out of him,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and asked him what was amiss; but Ralph stared wild at him and answered
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: not.  But Bull cried out from where he knelt:  "He is seeking the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: woman, and I would that he could find her; for then would I slay her on
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: That word heard Ralph, and he ran at Bull with uplifted sword to slay
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: him; but Clement tripped him and he fell, and his sword flew out of his

text: hand.  Then Clement and two of the others bound his hands with their
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: girdles, till they might know what had befallen; for they deemed that a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: devil had entered into him, and feared that he would do a mischief to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: himself or some other.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: And now was the whole Fellowship assembled, and stood in a ring round
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: about Ralph and Bull, and the dead man; as for him, he had been dead
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: some time, many days belike; but in that high and clear cold air, his
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: carcase, whistled by the wind, had dried rather than rotted, and his
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: face was clear to be seen with its great hooked nose and long black
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: hair: and his skull was cloven.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Now Bull had done his wailing for his kinsman, and he seemed to wake up
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: as from a dream, and looked about the ring of men and spake:  "Here is
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: a great to do, my masters!  What will ye with me?  Have ye heard, or is
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: it your custom, that when a man cometh on the dead corpse of his
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: brother, his own mother's son, he turneth it over with his foot, as if
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: it were the carcase of a dog, and so goeth on his way?  This I ask,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: that albeit I be but a war-taken thrall, I be suffered to lay my
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: brother in earth and heap a howe over him in these mountains."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: They all murmured a yeasay to this save Ralph.  He had been sobered by
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: his fall, and was standing up now betwixt Clement and the captain, who
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: had unbound his hands, now that the others had come up; he hung his
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: head, and was ashamed of his fury by seeming.  But when Bull had
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: spoken, and the others had answered, Ralph said to Bull, wrathfully
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: still, but like a man in his wits: "Why didst thou say that thou
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: wouldest slay her?"  "Hast thou found her?" said Bull.  "Nay," quoth
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Ralph, sullenly.  "Well, then," said Bull, "when thou dost find her, we
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: will speak of it." Said Ralph:  "Why didst thou say that she hath slain
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: him?" "I was put out of my wits by the sight of him dead," said Bull;
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "But now I say mayhappen she hath slain him."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "And mayhappen not," said Clement; "look here to the cleaving of his
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: skull right through this iron headpiece, which he will have bought at
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Cheaping Knowe (for I have seen suchlike in the armourers' booth
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: there): it must have taken a strong man to do this."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Yea," quoth the captain, "and a big sword to boot: this is the stroke
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: of a strong man wielding a good weapon."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Said Bull:  "Well, and will my master bid me forego vengeance for my
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: brother's slaying, or that I bear him to purse?  Then let him slay me
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: now, for I am his thrall."  Said Ralph: "Thou shalt do as thou wilt
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: herein, and I also will do as I will.  For if she slew him, the taking
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: of her captive should be set against the slaying."  "That is but
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: right," said the captain; "but Sir Ralph, I bid thee take the word of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: an old man-at-arms for it, that she slew him not; neither she, nor any
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: other woman."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Said Clement:  "Well, let all this be.  But tell me, lord Ralph, what
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: thou wouldst do, since now thou art come to thyself again?" Said Ralph:
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "I would seek the wilderness hereabout, if perchance the damsel be
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: thrust into some cleft or cavern, alive or dead."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Well," said Clement, "this is my rede.  Since Bull Shockhead would
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: bury his brother, and lord Ralph would seek the damsel, and whereas
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: there is water anigh, and the sun is well nigh set, let us pitch our
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: tents and abide here till morning, and let night bring counsel unto
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: some of us.  How say ye, fellows?"
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: None naysaid it, and they fell to pitching the tents, and lighting the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: cooking-fires; but Bull at once betook him to digging a grave for his
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: brother, whilst Ralph with the captain and four others went and sought
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: all about the place, and looked into all clefts of rocks, and found not
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the maiden, nor any token of her.  They were long about it, and when
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: they were come back again, and it was night, though the moon shone out,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: there was Bull Shockhead standing by the howe of his brother Bull Nosy,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: which was heaped up high over the place where they had found him.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: So when Bull saw him, he turned to him and said: "King's son, I have
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: done what needs was for this present.  Now, wilt thou slay me for my
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: fault, or shall I be thy man again, and serve thee truly unless the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: blood feud come between us?" Said Ralph:  "Thou shalt serve me truly,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and help me to find him who hath slain thy brother, and carried off the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: damsel; for even thus it hath been done meseemeth, since about here we
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: have seen no signs of her alive or dead.  But to-morrow we shall seek
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: wider ere I ride on my way." "Yea," said Bull, "and I will be one in
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the search."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: So then they gat them to their sleeping-berths, and Ralph, contrary to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: his wont, lay long awake, pondering these things; till at last he said
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: to himself that this woman, whom he called Dorothea, was certainly
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: alive, and wotted that he was seeking her.  And then it seemed to him
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: that he could behold her through the darkness of night, clad in the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: green flowered gown as he had first seen her, and she bewailing her
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: captivity and the long tarrying of the deliverer as she went to and fro
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: in a great chamber builded of marble and done about with gold and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: bright colours: and or ever he slept, he deemed this to be a vision of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: what then was, rather than a memory of what had been; and it was sweet
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: to his very soul.

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

text: Clement Tells of Goldburg
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Now when it was morning he rose early and roused Bull and the captain,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and they searched in divers places where they had not been the night
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: before, and even a good way back about the road they had ridden
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: yesterday, but found no tidings.  And Ralph said to himself that this
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: was naught but what he had looked for after that vision of the night.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: So he rode with his fellows somewhat shamefaced that they had seen that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: sudden madness in him; but was presently of better cheer than he had
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: been yet.  He rode beside Clement; they went downhill speedily, and the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: wilderness began to better, and there was grass at whiles, and bushes
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: here and there.  A little after noon they came out of a pass cleft deep
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: through the rocks by a swift stream which had once been far greater
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: than then, and climbed up a steep ridge that lay across the road, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: looking down from the top of it, beheld the open country again.  But
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: this was otherwise from what they had beheld from the mountain's brow
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: above Cheaping Knowe.  For thence the mountains beyond Whiteness, even
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: those that they had just ridden, were clear to be seen like the wall of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the plain country.  But here, looking adown, the land below them seemed
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: but a great spreading plain with no hills rising from it, save that far
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: away they could see a certain break in it, and amidst that, something
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: that was brighter than the face of the land elsewhere.  Clement told
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Ralph that this was Goldburg and that it was built on a gathering of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: hills, not great, but going up steep from the plain.  And the plain,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: said he, was not so wholly flat and even as it looked from up there,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: but swelled at whiles into downs and low hills.  He told him that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Goldburg was an exceeding fair town to behold; that the lord who had
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: built it had brought from over the mountains masons and wood-wrights
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and artificers of all kinds, that they might make it as fair as might
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: be, and that he spared on it neither wealth nor toil nor pains.  For in
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: sooth he deemed that he should find the Well at the World's End, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: drink thereof, and live long and young and fair past all record;
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: therefore had he builded this city, to be the house and home of his
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: long-enduring joyance.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Now some said that he had found the Well, and drank thereof; others
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: naysaid that; but all deemed that they knew how that Goldburg was not
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: done building ere that lord was slain in a tumult, and that what was
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: then undone was cobbled up after the uncomely fashion of the towns
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: thereabout.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Clement said moreover that, this happy lord dead, things had not gone
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: so well there as had been looked for.  Forsooth it had been that lord's
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: will and meaning that all folks in Goldburg should thrive, both those
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: who wrought and those for whom they wrought.  But it went not so, but
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: there were many poor folk there, and few wealthy.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Again said Clement that though the tillers and toilers of Goldburg were
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: not for the most part mere thralls and chattels, as in the lands beyond
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the mountains behind them, yet were they little more thriving for that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: cause; whereas they belonged not to a master, who must at worst feed
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: them, and to no manor, whose acres they might till for their
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: livelihood, and on whose pastures they might feed their cattle; nor had
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: they any to help or sustain them against the oppressor and the violent
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: man; so that they toiled and swinked and died with none heeding them,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: save they that had the work of their hands good cheap; and they
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: forsooth heeded them less than their draught beasts whom they must
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: needs buy with money, and whose bellies they must needs fill; whereas
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: these poor wretches were slaves without a price, and if one died
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: another took his place on the chance that thereby he might escape
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: present death by hunger, for there was a great many of them.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William
