title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: That night they slept yet amongst the mountains, or rather in the first
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: of the hill country at their feet; but on the morrow they rode down
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: into the lowlands, and thereby lost all sight of Goldburg, and it was
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: yet afar off, so that they rode four days through lands well-tilled,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: but for the most part ill-housed, a country of little hills and hollows
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and rising grounds, before they came in sight of it again heaving up
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: huge and bright under the sun.  It was built partly on three hills, the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: buttresses of a long ridge which turned a wide river, and on the ridge
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: itself, and partly on the flat shore of the river, on either side,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: hillward and plainward: but a great white wall girt it all about, which
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: went right over the river as a bridge, and on the plain side it was
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: exceeding high, so that its battlements might be somewhat evened with
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: those of the hill-wall above.  So that as they came up to the place
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: they saw little of the town because of the enormity of the wall; scarce
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: aught save a spire or a tall towering roof here and there.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: So when they were come anigh the gate, they displayed their banners and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: rode right up to it; and people thronged the walls to see their riding.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: One by one they passed through the wicket of the gate:  which gate
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: itself was verily huge beyond measure, all built of great
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: long and exceeding high, most fairly vaulted; midmost of the said hall
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: they rode through a noble arch on their right hand, and lo another hall
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: exceeding long, but lower than the first, with many glazen windows set
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: in its townward wall; and when they looked through these, they saw the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: river running underneath; for this was naught but the lower bridge of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the city and they learned afterwards and saw, that above the vault of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: this long bridge rose up the castle, chamber on chamber, till its
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: battlements were level with the highest towers of the wall on the hill
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: top.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Thus they passed the bridge, and turning to the left at its ending,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: came into the Water-Street of Goldburg, where the river, with wide
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: quays on either side thereof, ran betwixt the houses.  As for these,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: beneath the dwellings went a fair arched passage like to the ambulatory
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: of an abbey; and every house all along this street was a palace for its
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and knots of flowers; goodly were the windows and all glazed, as fair
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: were not sea-goers, river-ships that might get them through the bridges
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and furnished with masts that might be lowered and shipped.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Much people was gathered to see the chapmen enter, yet scarce so many
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: as might be looked for in so goodly a town; yea, and many of the folk
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: were clad foully, and were haggard of countenance, and cried on the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: chapmen for alms.  Howbeit some were clad gaily and richly enough, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: were fair of favour as any that Ralph had seen since he left Upmeads:

text: On the morrow, when Ralph and Clement met in the hall, Clement spake
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and said:  "Lord Ralph, as I told thee in Whitwall, we chapmen are now
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: at the end of our outward journey, and in about twenty days time we
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: shall turn back to the mountains; but, as I deem, thou wilt be minded
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: to follow up thy quest of the damsel, and whatsoever else thou mayst be
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: seeking.  Now this thou mayst well do whiles we are here in Goldburg,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and yet come back hither in time to fare back with us: and also, if
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: thou wilt, thou mayst have fellows in thy quest, to wit some of those
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: our men-at-arms, who love thee well.  But now, when thou hast done thy
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: best these days during, if thou hast then found naught, I counsel thee
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and beseech thee to come thy ways back with us, that we twain may wend
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: to Upmeads together, where thou shalt live well, and better all the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: deeds of thy father.  Meseemeth this will be more meet for thee than
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the casting away of thy life in seeking a woman, who maybe will be
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: naught to thee when thou hast found her; or in chasing some castle in
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the clouds, that shall be never the nigher to thee, how far soever thou
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: farest.  For now I tell thee that I have known this while how thou art
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: seeking the Well at the World's End; and who knoweth that there is any
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: such thing on the earth?  Come, then, thou art fair, and young, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: strong; and if ye seek wealth thou shalt have it, and my furtherance to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the utmost, if that be aught worth.  Bethink thee, child, there are
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: they that love thee in Upmeads and thereabout, were it but thy gossip,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: my wife, dame Katherine."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Said Ralph:  "Master Clement, I thank thee for all that thou hast said,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and thy behest, and thy deeds.  Thy rede is good, and in all ways will
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: I follow it save one; to wit, that if I have not found the damsel ere
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: ye turn back, I must needs abide in this land searching for her.  And I
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: pray the pardon both of thee and of thy gossip, if I answer not your
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: love as ye would, and perchance as I should.  Yea, and of Upmeads also
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: I crave pardon.  But in doing as I do, my deed shall be but according
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: to the duty bounden on me by mine oath, when Duke Osmond made me knight
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: last year, in the church of St. Laurence of Upmeads."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Said Clement:  "I see that there is something else in it than that; I
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: see thee to be young, and that love and desire bind thee in closer
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: bonds than thy knightly oath.  Well, so it must be, and till thou hast
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: her, there is but one woman in the world for thee."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Nay, it is not so, Master Clement," said Ralph, "and I will tell thee
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: this, so that thou mayst trow my naysay; since I departed from Upmeads,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: I have been taken in the toils of love, and desired a fair woman, and I
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: have won her and death hath taken her.  Trowest thou my word?"
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Yea," said Clement, "but to one of thy years love is not plucked up by
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the root, and it soon groweth again."  Then said Ralph, sadly: "Now
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: tell my gossip of this when thou comest home." Clement nodded yeasay,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and Ralph spake again in a moment: "And now will I begin my search in
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Goldburg by praying thee to bring me to speech of merchants and others
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: who may have seen or heard tidings of my damsel."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: He looked at Clement anxiously as he spoke; and Clement smiled, for he
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: said to himself that looking into Ralph's heart on this matter was like
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: looking into a chamber through an open window.  But he said:  "Fear not
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: but I will look to it; I am thy friend, and not thy schoolmaster."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Therewith he departed from Ralph, and within three days he had brought
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: him to speech of all those who were like to know anything of the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: matter; and one and all they said that they had seen no such woman, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: that as for the Lord of Utterbol, he had not been in Goldburg these
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: three months.  But one of the merchants said:  "Master Clement, if this
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: young knight is boun for Utterbol, he beareth his life in his hand, as
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: thou knowest full well.  Now I rede thee bring him to our Queen, who is
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: good and compassionate, and if she may not help him otherwise, yet
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: belike she may give him in writing to show to that tyrant, which may
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: stand him in stead: for it does not do for any man to go against the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: will of our Lady and Queen; who will surely pay him back for his
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: ill-will some day or other." Said Clement:  "It is well thought of, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: I will surely do as thou biddest."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: So wore four days, and, that time during, Ralph was going to and fro
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: asking questions of folk that he came across, as people new come to the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: city and hunters from the mountain-feet and the forests of the plain,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and mariners and such like, concerning the damsel and the Lord of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Utterbol; and Bull also went about seeking tidings: but whereas Ralph
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: asked downright what he wanted to know, Bull was wary, and rather led
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: men on to talk with him concerning those things than asked them of them
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: in such wise that they saw the question.  Albeit it was all one, and no
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: tidings came to them; indeed, the name of the Lord of Utterbol (whom
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and they commonly went away at once when it was spoken.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: On the fifth day came Clement to Ralph and said: "Now will I bring thee
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: to the Queen, and she is young, and so fair, and withal so wise, that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: it seems to me not all so sure but that the sight of her will make an
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: end of thy quest once for all.  So that meseems thou mayest abide here
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: in a life far better than wandering amongst uncouth folk, perilous and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: cruel.  Yea, so thou mayst have it if thou wilt, being so exceeding
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: goodly, and wise, and well-spoken, and of high lineage."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: together to the High House of the Queen, which was like a piece of the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: for none but the feet of the fairest of women.  And all this was set
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: amidst of gardens, the like of which they had never seen.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: But they entered without more ado, and were brought by the pages to the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Lady's innermost chamber; and if the rest of the house were goodly,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: this was goodlier, and a marvel, so that it seemed wrought rather by
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: had said with Clement that the Queen who sat there was the goodliest
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: part thereof.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Now she spake to Clement and said:  "Hail, merchant!  Is this the young
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: knight of whom thou tellest, he who seeketh his beloved that hath been
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: borne away into thralldom by evil men?"
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Even so," said Clement.  But Ralph spake:  "Nay, Lady, the damsel whom
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: I seek is not my beloved, but my friend.  My beloved is dead."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: The Queen looked on him smiling kindly, yet was her face somewhat
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: troubled.  She said:  "Master chapman, thy time here is not over long
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: for all that thou hast to do; so we give thee leave to depart with our
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: thanks for bringing a friend to see us.  But this knight hath no
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: affairs to look to: so if he will abide with us for a little, it will
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: be our pleasure."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: So Clement made his obeisance and went his ways.  But the Queen bade
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Ralph sit before her, and tell her of his griefs, and she looked so
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: kindly and friendly upon him that the heart melted within him, and he
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: might say no word, for the tears that brake out from him, and he wept
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: before her; while she looked on him, the colour coming and going in her
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: face, and her lips trembling, and let him weep on.  But he thought not
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: of her, but of himself and how kind she was to him.  But after a while
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: he mastered his passion and began, and told her all he had done and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: suffered.  Long was the tale in the telling, for it was sweet to him to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: whiles she listened to him, and whiles, not, but all the time she gazed
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: on him, yet sometimes askance, as if she were ashamed.  As for him, he
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: in his heart for her, more than for one of the painted women on the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: wall, for as kind and as dear as he deemed her.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: her, and spake:  "Sad it is for the mother that bore thee that thou art
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: not in her house, wherein all things would be kind and familiar to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

text: which is no great way from Utterbol, and is the last town whereof we

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

text: For those three days he was still seeking tidings everywhere, till folk
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: began to know of him far and wide, and to talk of him.  And at the time
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: appointed he went to the Queen's House and was brought to her chamber
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: as before, and she was alone therein.  She greeted him and smiled on
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: him exceeding kindly, but he might not fail to note of her that she
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: looked sad and her face was worn by sorrow.  She bade him sit beside
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: her, and said: "Hast thou any tidings of the woman whom thou seekest?"
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: out-a-gates. I have some good friends who will go with me awhile.  But
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: thou, Lady, hast thou heard aught?"
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Naught of the damsel," she said.  "But there is something else.  As
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Clement told me, thou seekest the Well at the World's End, and through
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Utterness and by Utterbol is a way whereby folk seek thither.  Mayst
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: thou find it, and may it profit thee more than it did my kinsman of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: old, who first raised up Goldburg in the wilderness.  Whereas for him
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: was naught but strife and confusion, till he was slain in a quarrel,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: wherein to fail was to fail, and to win the day was to win shame and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: misery."

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: She looked on him sweetly and said:  "Thou art nowise such as he; and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: if thou drink of the Well, thou wilt go back to Upmeads, and thy father
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and mother, and thine own folk and thine home.  But now here is the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: letter which thou shalt give to the Lord of Utterbol if thou meet him;
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and mayhappen he is naught so evil a man as the tale of him runs."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: She gave him the letter into his hands, and spake again: "And now I
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: have this to say to thee, if anything go amiss with thee, and thou be
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: mayst be, or whatsoever deed thou mayst have done, here will be the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Her voice shook a little as she spake, and she was silent again,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: mastering her trouble.  Then she said:  "At last I must say this to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: thee, that there may no lie be between us.  That damsel of whom thou
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: spakest that she was but thy friend, and not thy love--O that I might
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: into:  but at least he looked not a fierce or cruel man; nor indeed did

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

author: Morris, William

text: thee to a courteous joust; but do thou nay-say it, for he is a mere
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: felon, and shalt set his men-at-arms on thee, and then will rob thee
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and slay thee after, or cast thee into his prison."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: keeping, and held it open in his hand, and when the knight called out
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: on him in a rough voice as they drew anigh, he said: "Nay, sir, I may
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: knitted brow:  "Fair sir, since thou art a friend of our lord, wilt
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: like a swine snorting, and sat him down on the grass again.  Ralph
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: heeded him naught, but was glad that his let-pass was shown to be good
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: for something; but he could see that the minstrel was nigh sick for
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: fear and was shaking like an aspen leaf, and it was long ere he found
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: his tongue again.

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Forth then they rode till dusk, when the minstrel stayed Ralph at a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: builded, which Ralph took for a hostelry, though it had no sign nor
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: bush.  They entered the said house, wherein was an old woman to whom
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: to beds thereafter.

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: sun the minstrel seemed glad again, and talked abundantly, even though
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: at whiles Ralph answered him little.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: there was but tillage here and there in patches: of houses there were
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: woods scattered about the country-side.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: were riding up to the skirts of one of the woods aforesaid, weaponed
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: all, and four were horsed.  Ralph set his hand to his sword, but the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: let-pass again and show it in thine hand, and then let us on."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: end of his riding staff, and so rode trembling by Ralph's side:
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

text: was utterly uncouth.

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: The minstrel was loud in his mirth when they were well past these men;
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: but Ralph rode on silently, and was somewhat soberly.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Fair sir," quoth the minstrel, "I would wager that I know thy
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: thought."  "Yea," said Ralph, "what is it then?" Said the minstrel:
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Thou art thinking what thou shalt do when thou meetest suchlike folk
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: on thy way back; but fear not, for with that same seal thou shalt pass
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: through the land again." Said Ralph:  "Yea, something like that,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: forsooth, was my thought.  But also I was pondering who should be my
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: guide when I leave Utterbol."  The minstrel looked at him askance;
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: quoth he: "Thou mayst leave thinking of that awhile."  Ralph looked
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: hard at him, but could make naught of the look of his face; so he said:
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Why dost thou say that?"  Said Morfinn: "Because I know whither thou
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: art bound, and have been wondering this long while that thou hast asked
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: me not about the way to the WELL at the WORLD'S END:  since I told thy
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: friend the merchant that I could tell thee somewhat concerning it.  But
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: I suppose thou hast been thinking of something else?"
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Well," said Ralph, "tell me what thou hast to say of the Well." Said
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Morfinn:  "This will I tell thee first:  that if thou hast any doubt
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: that such a place there is, thou mayst set that aside; for we of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Utterness and Utterbol are sure thereof; and of all nations and peoples
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: whereof we know, we deem that we are the nighest thereto.  How sayest
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: thou, is that not already something?" "Yea, verily," said Ralph.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Now," said Morfinn, "the next thing to be said is that we are on the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: road thereto:  but the third thing again is this, lord, that though few
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: who seek it find it, yet we know that some have failed not of it,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: besides that lord of Goldburg, of whom I know that thou hast heard.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Furthermore, there dwelleth a sage in the woods not right far from
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Utterbol, a hermit living by himself; and folk seek to him for divers
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: lore, to be holpen by him in one way or other, and of him men say that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: he hath so much lore concerning the road to the Well (whether he hath
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: been there himself they know not certainly), that if he will, he can
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: put anyone on the road so surely that he will not fail to come there,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: but he be slain on the way, as I said to thee in Goldburg.  True it is
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: that the said sage is chary of his lore, and if he think any harm of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the seeker, he will show him naught; but, fair sir, thou art so valiant
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and so goodly, and as meseemeth so good a knight per amours, that I
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: deem it a certain thing that he will tell thee the uttermost of his
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: knowledge."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: since he had had that story of the damsel from the minstrel, she had
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: stood in the way before the Well at the World's End.  But now he said:
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: either at the Lord or at Ralph.  Wherefore he knew for certain that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: when he had called him traitor even now, that it was no more than the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: very sooth, and that he had fallen into the trap; though how or why he
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: wotted not clearly.  Well then might his heart have fallen, but so it
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

text: "Well," said the lord, turning towards Morfinn, "the catch is good,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: lucky man:  David will give thee gold for it, and thou mayst go back
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: go unscathed from before thee, lord:  for he looked not to meet thee
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: kept there till thou camest."

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

text: The lord said, grimly:  "He is not far wrong to fear me, maybe: but he
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: shall go for this time.  But if he bring me not those women within
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: them, let him look to it.  Give him his gold, David.  Now take ye the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: David smiled on Ralph and led him out unto a tent not far off, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: there he made much of him, and bade bring meat and drink and all he
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: he showed him how nigh the guards were and how many.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Glad was the old man when he saw the captive put a good face on
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: matters, and that he was not down-hearted. In sooth that hatred of the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: tyrant mingled with hope sustained Ralph's heart.  He had been minded
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: when he was brought before the lord to have shown the letter of the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Queen of Goldburg, and to defy him if he still held him captive.  But
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: when he had beheld him and his fellowship a while he thought better of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: it.  For though they had abundance of rich plenishing, and gay raiment,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and good weapons and armour, howbeit of strange and uncouth fashion,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: yet he deemed when he looked on them that they would scarce have the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: souls of men in their bodies, but that they were utterly vile through
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and through, like the shapes of an evil dream.  Therefore he thought
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: shame of it to show the Queen's letter to them, even as if he had shown
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Also he had no mind to wear his heart on his sleeve, but would keep his
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: own counsel, and let his foemen speak and show what was in their minds.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: this man had not been bought for money, he was little better than a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

text: rode betwixt two of the men-at-arms, he and Otter; for David was ridden
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: forward to speak with the Lord.  Otter talked ever gaily enough; but
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Ralph heeded him little a while, but had his eyes ever on the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: mountains, and could see that for all they were so dark, and filled up
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: so much of the eastward heaven, they were so far away that he could see
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: but little of them save that they were dark blue and huge, and one
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: rising up behind the other.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Thus they rode the down country, till at last, two hours before noon,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: coming over the brow of a long down, they had before them a shallow
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: dale, pleasanter than aught they had yet seen.  It was well-grassed,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and a little river ran through it, from which went narrow leats held up
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: by hatches, so that the more part of the valley bottom was a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: water-meadow, wherein as now were grazing many kine and sheep.  There
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: were willows about the banks of the river, and in an ingle of it stood
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: a grange or homestead, with many roofs half hidden by clumps of tall
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: old elm trees.  Other houses there were in the vale; two or three cots,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: to wit, on the slope of the hither down, and some half-dozen about the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: homestead; and above and beyond all these, on a mound somewhat away
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: from the river and the grange, a great square tower, with barriers and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: bailey all dight ready for war, and with a banner of the Lord's hanging
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: out.  But between the tower and the river stood as now a great pavilion
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: of snow-white cloth striped with gold and purple; and round about it
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: were other tents, as though a little army were come into the vale.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: So when they looked into that fair place, Otter the Captain rose in the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: stirrups and cast up his hand for joy, and cried out aloud:  "Now,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: young knight, now we are come home: how likest thou my Lord's land?"
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "It is a fair land," said Ralph; "but is there not come some one to bid
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: thy Lord battle for it? or what mean the tents down yonder?"
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Said Otter, laughing:  "Nay, nay, it hath not come to that yet.  Yonder
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: is my Lord's lady-wife, who hath come to meet him, but in love, so to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: say, not in battle--not yet.  Though I say not that the cup of love
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: betwixt them be brim-full. But this it behoveth me not to speak of,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: though thou art to be my brother-in-arms, since we are to tilt together
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: presently: for lo! yonder the tilt-yard, my lad."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Therewith he pointed to the broad green meadow:  but Ralph said: "How
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: canst thou, a free man, be brother-in-arms to a thrall?" "Nay, lad,"
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: quoth Otter, "let not that wasp sting thee: for even such was I, time
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: was.  Nay, such am I now, but that a certain habit of keeping my wits
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: in a fray maketh me of avail to my Lord, so that I am well looked to.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Forsooth in my Lord's land the free men are of little account, since
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: they must oftenest do as my Lord and my Lord's thralls bid them.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Truly, brother, it is we who have the wits and the luck to rise above
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the whipping-post and the shackles that are the great men hereabouts.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: I say we, for I deem that thou wilt do no less, whereas thou hast the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: lucky look in thine eyes.  So let to-day try it."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: As he spake came many glittering figures from out of those tents, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: therewithal arose the sound of horns and clashing of cymbals, and their
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: own horns gave back the sound of welcome.  Then Ralph saw a man in
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: golden armour of strange, outlandish fashion, sitting on a great black
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: horse beside the Lord's litter; and Otter said:  "Lo! my Lord, armed
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and a-horseback to meet my lady: she looketh kinder on him thus; though
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: in thine ear be it said, he is no great man of war; nor need he be,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: since he hath us for his shield and his hauberk."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Herewith were they come on to the causeway above the green meadows, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: presently drew rein before the pavilion, and stood about in a half-ring
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: facing a two score of gaily clad men-at-arms, who had come with the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Lady and a rout of folk of the household.  Then the Lord gat off his
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: horse, and stood in his golden armour, and all the horns and other
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: music struck up, and forth from the pavilion came the Lady with a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: half-score of her women clad gaily in silken gowns of green, and blue,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and yellow, broidered all about with gold and silver, but with naked
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: feet, and having iron rings on their arms, so that Ralph saw that they
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: were thralls.  Something told him that his damsel should be amongst
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: these, so he gazed hard on them, but though they were goodly enough
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: there was none of them like to her.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: As to the Queen, she was clad all in fine linen and gold, with gold
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: shoes on her feet:  her arms came bare from out of the linen: great
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: they were, and the hands not small; but the arms round and fair, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the hands shapely, and all very white and rosy: her hair was as yellow
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: as any that can be seen, and it was plenteous, and shed all down about
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: her.  Her eyes were blue and set wide apart, her nose a little snubbed,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: her mouth wide, full-lipped and smiling.  She was very tall, a full
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: half-head taller than any of her women: yea, as tall as a man who is
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: above the middle height of men.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Now she came forward hastily with long strides, and knelt adown before
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the Lord, but even as she kneeled looked round with a laughing face.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: The Lord stooped down to her and took her by both hands, and raised her
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: up, and kissed her on the cheek (and he looked but little and of no
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: presence beside her:) and he said:  "Hail to thee, my Lady; thou art
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: come far from thine home to meet me, and I thank thee therefor.  Is it
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: well with our House?"
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: She spake seeming carelessly and loud; but her voice was somewhat
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: husky: "Yea, my Lord, all is well; few have done amiss, and the harvest
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: is plenteous."  As she spake the Lord looked with knit brows at the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: damsels behind her, as if he were seeking something; and the Lady
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: followed his eyes, smiling a little and flushing as if with merriment.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: But the Lord was silent a while, and then let his brow clear and said:
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Yea, Lady, thou art thanked for coming to meet us; and timely is thy
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: coming, since there is game and glee for thee at hand; I have cheapened
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: a likely thrall of Morfinn the Unmanned, and he is a gift to thee; and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: he hath given out that he is no ill player with the spear after the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: fashion of them of the west; and we are going to prove his word here in
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: this meadow presently."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: The Lady's face grew glad, and she said, looking toward the ring of new
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: comers:  "Yea, Lord, and which of these is he, if he be here?"
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: The Lord turned a little to point out Ralph, but even therewith the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Lady's eyes met Ralph's, who reddened for shame of being so shown to a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: great lady; but as for her she flushed bright red all over her face and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: even to her bosom, and trouble came into her eyes, and she looked
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: adown.  But the Lord said: "Yonder is the youngling, the swordless one
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: in the green coat; a likely lad, if he hath not lied about his prowess;
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and he can sing thee a song withal, and tell a piteous tale of old, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: do all that those who be reared in the lineages of the westlands deem
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: meet and due for men of knightly blood.  Dost thou like the looks of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: him, lady! wilt thou have him?"
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: The Lady still held her head down, and tormented the grass with her
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: foot, and murmured somewhat; for she could not come to herself again as
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: yet.  So the Lord looked sharply on her and said:  "Well, when this
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: tilting is over, thou shalt tell me thy mind of him; for if he turn out
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: a dastard I would not ask thee to take him."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Now the lady lifted up her face, and she was grown somewhat pale; but
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: she forced her speech to come, and said:  "It is well, Lord, but now
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: come thou into my pavilion, for thy meat is ready, and it lacketh but a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: minute or so of noon."  So he took her hand and led her in to the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the lists, which they were doing with such stuff as they had at the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: through.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Now, the Lady had abided in her pavilion when her Lord went abroad;
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: anon after she sent all her women away, save one whom she loved, and to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: whom she was wont to tell the innermost of her mind; though forsooth
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: she mishandled her at whiles; for she was hot of temper, and over-ready
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: with her hands when she was angry; though she was nowise cruel.  But
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the woman aforesaid, who was sly and sleek, and somewhat past her first
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: youth, took both her caresses and her buffets with patience, for the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: sake of the gifts and largesse wherewith they were bought.  So now she
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: stood by the board in the pavilion with her head drooping humbly, yet
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: smiling to herself and heedful of whatso might betide.  But the Lady
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: walked up and down the pavilion hastily, as one much moved.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: At last she spake as she walked and said:  "Agatha, didst thou see him
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: when my Lord pointed him out?"  "Yea," said the woman lifting her face
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: a little.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "And what seemed he to thee?" said the Lady.  "O my Lady," quoth
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Agatha, "what seemed he to thee?"  The lady stood and turned and looked
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: at her; she was slender and dark and sleek; and though her lips moved
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: not, and her eyes did not change, a smile seemed to steal over her face
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: whether she would or not.  The Lady stamped her foot and lifted her
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: hand and cried out.  "What! dost thou deem thyself meet for him?" And
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: she caught her by the folds over her bosom.  But Agatha looked up into
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: her face with a simple smile as of a child: "Dost thou deem him meet
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: for thee, my Lady--he a thrall, and thou so great?"  The Lady took her
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: hand from her, but her face flamed with anger and she stamped on the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: ground again: "What dost thou mean?" she said; "am I not great enough
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: to have what I want when it lieth close to my hand?" Agatha looked on
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: her sweetly, and said in a soft voice: "Stretch out thine hand for it
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: then."  The Lady looked at her grimly, and said:  "I understand thy
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: jeer; thou meanest that he will not be moved by me, he being so fair,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and I being but somewhat fair.  Wilt thou have me beat thee?  Nay, I
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: will send thee to the White Pillar when we come home to Utterbol."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: The woman smiled again, and said:  "My Lady, when thou hast sent me to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the White Pillar, or the Red, or the Black, my stripes will not mend
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the matter for thee, or quench the fear of thine heart that by this
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: time, since he is a grown man, he loveth some other.  Yet belike he
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: will obey thee if thou command, even to the lying in the same bed with
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: thee; for he is a thrall." The Lady hung her head, but Agatha went on
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: in her sweet clear voice: "The Lord will think little of it, and say
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: nothing of it unless thou anger him otherwise; or unless, indeed, he be
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: minded to pick a quarrel with thee, and hath baited a trap with this
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: stripling.  But that is all unlike:  thou knowest why, and how that he
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: loveth the little finger of that new-come thrall of his (whom ye left
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: at home at Utterbol in his despite), better than all thy body, for all
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: thy white skin and lovely limbs.  Nay, now I think of it, I deem that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: with thee, that he may stop thy mouth from crying out at him--well,

text: what wilt thou do? he is a mighty Lord."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: The Lady looked up (for she had hung her head at first), her face all
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: red with shame, yet smiling, though ruefully, and she said: "Well, thou
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: art determined that if thou art punished it shall not be for naught.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: But thou knowest not my mind." "Yea, Lady," said Agatha, smiling in
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

text: Then the Lord cried out:  "Now make we an end of it!  We have no might
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: against this youngling, man to man: or else would Otter have done it.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: This comes of learning a craft diligently."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and anon comes to him the surly sergeant, and brought him a cup of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Lord; and I deem that thou art in favour with him.  So if thou art not
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: too great a man, thou mightest put in a word for poor Redhead, that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: first man that did so ill.  For my Lord would have him set up, and head
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: down and buttocks aloft, as a target for our bowmen.  And it will be
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: his luck if he be sped with the third shot, and last not out to the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: twentieth."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: also, when thou becomest right great; for have I not brought thee a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William
