text: They Come to the Gate of the Mountains
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: That day they herded their horses thereabout, and from time to time the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Sage tried those two if they were perfect in the lore of the road; and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: he found that they had missed nothing.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: They lay down in the self-same place again that night, and arose
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: betimes on the morrow and went their ways over the plain as the Sage
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: led, till it was as if the mountains and their terror hung over their
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: very heads, and the hugeness and blackness of them were worse than a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: wall of fire had been.  It was still a long way to them, so that it was
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: not till noon of the third day from the rock-sea that they came to the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: very feet of that fire-scorched ness, and wonderful indeed it seemed to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: them that anything save the eagles could have aught to tell of what lay
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: beyond it.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: There were no foothills or downs betwixt the plain and the mountains,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: naught save a tumble of rocks that had fallen from the cliffs, piled up
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: strangely, and making a maze through which the Sage led them surely;
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and at last they were clear even of this, and were underneath the flank
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: of that ness, which was so huge that there seemed that there could
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: scarce be any more mountain than that.  Little of its huge height could
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: they see, now they were close to it, for it went up sheer at first and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: then beetled over them till they could see no more of its side; as they
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: wound about its flank, and they were long about it, the Sage cried out
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: to those two and stretched out his hand, and behold! the side of the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: black cliff plain and smooth and shining as if it had been done by the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: hand of men or giants, and on this smooth space was carven in the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: living rock the image of a warrior in mail and helm of ancient fashion,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and holding a sword in his right hand.  From head to heel he seemed
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: some sixty feet high, and the rock was so hard, that he was all clean
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and clear to see; and they deemed of him that his face was keen and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: stern of aspect.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: So there they stood in an awful bight of the mountain, made by that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: ness, and the main wall from which it thrust out.  But after they had
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: gazed awhile and their hearts were in their mouths, the Sage turned on
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: those twain and said: "Here then is the end of my journey with you; and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: ye wot all that I can tell you, and I can say no word more save to bid
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: you cast all fear aside and thrive.  Ye have yet for this day's journey
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: certain hours of such daylight as the mountain pass will give you,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: which at the best is little better than twilight; therefore redeem ye
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the time."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: But Ralph got off his horse, and Ursula did in likewise, and they both
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: kissed and embraced the old man, for their hearts were full and fain.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: But he drew himself away from them, and turned about with no word more,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and went his ways, and presently was hidden from their eyes by the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: rocky maze which lay about the mountain's foot.  Then the twain mounted
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: their horses again and set forth silently on the road, as they had been
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: bidden.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: In a little while the rocks of the pass closed about them, leaving but
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: a way so narrow that they could see a glimmer of the stars above them
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: as they rode the twilight; no sight they had of the measureless stony
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: desert, yet in their hearts they saw it.  They seemed to be wending a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: straight-walled prison without an end, so that they were glad when the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: dark night came on them.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Ralph found some shelter in the cleft of a rock above a mound where was
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: little grass for the horses.  He drew Ursula into it, and they sat down
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: there on the stones together.  So long they sat silent that a great
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: gloom settled upon Ralph, and he scarce knew whether he were asleep or
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: waking, alive or dead.  But amidst of it fell a sweet voice on his
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: ears, and familiar words asking him of what like were the fields of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Upmeads, and the flowers; and of the fish of its water, and of the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: fashion of the building of his father's house; and of his brethren, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the mother that bore him.  Then was it to him at first as if a sweet
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: dream had come across the void of his gloom, and then at last the gloom
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and the dread and the deadness left him, and he knew that his friend
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and fellow was talking to him, and that he sat by her knee to knee, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the sweetness of her savoured in his nostrils as she leaned her face
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: toward him, and he knew himself for what he was; and yet for memory of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: that past horror, and the sweetness of his friend and what not else, he
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: fell a-weeping. But Ursula bestirred herself and brought out food from
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: her wallet, and sat down beside him again, and he wiped the tears from
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: his eyes and laughed, and chid himself for being as a child in the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: dark, and then they ate and drank together in that dusk nook of the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: wilderness.  And now was he happy and his tongue was loosed, and he
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: fell to telling her many things of Upmeads, and of the tale of his
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: forefathers, and of his old loves and his friends, till life and death
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: seemed to him as they had seemed of time past in the merry land of his
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: birth.  So there anon they fell asleep for weariness, and no dreams of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: terror beset their slumbers.

author: Morris, William

text: Many days they rode that pass of the mountains, though it was not
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: always so evil and dreadful as at the first beginning; for now again
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: him, and she noted it and forbore somewhat the sweetness of her
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: glances, and the caressing of her soft speech:  though oft when he
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: looked on her fondly, the blood would rise to her cheeks, and her bosom
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: would heave with the thought of his desire, which quickened hers so
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: sorely, that it became a pain and grief to her.

text: Of Ursula and the Bear

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: It befell on a fair sunny morning of spring, that Ralph sat alone on
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the toft by the rock-house, for Ursula had gone down the meadow to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: disport her and to bathe in the river.  Ralph was fitting the blade of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: a dagger to a long ashen shaft, to make him a strong spear; for with
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the waxing spring the bears were often in the meadows again; and the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: day before they had come across a family of the beasts in the sandy
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: bight under the mountains; to wit a carle, and a quean with her cubs;
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the beasts had seen them but afar off, and whereas the men were two and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the sun shone back from their weapons, they had forborne them; although
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: they were fierce and proud in those wastes, and could not away with
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: creatures that were not of their kind.  So because of this Ralph had
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: bidden Ursula not to fare abroad without her sword, which was sharp and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: strong, and she no weakling withal.  He bethought him of this just as
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: he had made an end of his spear-shaping, so therewith he looked aside
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and saw the said sword hanging to a bough of a little quicken-tree,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: which grew hard by the door.  Fear came into his heart therewith, so he
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: arose and strode down over the meadow hastily bearing his new spear,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and girt with his sword.  Now there was a grove of chestnuts betwixt
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: him and the river, but on the other side of them naught but the green
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: grass down to the water's edge.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Sure enough as he came under the trees he heard a shrill cry, and knew
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: that it could be naught save Ursula; so he ran thitherward whence came
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the cry, shouting as he ran, and was scarce come out of the trees ere
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: he saw Ursula indeed, mother-naked, held in chase by a huge bear as big
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: as a bullock:  he shouted again and ran the faster; but even therewith,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: whether she heard and saw him, and hoped for timely help, or whether
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: she felt her legs failing her, she turned on the bear, and Ralph saw
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: that she had a little axe in her hand wherewith she smote hardily at
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the beast; but he, after the fashion of his kind, having risen to his
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: hind legs, fenced with his great paws like a boxer, and smote the axe
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: out of her hand, and she cried out bitterly and swerved from him and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: fell a running again; but the bear tarried not, and would have caught
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: her in a few turns; but even therewith was Ralph come up, who thrust
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the beast into the side with his long-headed spear, and not waiting to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: pull it out again, drew sword in a twinkling, and smote a fore-paw off
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: him and then drave the sword in over the shoulder so happily that it
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: reached his heart, and he fell over dead with a mighty thump.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Then Ralph looked around for Ursula; but she had already run back to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the river-side and was casting her raiment on her; so he awaited her
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: beside the slain bear, but with drawn sword, lest the other bear should
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: come upon them; for this was the he-bear. Howbeit he saw naught save
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: presently Ursula all clad and coming towards him speedily; so he turned
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: toward her, and when they met he cast himself upon her without a word,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and kissed her greedily; and she forbore not at all, but kissed and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: caressed him as if she could never be satisfied.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: So at last they drew apart a little, and walked quietly toward the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: rock-house hand in hand.  And on the way she told him that even as she
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: came up on to the bank from the water she saw the bear coming down on
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: her as fast as he could drive, and so she but caught up her axe, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: ran for it:  "Yet I had little hope, dear friend," she said, "but that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: thou shouldst be left alone in the wilderness." And therewith she
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: turned on him and cast her arms about him again, all weeping for joy of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: their two lives.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Thus slowly they came before the door of their rock-house and Ralph
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: said: "Let us sit down here on the grass, and if thou art not over
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: wearied with the flight and the battle, I will ask thee a question."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: She laid herself down on the grass with a sigh, yet it was as of one
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: who sighs for pleasure and rest, and said, as he sat down beside her:
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "I am fain to rest my limbs and my body, but my heart is at rest; so
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: ask on, dear friend."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: The song of birds was all around them, and the scent of many blossoms
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: went past on the wings of the west wind, and Ralph was silent a little
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: as he looked at the loveliness of his friend; then he said:  "This is
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the question; of what kind are thy kisses this morning, are they the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: kisses of a friend or a lover?  Wilt thou not called me beloved and not
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: friend?  Shall not we two lie on the bridal bed this same night?"
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: She looked on him steadily, smiling, but for love and sweetness, not
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: for shame and folly; then she said:  "O, dear friend and dearest lover,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: three questions are these and not one; but I will answer all three as
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: my heart biddeth me.  And first, I will tell thee that my kisses are as
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: thine; and if thine are aught but the kisses of love, then am I
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: befooled.  And next, I say that if thou wilt be my friend indeed, I
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: will not spare to call thee beloved, or to be all thy friend.  But as
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: to thy third question; tell me, is there not time enough for that?"
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: She faltered as she spake, but he said:  "Look, beloved, and see how
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: fair the earth is to-day! What place and what season can be goodlier
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: than this?  And were it not well that we who love each other should
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: have our full joy out of this sweet season, which as now is somewhat
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: marred by our desire?"
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Ah, beloved!" she said, looking shyly at him, "is it so marred by that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: which marreth not us?"
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Hearken!" he said; "how much longer shall this fairness and peace, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: our leisure and safety endure?  Here and now the earth rejoiceth about
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: us, and there is none to say us nay; but to-morrow it may all be
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: otherwise.  Bethink thee, dear, if but an hour ago the monster had
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: slain thee, and rent thee ere we had lain in each other's arms!"
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Alas!" she said, "and had I lain in thine arms an hundred times, or an
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: hundred times an hundred, should not the world be barren to me, wert
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: thou gone from it, and that could never more be?  But thou friend, thou
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: well-beloved, fain were I to do thy will that thou mightest be the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: happier...and I withal.  And if thou command it, be it so!  Yet now
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: should I tell thee all my thought, and it is on my mind, that for a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: many hundreds of years, yea, while our people were yet heathen, when a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: man should wed a maid all the folk knew of it, and were witnesses of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the day and the hour thereof:  now thou knowest that the time draws
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: nigh when we may look for those messengers of the Innocent Folk, who
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: come every spring to this cave to see if there be any whom they may
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: speed on the way to the Well at the World's End.  Therefore if thou
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: wilt (and not otherwise) I would abide their coming if it be not over
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: long delayed; so that there may be others to witness our wedding
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: besides God, and those his creatures who dwell in the wilderness.  Yet
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: shall all be as thou wilt."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "How shall I not do after thy bidding?" said Ralph.  "I will abide
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: their coming:  yet would that they were here to-day! And one thing I
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: will pray of thee, that because of them thou wilt not forbear, or cause
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: me to forbear, such kissing and caressing as is meet betwixt
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: troth-plight lovers."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: She laughed and said:  "Nay, why should I torment thee...or me?  We
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: will not tarry for this."  And therewith she took her arm about his
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: neck and kissed him oft.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Then they said naught awhile, but sat listening happily to the song of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the pairing birds.  At last Ralph said: "What was it, beloved, that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: thou wert perchance to tell me concerning the thing that caused thine
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: weep at the ale-house at Bourton Abbas, was of no avail to thee?"
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: never be thine.  For that I have sorrowed many a time since."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Said Ralph:  "I am young and unmighty, yet lo!  I heal thy sorrow as if
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: I were an exceeding mighty man.  And now I tell thee that I am minded
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: to go back with thee to Upmeads straightway; for love will prevail."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Nay," she said, "that word is but from the teeth outwards; for thou
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: knowest, as I do, that the perils of the homeward road shall overcome
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: us, despite of love, if we have not drunk of the Well at the World's
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: End."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Again they were silent awhile, but anon she arose to her feet and said:
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Now must I needs dight victual for us twain; but first" (and she
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: smiled on him withal), "how is it that thou hast not asked me if the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: is so nigh?"
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: reddened, and said:  "Ah, I forgot how keen-eyes thou art." And she
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: sweetness.  Then he said:  "I am exceeding full of joy, but my body is
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: uneasy; so I will now go and skin that troll who went so nigh to slay
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: to don thine helm and hauberk to boot."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Ralph, my friend; yet shall I do thy will, my lord and my love."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: on her, and kissed her, and so went his ways to the carcase of the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: But when he had come forth from the chestnut-grove, and could see the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: face of their house-rock clearly, he beheld new tidings; for there were
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: folk before the door of the dwelling, and Ursula was standing amidst of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: them, for he could see the gleam of her armour; and with the men he
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: could see also certain beasts of burden, and anon that these were oxen.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: So he hastened on to find what this might mean, and drew his sword as
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: he went.  But when he came up to the rock, he found there two young men
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and an elder, and they had with them five oxen, three for riding, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: two sumpter beasts, laden:  and Ursula and these men were talking
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: together friendly; so that Ralph deemed that the new-comers must be the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: messengers of the Innocent Folk.  They were goodly men all three,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: somewhat brown of skin, but well fashioned, and of smiling cheerful
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: countenance, well knit, and tall.  The elder had a long white beard,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: but his eye was bright, and his hand firm and smooth.  They were all
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: clad in white woollen raiment, and bore no armour, but each had an axe
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: with a green stone blade, curiously tied to the heft, and each of the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: young men carried a strong bow and a quiver of arrows.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Ralph greeted the men, and bade them sit down on the toft and eat a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: morsel; they took his greeting kindly, and sat down, while Ursula went
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: into the cave to fetch them matters for their victual, and there was
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: already venison roasting at the fire on the toft, in the place where
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: they were wont to cook their meat.  So then came Ursula forth from the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: cave, and served the new-comers and Ralph of such things as she had,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and they ate and drank together; and none said aught of their errand
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: till they had done their meat, but they talked together pleasantly
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: about the spring, and the blossoms of the plain and the mountain, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the wild things that dwelt thereabout.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: But when the meal was over, the new-comers rose to their feet, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: bowed before Ralph and Ursula, and the elder took up the word and said:
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Ye fair people, have ye any errand in the wilderness, or are ye
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: chance-comers who have strayed thus far, and know not how to return?"
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Father," said Ralph, "we have come a long way on an errand of life or
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: death; for we seek the WELL at the WORLD'S END.  And see ye the token
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: thereof, the pair of beads which we bear, either of us, and the fashion
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: whereof ye know."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Then the elder bowed to them again, and said:  "It is well; then is
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: this our errand with you, to be your way-leaders as far as the House of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the Sorceress, where ye shall have other help.  Will ye set out on the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: journey to-day? In one hour shall we be ready."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Nay," said Ralph, "we will not depart till tomorrow morn, if it may be
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: so.  Therewith I bid you sit down and rest you, while ye hearken a word
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: which I have to say to you."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: So they sat down again, and Ralph arose and took Ursula by the hand,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and stood with her before the elder, and said: "This maiden, who is my
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: fellow-farer in the Quest, I desire to wed this same night, and she
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: also desireth me: therefore I would have you as witnesses hereto.  But
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: first ye shall tell us if our wedding and the knowing each other
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: carnally shall be to our hurt in the Quest; for if that be so, then
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: shall we bridle our desires and perform our Quest in their despite."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: The old man smiled upon them kindly, and said:  "Nay, son, we hear not
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: that it shall be the worse for you in any wise that ye shall become one
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: flesh; and right joyful it is to us, not only that we have found folk
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: who seek to the Well at the World's End, but also that there is such
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: love as I perceive there is betwixt such goodly and holy folk as ye be.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: For hither we come year by year according to the behest that we made to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the fairest woman of the world, when she came back to us from the Well
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: at the World's End, and it is many and many a year ago since we found
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: any seekers after the Well dwelling here.  Therefore have we the more
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: joy in you.  And we have brought hither matters good for you, as
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: raiment, and meal, and wine, on our sumpter-beasts; therefore as ye
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: have feasted us this morning, so shall we feast you this even.  And if
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: ye will, we shall build for you in the grove yonder such a bower as we
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: build for our own folk on the night of the wedding."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Ralph yeasaid this, and thanked them.  So then the elder cried: "Up, my
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: sons, and show your deftness to these dear friends!" Then the young men
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: arose, naught loth, and when they had hoppled their oxen and taken the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: burdens from off them, they all went down the meadow together into the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: wood, and drave stakes and wove the twigs together; and Ralph and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: together: because for those two wanderers it was a great delight to see
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the faces of the children of men once more after so many months, and to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: hold converse with them; while for their part the young men marvelled
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: at Ursula's beauty, and the pith and goodliness of Ralph.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: By then it was nigh evening they had made a very goodly wattled bower,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: elder had opened the loads, and had taken meal thence, and was making
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: cakes at the fire.  And there was wine there in well-hooped kegs, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: So then were those twain arrayed for the bridal; and the meat was dight
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and the cups filled, and they sat down on the grassy toft a little
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and they stood before the elder, and bade him and the young men bear
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: When it was morning they speedily gat them ready for the road, whereas
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: they had little to take with them; so they departed joyously, howbeit
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: both Ralph and Ursula felt rather love than loathing for their winter
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: abode.  The day was yet young when they went their ways.  Their horses
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and all their gear were a great wonder to the young men, for they had
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: seen no such beasts before:  but the elder said that once in his young
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: days he had led a man to the Well who was riding a horse and was clad
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: in knightly array.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: So they went by ways which were nowise dreadful, though they were void
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: of men-folk, and in three days' time they were come out of the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: mountains, and in three more the said mountains were to behold but a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: cloud behind them, and the land was grown goodly, with fair valleys and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: little hills, though still they saw no men, and forsooth they went
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: leisurely, for oxen are but slow-going nags.  But when they were gone
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: eight days from the Valley of Sweet-chestnuts, they came across a flock
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: of uncouth-looking sheep on a green hill-side, and four folk
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: shepherding them, two carles to wit, and two queans, like to their
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: way-leaders, but scarce so goodly, and ruder of raiment.  These men
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: greeted them kindly, and yet with more worship than fellowship, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: they marvelled exceedingly at their horses and weapons.  Thence they
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: passed on, and the next day came into a wide valley, well-grassed and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: watered, and wooded here and there; moreover there were cots scattered
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: about it.  There and thenceforth they met men a many, both carles and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: queans, and sheep and neat in plenty, and they passed by garths wherein
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the young corn was waxing, and vineyards on the hillsides, where the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: vines were beginning to grow green.  The land seemed as goodly as might
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: be, and all the folk they met were kind, if somewhat over reverent.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: On the evening of that day they came into the town of that folk, which
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: was but simple, wholly unfenced for war, and the houses but low, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: not great.  Yet was there naught of filth or famine, nor any poverty or
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: misery; and the people were merry-faced and well-liking, and clad
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: goodly after their fashion in white woollen cloth or frieze.  All the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: people of the town were come forth to meet them, for runners had gone
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: before them, and they stood on either side of the way murmuring
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: greetings, and with their heads bent low in reverence.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Thus rode Ralph and Ursula up to the door of the Temple, or Mote-house,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: or Guest-house, for it was all these, a house great, and as fair as
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: they knew how to make it.  Before the door thereof were standing the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: elders of the Folk; and when they drew rein, the eldest and most
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: reverend of these came forth and spake in a cheerful voice, yet
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: solemnly: "Welcome and thrice welcome to the Seekers after length of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: days and happy times, and the loving-kindness of the Folks of the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Earth!"
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Then all the elders gathered about them, and bade them light down and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: be at rest amongst them, and they made much of them and brought them
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: into the Mote-house, where-in were both women and men fair and stately,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and the men took Ralph by the hand and the women Ursula, and brought
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: them into chambers where they bathed them and did off their wayfaring
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: raiment, and clad them in white woollen gowns of web exceeding fine,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and fragrant withal.  Then they crowned them with flowers, and led them
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: back into the hall, whereas now was much folk gathered, and they set
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: of them, and bade them hail oft and oft.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

text: therein.

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

text: which albeit not richly decked, or plenished with precious things, was

author: Morris, William

text: most dainty clean, and sweet smelling, and strewn with flowers, so that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: waste, wherein was naught for their avail, neither man, nor beast, nor
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

text: and mounds against the day of return.

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the waste, and comforted each other, and slept two or three hours, but
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: This day, forsooth, they found so many dead folk, that they might not
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: stay to bury them, lest they themselves should come to lie there
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: lacking burial.  So they made all the way they might, and rode on some
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

text: On the morrow morn Ralph awoke and saw Ursula sleeping peacefully as he
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: deemed, and he looked about on the dreary desert and its dead men and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: bents; and he said softly to himself:  "Will it end at all then?
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: we be; and have they belike turned back from somewhere further on, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: might not escape the desert despite of all?  Shall we turn now: shall
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: we turn? surely we might get into the kindly wood from here."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: So he spake; but Ursula sat up (for she was not asleep) and said: "The
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: perils of the waste being abundant and exceeding hard to face, would
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: not the Sage or his books have told us of the most deadly?" Said Ralph:
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: nevertheless we have seen the token on the rocks oft-times yesterday,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: so we are yet in the road, unless all this hath been but a snare and a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: betrayal."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: She shook her head, and was silent a little; then she said: "Ralph, my
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: sooth to say I looked for it." "And I in likewise," she said; "for
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: indeed I had misgivings as the day grew old; but now I say, let us on
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: in the faith of that token and the kindness of the Sage, and the love
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: was there.  Moreover I can note that this army of dead men has not come
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

text: "Nowhere," she said, "it was naught but my word to draw thee from
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: death; but praise to the saints that thou are come alive out of the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: accursed valley."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: He seemed not to hearken, but turned about once, and beat the air with
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: his hands, and then fell down on his back and with a great wail she
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: cast herself upon him, for she deemed at first that he was dead.  But
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: she took a little water from one of their skins, and cast it into his
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: face, and took a flask of cordial from her pouch, and set it to his
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: lips, and made him drink somewhat thereof.  So in a while he came to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: himself and opened his eyes and smiled upon her, and she took his head
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: in her hands and kissed his cheek, and he sat up and said feebly:
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Shall we not go down into the valley?  there is naught there to harm
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: us."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "We have been down there already," she said, "and well it is that we
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: are not both lying there now."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Then he got to his feet, and stretched himself, and yawned like one
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: just awakened from long sleep.  But she said: "Let us to horse and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: begone; it is early hours to slumber, for those that are seeking the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Well at the World's End."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: He smiled on her again and took her hand, and she led him to his horse,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and helped him till he was in the saddle and lightly she gat
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: a-horseback, and they rode away swiftly from that evil place; and after
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: a while Ralph was himself again, and remembered all that had happened
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: till he fell down on the brow of the ridge.  Then he praised Ursula's
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: wisdom and valiancy till she bade him forbear lest he weary her.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Albeit she drew up close to him and kissed his face sweetly.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: They Come Out of the Thirsty Desert
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Past the Valley of the Dry Tree they saw but few dead men lying about,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and soon they saw never another: and, though the land was still utterly
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: barren, and all cast up into ridges as before, yet the salt slime grew
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: less and less, and before nightfall of that day they had done with it:
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and the next day those stony waves were lower; and the next again the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: waste was but a swelling plain, and here and there they came on patches
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: of dwarf willow, and other harsh and scanty herbage, whereof the horses
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: might have a bait, which they sore needed, for now was their fodder
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: done: but both men and horses were sore athirst; for, as carefully as
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: they had hoarded their water, there was now but little left, which they
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: durst not drink till they were driven perforce, lest they should yet
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: die of drought.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: They journeyed long that day, and whereas the moon was up at night-tide
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: they lay not down till she was set; and their resting place was by some
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: low bushes, whereabout was rough grass mingled with willow-herb,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: whereby Ralph judged that they drew nigh to water, so or ever they
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: slept, they and the horses all but emptied the water-skins. They heard
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: some sort of beasts roaring in the night, but they were too weary to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: watch, and might not make a fire.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: When Ralph awoke in the morning he cried out that he could see the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: woodland; and Ursula arose at his cry and looked where he pointed, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: sure enough there were trees on a rising ground some two miles ahead,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and beyond them, not very far by seeming, they beheld the tops of great
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: dark mountains.  On either hand moreover, nigh on their right hand, far
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: off on their left, ran a reef of rocks, so that their way seemed to be
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: as between two walls.  And these said reefs were nowise like those that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: they had seen of late, but black and, as to their matter, like to the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: great mountains by the rock of the Fighting Man:  but as the reefs ran
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: eastward they seemed to grow higher.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Now they mounted their horses at once and rode on; and the beasts were
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: as eager as they were, and belike smelt the water.  So when they had
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: ridden but three miles, they saw a fair little river before them
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: winding about exceedingly, but flowing eastward on the whole.  So they
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: spurred on with light hearts and presently were on the banks of the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: said river, and its waters were crystal-clear, though its sands were
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: black: and the pink-blossomed willow-herb was growing abundantly on the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: sandy shores.  Close to the water was a black rock, as big as a man,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: whereon was graven the sign of the way, so they knew that there was no
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: evil in the water, wherefore they drank their fill and watered their
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: horses abundantly, and on the further bank was there abundance of good
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: grass.  So when they had drunk their fill, for the pleasure of the cool
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: water they waded the ford barefoot, and it was scarce above Ursula's
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: knee.  Then they had great joy to lie on the soft grass and eat their
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: meat, while the horses tore eagerly at the herbage close to them.  So
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: when they had eaten, they rested awhile, but before they went further
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: they despoiled them, one after other, and bathed in a pool of the river
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: to wash the foul wilderness off them.  Then again they rested and let
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the horses yet bite the grass, and departed not from that pleasant
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: place till it was two hours after noon.  As they were lying there Ralph
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: said he could hear a great roar like the sound of many waters, but very
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: far off: but to Ursula it seemed naught but the wind waxing in the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: boughs of the woodland anigh them.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
