text: They Come to the Ocean Sea
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Being come to the wood they went not very far into it that day, for
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: they were minded to rest them after the weariness of the wilderness:
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: they feasted on a hare which Ralph shot, and made a big fire to keep
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: off evil beasts, but none came nigh them, though they heard the voices
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: of certain beasts as the night grew still.  To be short, they slept far
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: into the morrow's morn, and then, being refreshed, and their horses
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: also, they rode strongly all day, and found the wood to be not very
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: great; for before sunset they were come to its outskirts, and the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: mountains lay before them.  These were but little like to that huge
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: wall they had passed through on their way to Chestnut-dale, being
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: rather great hills than mountains, grass-grown, and at their feet
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: somewhat wooded, and by seeming not over hard to pass over.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: The next day they entered them by a pass marked with the token, which
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: led them about by a winding way till they were on the side of the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: biggest fell of all; so there they rested that night in a fair little
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: hollow or dell in the mountain-side. There in the stillness of the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: night both Ursula, as well as Ralph, heard that roaring of a great
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: water, and they said to each other that it must be the voice of the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Sea, and they rejoiced thereat, for they had learned by the Sage and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: his books that they must needs come to the verge of the Ocean-Sea,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: which girdles the earth about.  So they arose betimes on the morrow,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and set to work to climb the mountain, going mostly a-foot; and the way
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: was long, but not craggy or exceeding steep, so that in five hours'
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: time they were at the mountain-top, and coming over the brow beheld
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: beneath them fair green slopes besprinkled with trees, and beyond them,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: some three or four miles away, the blue landless sea and on either hand
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: of them was the sea also, so that they were nigh-hand at the ending of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: a great ness, and there was naught beyond it; and naught to do if they
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: missed the Well, but to turn back by the way they had come.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Now when they saw this they were exceedingly moved and they looked on
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: one another, and each saw that the other was pale, with glistening
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: eyes, since they were to come to the very point of their doom, and that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: it should be seen whether there were no such thing as the Well in all
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the earth, but that they had been chasing a fair-hued cloud; or else
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: their Quest should be achieved and they should have the world before
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: them, and they happy and mighty, and of great worship amidst all men.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Little they tarried, but gat them down the steep of the mountain, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: so lower and lower till they were come to ground nigh level; and then
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: at last it was but thus, that without any great rock-wall or girdle of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: marvellous and strange land, there was an end of earth, with its grass
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and trees and streams, and a beginning of the ocean, which stretched
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: away changeless, and it might be for ever.  Where the land ended there
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: was but a cliff of less than an hundred feet above the eddying of the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: sea; and on the very point of the ness was a low green toft with a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: square stone set atop of it, whereon as they drew nigh they saw the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: token graven, yea on each face thereof.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Then they went along the edge of the cliff a mile on each side of the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: said toft, and then finding naught else to note, naught save the grass
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and the sea, they came back to that place of the token, and sat down on
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the grass of the toft.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: It was now evening, and the sun was setting beyond them, but they could
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: behold a kind of stair cut in the side of the cliff, and on the first
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: step whereof was the token done; wherefore they knew that they were
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: bidden to go down by the said stair; but it seemed to lead no whither,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: save straight into the sea.  And whiles it came into Ralph's mind that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: this was naught but a mock, as if to bid the hapless seekers cast
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: themselves down from the earth, and be done with it for ever.  But in
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: any case they might not try the adventure of that stair by the failing
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: light, and with the night long before them.  So when they had hoppled
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: their horses, and left them to graze at their will on the sweet grass
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: of the meadow, they laid them down behind the green toft, and, being
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: forwearied, it was no long time ere they twain slept fast at the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: uttermost end of the world.

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Ralph awoke from some foolish morning dream of Upmeads, wondering where
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: he was, or what familiar voice had cried out his name:  then he raised
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: himself on his elbow, and saw Ursula standing before him with flushed
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: face and sparkling eyes, and she was looking out seaward, while she
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: called on his name.  So he sprang up and strove with the slumber that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: still hung about him, and as his eyes cleared he looked down, and saw
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: that the sea, which last night had washed the face of the cliff, had
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: now ebbed far out, and left bare betwixt the billows and the cliff some
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: half mile of black sand, with rocks of the like hue rising out of it
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: here and there.  But just below the place where they stood, right up
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: against the cliff, was builded by man's hand of huge stones a garth of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: was filled with the waters of a spring that came forth from the face of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the cliff as they deemed, though from above they might not see the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: issue thereof; but the water ran seaward from the pound by some way
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: unseen, and made a wide stream through the black sand of the foreshore:
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: but ever the great basin filled somewhat faster than it voided, so that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: save light airs playing about from the westward ort, and all things
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: gleamed and glittered in the sun.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

text: hands beat upon his body.

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

text: On the morrow morning they armed them and took to their horses and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: departed from that pleasant place and climbed the mountain without
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: weariness, and made provision of meat and drink for the Dry Desert, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: so entered it, and journeyed happily with naught evil befalling them
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: till they came back to the House of the Sorceress; and of the Desert
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: they made little, and the wood was pleasant to them after the drought
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: of the Desert.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: But at the said House they saw those kind people, and they saw in their
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: eager eyes as in a glass how they had been bettered by their drinking
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: of the Well, and the Elder said to them: "Dear friends, there is no
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: need to ask you whether ye have achieved your quest; for ye, who before
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: were lovely, are now become as the very Gods who rule the world.  And
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: now methinks we have to pray you but one thing, to wit that ye will not
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: be overmuch of Gods, but will be kind and lowly with them that needs
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: must worship you."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: They laughed on him for kindness' sake, and kissed and embraced the old
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: man, and they thanked them all for their helping, and they abode with
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: them for a whole day in good-will and love, and thereafter the carle,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: who was the son of the Elder, with his wife, bade farewell to his
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: kinsmen, and led Ralph and Ursula back through the wood and over the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: desert to the town of the Innocent Folk.  The said Folk received them
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: in all joy and triumph, and would have them abide there the winter
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: over.  But they prayed leave to depart, because their hearts were sore
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: for their own land and their kindred.  So they abode there but two
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: days, and on the third day were led away by a half score of men gaily
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: apparelled after their manner, and having with them many sumpter-beasts
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: with provision for the road.  With this fellowship they came safely and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: with little pain unto Chestnut Vale, where they abode but one night,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: though to Ralph and Ursula the place was sweet for the memory of their
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: loving sojourn there.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: They would have taken leave of the Innocent Folk in the said vale, but
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: those others must needs go with them a little further, and would not
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: leave them till they were come to the jaws of the pass which led to the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Rock of the Fighting Man.  Further than that indeed they would not, or
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: durst not go; and those huge mountains they called the Wall of Strife,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: even as they on the other side called them the Wall of the World.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: So the twain took leave of their friends there, and howbeit that they
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: had drunk of the Well at the World's End, yet were their hearts grieved
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: at the parting.  The kind folk left with them abundant provision for
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the remnant of the road, and a sumpter-ox to bear it; so they were in
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: no doubt of their livelihood.  Moreover, though the turn of autumn was
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: come again and winter was at hand, yet the weather was fair and calm,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and their journey through the dreary pass was as light as it might be
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: to any men.

author: Morris, William

text: They Hear New Tidings of Utterbol

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: It was on a fair evening of later autumn-tide that they won their way
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: out of the Gates of the Mountains, and came under the rock of the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Fighting Man.  There they kissed and comforted each other in memory of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the terror and loneliness wherewith they had entered the Mountains that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: other time; though, sooth to say, it was to them now like the reading
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: of sorrow in a book.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: But when they came out with joyful hearts into the green plain betwixt
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the mountains and the River of Lava, they looked westward, and beheld
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: no great way off a little bower or cot, builded of boughs and rushes by
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: a blackthorn copse; and as they rode toward it they saw a man come
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: forth therefrom, and presently saw that he was hoary, a man with a long
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: white beard.  Then Ralph gave a glad cry, and set spurs to his horse
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and galloped over the plain; for he deemed that it could be none other
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: than the Sage of Swevenham; and Ursula came pricking after him laughing
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: for joy.  The old man abode their coming, and Ralph leapt off his horse
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: at once, and kissed and embraced him; but the Sage said: "There is no
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: need to ask thee of tidings; for thine eyes and thine whole body tell
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: me that thou hast drunk of the Well at the World's End.  And that shall
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: be better for thee belike than it has been for me; though for me also
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the world has not gone ill after my fashion since I drank of that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: water."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Then was Ursula come up, and she also lighted down and made much of the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Sage.  But he said:  "Hail, daughter!  It is sweet to see thee so, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: to wot that thou art in the hands of a mighty man: for I know that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Ralph thy man is minded for his Father's House, and the deeds that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: abide him there; and I think we may journey a little way together; for
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: as for me, I would go back to Swevenham to end my days there, whether
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: they be long or short."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: But Ralph said:  "As for that, thou mayst go further than Swevenham,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and as far as Upmeads, where there will be as many to love and cherish
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: thee as at Swevenham."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: The old man laughed a little, and reddened withal, but answered nothing.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Then they untrussed their sumpter-beast, and took meat and drink from
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: his burden, and they ate and drank together, sitting on the green grass
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: there; and the twain made great joy of the Sage, and told him the whole
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: tale; and he told them that he had been abiding there since the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: spring-tide, lest they might have turned back without accomplishing
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: their quest, and then may-happen he should have been at hand to comfort
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: them, or the one of them left, if so it had befallen.  "But," quoth he,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "since ye have verily drunk of the Well at the World's End, ye have
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: come back no later than I looked for you."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: That night they slept in the bower there, and on the morrow betimes,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the Sage drove together three or four milch goats that he pastured
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: there, and went their ways over the plain, and so in due time entered
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: into the lava-sea. But the first night that they lay there, though it
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: was moonless and somewhat cloudy, they saw no glare of the distant
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: earth-fires which they had looked for; and when on the morrow they
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: questioned the Sage thereof, he said: "The Earth-fires ceased about the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: end of last year, as I have heard tell.  But sooth it is that the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: foreboding of the Giant's Candle was not for naught.  For there hath
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: verily been a change of masters at Utterbol."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Yea," said Ralph, "for better or worse?"
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Said the Sage:  "It could scarce have been for worse; but if rumour
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: runneth right it is much for the better.  Hearken how I learned
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: thereof.  One fair even of late March, a little before I set off
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: hither, as I was sitting before the door of my house, I saw the glint
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: of steel through the wood, and presently rode up a sort of knights and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: men-at-arms, about a score; and at the head of them a man on a big
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: red-roan horse, with his surcoat blazoned with a white bull on a green
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: field: he was a man black-haired, but blue-eyed; not very big, but well
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: knit and strong, and looked both doughty and knightly; and he wore a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: gold coronet about his basnet: so not knowing his blazonry, I wondered
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: who it was that durst be so bold as to ride in the lands of the Lord of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Utterbol.  Now he rode up to me and craved a drink of milk, for he had
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: seen my goats; so I milked two goats for him, and brought whey for the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: others, whereas I had no more goats in milk at that season.  So the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: bull-knight spake to me about the woodland, and wherefore I dwelt there
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: apart from others; somewhat rough in his speech he was, yet rather
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: jolly than fierce; and he thanked me for the bever kindly enough, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: said: "I deem that it will not avail to give thee money; but I shall
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: give thee what may be of avail to thee.  Ho, Gervaise! give me one of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: those scrolls!"  So a squire hands him a parchment and he gave it me,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and it was a safe-conduct to the bearer from the Lord of Utterbol; but
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: whereas I saw that the seal bore not the Bear on the Castle-wall, but
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the Bull, and that the superscription was unknown to me, I held the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: said scroll in my hand and wondered; and the knight said to me: "Yea,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: look long at it; but so it is, though thou trow it not, that I am
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: verily Lord of Utterbol, and that by conquest; so that belike I am
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: mightier than he was, for that mighty runagate have I slain.  And many
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: there be who deem that no mishap, heathen though I be.  Come thou to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Utterbol and see for thyself if the days be not changed there; and thou
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: shalt have a belly-full of meat and drink, and honour after thy
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: deserving."  So they rested a while, and then went their ways.  To
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Utterbol I went not, but ere I departed to come hither two or three
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: carles strayed my way, as whiles they will, who told me that this which
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the knight had said was naught but the sooth, and that great was the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: change of days at Utterbol, whereas all men there, both bond and free,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: were as merry as they deserved to be, or belike merrier."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Ralph pondered this tale, and was not so sure but that this new lord
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: was not Bull Shockhead, his wartaken thrall; natheless he held his
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: peace; but Ursula said:  "I marvel not much at the tale, for sure I am,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: that had Gandolf of the Bear been slain when I was at Utterbol, neither
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: man nor woman had stirred a finger to avenge him.  But all feared him,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: I scarce know why; and, moreover, there was none to be master if he
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: were gone."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Thereafter she told more tales of the miseries of Utterbol than Ralph
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: had yet heard, as though this tale of the end of that evil rule had set
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: her free to utter them; and they fell to talking of others matters.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: They Winter With the Sage; and Thereafter Come Again to Vale Turris
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Thus with no peril and little pain they came to the Sage's hermitage;
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and whereas the autumn was now wearing, and it was not to be looked for
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: that they should cross even the mountains west of Goldburg, let alone
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: those to the west of Cheaping Knowe, when winter had once set in, Ralph
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and Ursula took the Sage's bidding to abide the winter through with
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: him, and set forth on their journey again when spring should be fairly
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: come and the mountain ways be clear of snow.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: So they dwelt there happily enough; for they helped the Sage in his
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: husbandry, and he enforced him to make them cheer, and read in the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: ancient book to them, and learned them as much as it behoved them to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: hearken; and told them tales of past time.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Thereafter when May was at hand they set out on their road, and whereas
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the Sage knew the wood well, he made a long story short by bringing
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: them to Vale Turris in four days' time.  But when they rode down into
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the dale, they saw the plain meads below the Tower all bright with
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: tents and booths, and much folk moving about amidst them; here and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: there amidst the roofs of cloth withal was showing the half finished
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: frame of a timber house a-building. But now as they looked and wondered
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: what might be toward, a half score of weaponed men rode up to them and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: bade them, but courteously, to come with them to see their Lord.  The
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Sage drew forth his let-pass thereat; but the leader of the riders
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: said, as he shook his head: "That is good for thee, father; but these
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: two knights must needs give an account of themselves:  for my lord is
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: minded to put down all lifting throughout his lands; therefore hath he
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: made the meshes of his net small.  But if these be thy friends it will
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: be well.  Therefore thou art free to come with them and bear witness to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: their good life."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Here it must be said that since they were on the road again Ursula had
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: donned her wargear once more, and as she rode was to all men's eyes
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: naught but a young and slender knight.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: So without more ado they followed those men-at-arms, and saw how the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: banner of the Bull was now hung out from the Tower; and the sergeants
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: brought them into the midst of the vale, where, about those tents and

text: Then Ralph arose and took the cup and lifted it and spake: "This I
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

text: swear, that I will go home to my kindred, yet on the road will I not
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: into the Tower, whereas the chambers are dight for you, that I may make
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the most of this good day wherein I have met thee again."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

text: "When thou rannest away from me, and left me alone at Goldburg, I was
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: grieved; then Clement Chapman offered to take me back with him to his
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: own country, which, he did me to wit, lieth hard by thine: but I would
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: not go with him, since I had an inkling that I should find the slayer
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: of my brother and be avenged on him.  So the Chapmen departed from
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Goldburg after that Clement had dealt generously by me for thy sake;
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and when they were gone I bethought me what to do, and thou knowest I
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: can some skill with the fiddle and song, so I betook myself to that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: craft, both to earn somewhat and that I might gather tidings and be
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: little heeded, till within awhile folk got to know me well, and would
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: often send for me to their merry-makings, where they gave me fiddler's
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: wages, to wit, meat, drink, and money.  So what with one thing what
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: with another I was rich enough to leave Goldburg and fall to my journey
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: unto Utterbol; since I misdoubted me from the first that the caytiff
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: who had slain my brother was the Lord thereof.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "But one day when I went into the market-place I found a great stir and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: clutter there; some folk, both men and women screeching and fleeing,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and some running to bows and other weapons.  So I caught hold of one of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the fleers, and asked him what was toward; and he cried out, 'Loose me!
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: let me go! he is loose, he is loose!'
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "'Who is loose, fool?' quoth I. 'The lion,' said he, and therewith in
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the extremity of his terror tore himself away from me and fled.  By
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: this time the others also had got some distance away from me, and I was
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: left pretty much alone.  So I went forth on a little, looking about me,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and sure enough under one of the pillars of the cloister beneath the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: market-house (the great green pillar, if thou mindest it), lay crouched
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: a huge yellow lion, on the carcase of a goat, which he had knocked
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: down, but would not fall to eating of amidst all that cry and hubbub.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Now belike one thing of me thou wottest not, to wit, that I have a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: gift that wild things love and will do my bidding.  The house-mice will
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: run over me as I lie awake looking on them; the small birds will perch
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: on my shoulders without fear; the squirrels and hares will gambol about
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: quite close to me as if I were but a tree; and, withal, the fiercest
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: hound or mastiff is tame before me.  Therefore I feared not this lion,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and, moreover, I looked to it that if I might tame him thoroughly, he
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: would both help me to live as a jongleur, and would be a sure ward to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: me.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "So I walked up towards him quietly, till he saw me and half rose up
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: growling; but I went on still, and said to him in a peaceable voice:
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: 'How now, yellow mane! what aileth thee? down with thee, and eat thy
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: meat.' So he sat down to his quarry again, but growled still, and I
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: went up close to him, and said to him:  'Eat in peace and safety, am I
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: not here?' And therewith I held out my bare hand unclenched to him, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: he smelt to it, and straightway began to be peaceable, and fell to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: tearing the goat, and devouring it, while I stood by speaking to him
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: friendly.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "But presently I saw weapons glitter on the other side of the square
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: place, and men with bended bows.  The yellow king saw them also, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: rose up again and stood growling; then I strove to quiet him, and said,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: 'These shall not harm thee.'
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Therewith the men cried out to me to come away, for they would shoot:
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: But I called out; 'Shoot not yet! but tell me, does any man own this
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: beast?' 'Yea,' said one, 'I own him, and happy am I that he doth not
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: own me.' Said I, 'Wilt thou sell him?'  'Yea' said he, 'if thou livest
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: another hour to tell down the money.'  Said I, 'I am a tamer of wild
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: beasts, and if thou wilt sell this one at such a price, I will rid thee
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: of him.' The man yeasaid this, but kept well aloof with his fellows,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: who looked on, handling their weapons.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Then I turned to my new-bought thrall and bade him come with me, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: he followed me like a dog to his cage, which was hard by; and I shut
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: him in there, and laid down the money to his owner; and folk came round
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: about, and wondered, and praised me.  But I said:  'My masters, have ye
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: naught of gifts for the tamer of beasts, and the deliverer of men?'
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Thereat they laughed: but they brought me money and other goods, till I
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: had gotten far more than I had given for the lion.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Howbeit the next day the officers of the Porte came and bade me avoid
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the town of Goldburg, but gave me more money withal.  I was not loth
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: thereto, but departed, riding a little horse that I had, and leading my
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: lion by a chain, though when I was by he needed little chaining.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "So that without more ado I took the road to Utterbol, and wheresoever
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: I came, I had what was to be had that I would; neither did any man fall
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: on me, or on my lion.  For though they might have shot him or slain him
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: with many spear-thrusts, yet besides that they feared him sorely, they
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: feared me still more; deeming me some mighty sending from their Gods.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Thus came I to Utterness, and found it poor and wretched, (as
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: forsooth, it yet is, but shall not be so for long). But the House of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Utterbol is exceeding fair and stately (as thou mightest have learned
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: from others, my master,) and its gardens, and orchards, and acres, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: meadows as goodly as may be.  Yea, a very paradise; yet the dwellers
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: therein as if it were hell, as I saw openly with mine own eyes.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "To be short, the fame of me and my beast had somehow gone before me,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and when I came to the House, I was dealt with fairly, and had good
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: entertainment: and this all the more, as the Lord was away for a while,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and the life of folk not so hard by a great way as it had been if he
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: had been there: but the Lady was there in the house, and on the morrow
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: of my coming by her command, I brought my lion before her window and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: made him come and go, and fetch and carry at my bidding, and when I had
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: done my play she bade me up into her bower, and bade me sit and had me
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: served with wine, while she asked me many questions as to my country
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and friends, and whence and whither I was; and I answered her with the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: very sooth, so far as the sooth was handy; and there was with her but
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: one of her women, even thy friend Agatha, fair sir.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Methought both that this Queen was a fair woman, and that she looked
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: kindly upon me, and at last she said, sighing, that she were well at
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: ease if her baron were even such a man as I, whereas the said Lord was
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: fierce and cruel, and yet a dastard withal.  But the said Agatha turned
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: on her, and chided her, as one might with a child, and said: 'Hold thy
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: peace of thy loves and thy hates before a very stranger!  Or must I
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: leave yet more of my blood on the pavement of the White Pillar, for the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: pleasure of thy loose tongue?  Come out now, mountain-carle!'
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "And she took me by the hand and led me out, and when we had passed the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: door and it was shut, she turned to me and said: 'Thou, if I hear any
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: word abroad of what my Lady has just spoken, I shall know that thou
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: hast told it, and though I be but a thrall, yea, and of late a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: mishandled one, yet am I of might enough in Utterbol to compass thy
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: destruction.'
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "I laughed in her face and went my ways:  and thereafter I saw many
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: folk and showed them my beast, and soon learned two things clearly.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "And first that the Lord and the Lady were now utterly at variance.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: For a little before he had come home, and found a lack in his
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: household--to wit, how a certain fair woman whom he had but just got
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: hold of, and whom he lusted after sorely, was fled away.  And he laid
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the wyte thereof on his Lady, and threatened her with death: and when
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: he considered that he durst not slay her, or torment her (for he was
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: verily but a dastard), he made thy friend Agatha pay for her under
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: pretence of wringing a true tale out of her.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Now when I heard this story I said to myself that I should hear that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: other one of the slaying of my brother, and even so it befell.  For I
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: came across a man who told me when and how the Lord came by the said
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: damsel (whom I knew at once could be none other than thou, Lady,) and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: how he had slain my brother to get her, even as doubtless thou knowest,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Lord Ralph.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "But the second thing which I learned was that all folk at Utterbol,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: men and women, dreaded the home-coming of this tyrant; and that there
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: was no man but would have deemed it a good deed to slay him.  But,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: dastard as he was, use and wont, and the fear that withholdeth rebels,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and the doubt that draweth back slaves, saved him; and they dreaded him
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: moreover as a devil rather than a man.  Forsooth one of the men there,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: who looked upon me friendly, who had had tidings of this evil beast
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: drawing near, spake to me a word of warning, and said:  'Friend
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: lion-master, take heed to thyself!  For I fear for thee when the Lord
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: cometh home and findeth thee here; lest he let poison thy lion and slay
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: thee miserably afterward.'
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Well, in three days from that word home cometh the Lord with a rout of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: his spearmen, and some dozen of captives, whom he had taken.  And the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: morrow of his coming, he, having heard of me, sent and bade me showing
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the wonder of the Man and the Lion; therefore in the bright morning I
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: played with the lion under his window as I had done by the Queen.  And
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: after I had played some while, and he looking out of the window, he
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: called to me and said:  'Canst thou lull thy lion to sleep, so that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: thou mayst leave him for a little?  For I would fain have thee up here.'
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "I yeasaid that, and chid the beast, and then sang to him till he lay
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: down and slept like a hound weary with hunting.  And then I went up
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: into the Lord's chamber; and as it happed, all the while of my playing
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: I had had my short-sword naked in my hand, and thus, I deem without
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: noting it, yet as weird would, I came before the tyrant, where he sat
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: with none anigh him save this Otter and another man-at-arms. But when I
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: saw him, all the blood within me that was come of one mother with my
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: brother's blood stirred within me, and I set my foot on the foot-pace
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: of this murderer's chair, and hove up my short-sword, and clave his
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: skull, in front and with mine own hand: not as he wrought, not as he
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: wrought with my brother.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Then I turned about to Otter (who had his sword in his fist when it
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: was too late) till he should speak.  Hah Otter, what didst thou say?"
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Otter laughed:  Quoth he, "I said:  thus endeth the worst man in the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: world.  Well done, lion-tamer! thou art no ill guest, and hast paid on
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the nail for meat, drink and lodging.  But what shall we do now?  Then
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: thou saidst; 'Well, I suppose thou wilt be for slaying me.' 'Nay,' said
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: I, 'We will not slay thee; at least not for this, nor now, nor without
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: terms.'  Thou saidst:  'Perchance then thou wilt let me go free, since

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

author: Morris, William

text: They slept in no house that night nor for many nights after; for they
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: were now fairly on the waste.  They bore with them a light tent for
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Ursula's lodging benights, and the rest of them slept on the field as
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: they might; or should they come to a thicket or shaw, they would lodge
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: them there softly.  Victual and drink failed them not, for they bore
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: what they needed on sumpter-horses, and shot some venison on the way
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: withal.  They saw but few folk; for the most part naught save a fowler
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: of the waste, or a peat-cutter, who stood to look on the men-at-arms
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: going by, and made obeisance to the token of Utterbol.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: But on a time, the fifth day of their journey, they saw, in the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: morning, spears not a few standing up against a thicket-side in the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: offing.  Redhead looked under the sharp of his hand, and laughed as
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: though he were glad, and said:  "I know not clearly what these may be,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: but it looketh like war.  Now, knight, this is best to do: hold with
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: thee three of our best men, so that ye may safe guard the Lady, and I
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: with the others will prick on and look into this."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Nay," said Ralph, "thou mayst yet be apaid of a man's aid; and if
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: there be strokes on sale in the cheaping-stead yonder, I will deal
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: along with thee.  Leave thy three men with the Lady, and let us on; we
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: shall soon be back."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Nay once more, dear lord," quoth Ursula, "I fear to be left alone of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: thee, and it is meet that thou free me from fear.  I will ride with
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: you, but three horse-lengths behind, so as not to hinder you.  I have
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: been worse bestead than this shall be."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "It is good," quoth Redhead, "let her ride with us: for why should she
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: suffer the pain of fear in the lonely waste?  But let her do on a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: hauberk over her coats, and steel coif over her head, for shaft and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: bolt will ofttimes go astray."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Even so they did, and rode forward, and presently they saw the spearmen
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: that they were somewhat more than their company, and that they were
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: well mounted on black horses and clad in black armour.  Then they drew
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: rein for awhile and Redhead scanned them again and said: "Yea, these
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: are the men of the brother of thy hot wooer, Lady Ursula, whom I cooled
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: in the Ram's Bane, but a man well nigh as old as his uncle, though he
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: hath not made men tremble so sore, albeit he be far the better man, a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: good warrior, a wise leader, a reiver and lifter well wrought at all
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: points.  Well, 'tis not unlike that we shall have to speak to his men
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: again, either out-going or home-coming: so we had best kill as many of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: these as we may now.  Do on thy sallet, my lord; and thou,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Michael-a-green shake out the Bull; and thou, our Noise, blow a point
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: of war that they may be warned.  God to aid! but they be ready and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: speedy!"
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: In sooth even as the pennon of the Bull ran down the wind and the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Utterbol horn was winded, the Black men-at-arms came on at a trot, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: presently with a great screeching yell cast their spears into the rest,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and spurred on all they might, while a half score of bowmen who had
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: come out of the thicket bent their bows and fell a-shooting. But now
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the men of Utterbol spurred to meet the foe, and as Redhead cast his
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: anear to see me, for now I worship her."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Therewith the two bands met, and whereas on neither side was the armour
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: very stout, some men of either band were hurt or slain at once with
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: spearthrust; though, save for Ralph, they did not run straight on each
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: other; but fenced and foined with their spears deftly enough.  As for
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Ralph, he smote a tall man full on the breast and pierced him through
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and through, and then pulled out the Upmeads blade and smote on the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: right hand and the left, so that none came anigh him willingly.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Shortly to say it, in five minutes' time the Black Riders were fleeing
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: all over the field with them of Utterbol at their heels, and the bowmen
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: ran back again into the wood.  But one of the foemen as he fled cast a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: javelin at a venture, and who should be before it save Ursula, so that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: she reeled in her saddle, and would have fallen downright but for one
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: of the Utterbol fellows who stayed her, and got her gently off her
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: horse.  This Ralph saw not, for he followed far in the chase, and was
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: coming back somewhat slowly along with Redhead, who was hurt, but not
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: sorely.  So when he came up, and saw Ursula sitting on the grass with
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: for steel kept out steel: I have no scratch or point or edge on me."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: So therewith he kissed her, and embraced her, and was glad.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: The Utterbol Riders had slain sixteen of their foemen; for they took
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: that other day?"
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: wall.  For to-day, at least, I have seen thee play at sharps deftly
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: enough."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: which trieth a man, is to fight and overcome, and straight have to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: cover you--yea, or even death."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: servest thou shalt serve well.  And now once more I would it were me."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

text: Redhead shook his head at that word, and said:  "I would it might be
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: so; but it will not be so as now."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: On a day thereafter when it was nigh evening, Ralph looked about, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: saw a certain wood on the edge of a plain, and he stayed Ursula, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: kind field, where thou wert not stayed over long, but even long enough
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: that we might meet in the dark wood thereafter."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: even for a little.  For lo you! the captain is staying the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William
