text: Of Goldburg Again, and the Queen Thereof
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Next day they went forth through the country wherethrough Morfinn had
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: led Ralph into captivity; and Redhead rode warily; for there were many
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: passes which looked doubtful:  but whether the ill men feared to meddle
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: with them, or however it were, none waylaid them, and they all came
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: safely to the gate of Goldburg, the towers whereof were full of folk
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: looking forth on them.  So they displayed their pennon, and rode into
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the street, where folk pressed about them in friendly wise; for the new
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Lord of Utterbol had made firm and fast peace with Goldburg.  So they
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: rode to the hostel, and gat them victual, and rested in peace that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: night.  But Ralph wondered whether the Queen would send for him when
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: she heard of his coming back again, and he hoped that she would let him
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: be; for he was ashamed when he thought of her love for him, and how
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: that he had clean forgotten her till he was close to Goldburg again.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: But when morning was come Ralph spake to Redhead and asked him how he
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: should do to wage men for the homeward journey on thence; and Redhead
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: said:  "I have already seen the Clerk of the Porte, and he will be here
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: in an hour with the license for thee to wage men to go with thee to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Cheaping Knowe.  As for me, I must needs go see the King, and give him
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: a letter sealed by my lord's hand; and when I come back from him, I
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: will go round to the alehouses which be haunted of the men-at-arms to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: see after strong carles for thine avail.  But to the King hast thou no
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: need to go, save he send for thee, whereas thou art not come hither to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: chaffer, and he needeth not men of war."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Ralph stared at him and said:  "The King, sayst thou? is there no Queen
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: of Goldburg?"  Said Redhead:  "There is the King's wedded wife, but her
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: they call not Queen, but Lady." "But the Queen that was," said Ralph,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "where is she then?" "Yea truly," said Redhead, "a Queen sat alone as
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: ruler here a while ago; but whether she died, or what befell her, I
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: know nothing.  I had little to do with Goldburg till our lord conquered
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Utterbol.  Lo here the host! he may tell thee the tale thereof."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Therewith he departed, and left Ralph with the host, whom Ralph
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: questioned of the story, for his heart was wrung lest such a fair woman
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and so friendly should have come to harm.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: So the host sat down by Ralph and said:  "My master, this is a tale
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: which is grievous to us:  for though the saints forbid I should say a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: word against my lord that is now, nor is there any need to, yet we
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: deemed us happy to be under so dear a lady and so good and fair as she
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: was.  Well, she is gone so that we wot not whether she be living or
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: dead.  For so it is that in the early spring, somewhat more than a year
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: ago that is, one morning when folk arose, the Queen's place was empty.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Riding and running there was about and about, but none the more was she
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: found.  Forsooth as time wore, tales were told of what wise she left
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: us, and why:  but she was gone.  Well, fair sir, many deemed that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: though her lineage was known by seeming, yet she was of the fairy, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: needed neither steed nor chariot to go where she would.  But her women
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and those that knew her best, deemed that whatso she were, she had
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: slain herself, as they thought, for some unhappiness of love.  For
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: indeed she had long gone about sad and distraught, though she neither
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: wept, nor would say one word of her sorrow, whatsoever it might be.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "But, fair sir, since thou art a stranger, and art presently departing
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: from our city, I will tell thee a thing.  To wit; one month or so after
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: she had vanished away, I held talk with a certain old fisherman of our
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: water, and he told me that on that same night of her vanishing, as he
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: stood on the water-side handing the hawser of his barque, and the sail
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: was all ready to be sheeted home, there came along the shore a woman
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: our city; so that by night and cloud they made much way down the water,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

text: Ralph heard and pondered, and was exceeding sorry, and more had he been
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: but for the joyousness which came of the Water of the Well.  Howbeit he
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: They Come to Cheaping Knowe Once More.  Of the King Thereof
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Toward evening comes Redhead, and tells Ralph how he hired him a dozen
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: men-at-arms to follow him well-weaponed to Cheaping Knowe: withal he
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: counselled him to take a good gift with him to that same town to buy
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the good will of the King there; who was a close-fist and a cruel lord.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Afterwards they sat together in the court of that fair house before
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: good wine, Ralph and Ursula, and Redhead and the Sage of Swevenham, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: spake of many things, and were merry and kind together.  But on the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: depart, and they gave him farewell lovingly.  Thereafter Ralph's new
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: men came to him in the hostelry, and he feasted them and did well to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: them, so that they praised him much.  Then he gat him victuals and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: sumpter-horses for the journey, and bought good store of bows and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: goodly gift of silver vessel and fine cloth for the King of Cheaping
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Knowe.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: The day after he and his company departed from Goldburg toward the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: mountains, which they passed unfought and unwaylaid: partly because
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: they were a band of stout men, and partly because a little before there
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: had been a great overthrow of the wild men of those mountains at the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: hands of the men of Goldburg and the Chapmen; so that now the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: mountain-men lay close, and troubled none that rode with any force.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: On the way they failed not to pass by the place where they had erst
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: found Bull Nosy slain:  there they saw his howe, heaped up exceeding
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: high, covered in with earth, whereon the grass was now beginning to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: grow, and with a great standing stone on the top thereof, whereon was
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: graven the image of a bull, with a sword thereunder; whereby the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the new Lord of Utterbol.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: safe and sound on the third day; and slept in the hostelry of the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: three men unweaponed bearing the gift which he had got for the King.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Albeit he sent not away his men-at-arms till he should know how the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: King was minded towards him.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: justice, as handless men, fettered, dragging themselves about, and folk
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: errand, for gift-bearing men are not oftenest withstood.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: He was brought straightway into the great hall, where sat the King on
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: his throne amidst the chiefs of the Porte, and his captains and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: of lineage, but masterful men who were wise to do his bidding.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Being come to the King, he made his obeisance to him, and craved his
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: good will and leave to wage men-at-arms to bring him through the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: mountains.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: The King was a tall man, a proper man of war; long-legged, black
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: bearded, and fierce-eyed. Some word he had heard of Ralph's gift,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: therefore he was gracious to him; he spake and said:  "Thou hast come
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: across the mountains a long way, fair Sir; prithee on what errand?"
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: land." "Where is thine own land?" said the King, stretching out his
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: legs and lying back in his chair.  "West-away, lord, many a mile," said
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: mountains?  As far as Utterbol?"  Said Ralph:  "Yet further, but not to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: great errand; what was thine?"
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: might concerning Ursula; so he answered, and his voice grew loud and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: were knit a little, but his eyes sparkled from under them, and his
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and sent it back rattling, so that the sound of it went about the hall;
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the King's hall, and his armour rattled upon him.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the warriors and lords and merchants fell back from Ralph and stood in
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: wheedling: "Tell us, fair Sir, what is it that we can do to pleasure
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: thee?"
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "King," said Ralph, "I am not here to take gifts but to give them
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: rather: yet since thou biddest me I will crave somewhat of thee, that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: thou mayst be the more content:  and moreover the giving shall cost
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: thee nothing: I crave of thee to give me life and limb and freedom for
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the poor folk whom I saw led down the hall by thy tipstaves, even now.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Give me that or nothing."  The King scowled, but he spake: "This is
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: indeed a little gift of thee to take; yet to none else save thee had I
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: given it."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: free, and if any hurt hath befallen them thy life shall answer for it.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: to his mouth would have heard him mutter:  "So mighty! yet so wealthy!"
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: that for all his seeming wretchedness he was but disguised, and was in
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: King's Council, and I must needs tell thee a thing of the King: that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: though he was at the first overawed and cowed by the majesty of thee, a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Friend of the Well, he presently came to himself, which was but ill; so
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: that what for greed, what for fear even, he is minded to send men to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: waylay thee, some three leagues from the town, on your way to the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: mountains, but ye shall easily escape his gin now I have had speech of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: miles, and get aback of the waylayers.  Yet if ye escape this first
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

text: Ralph flushed red at that word, and felt his heart bound: but even
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: therewith came into them the Sage; and straightway Ralph took him apart
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and told him on what errand the man was come, and ask him if he deemed
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: him trusty.  Then the Sage went up to Michael and looked him hard in
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the face awhile, and then said: "Yea, honest he is unless the kindred
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: of Michael of the Hatch of Swevenham have turned thieves in the third
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: generation."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Yea," said Michael, "and dost thou know the Hatch?"
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "As I know mine own fingers," said the Sage; "and even so I knew it
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: years and years before thou wert born."  Therewith he told the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: new-comer what he was, and the two men of Swevenham made joy of each
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: other.  And Ralph was fain of them, and went into the chamber wherein
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: sat Ursula, and told her how all things were going, and she said that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: On the morrow Ralph got his men together betimes and rode out a-gates,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and was little afraid that any should meddle with him within the town
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: or anigh it, and even so it turned out.  But Michael rode in the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: company new clad, and with his head and face all hidden in a wide
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: sallet.  As for Ralph and Ursula, they were exceeding glad, and now
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: that their heads were turned to the last great mountains, it seemed to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: them that they were verily going home, and they longed for the night,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: that they might be alone together, and talk of all these matters in
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: each others' arms.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: When they were out a-gates, they rode for two miles along the highway,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: heedlessly enough by seeming, and then, as Michael bade, turned
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: suddenly into a deep and narrow lane, and forth on, as it led betwixt
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: hazelled banks and coppices of small wood, skirting the side of the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: hills, so that it was late in the afternoon before they came into the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Highway again, which was the only road leading into the passes of the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: mountains.  Then said Michael that now by all likelihood they had
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: beguiled the waylayers for that time; so they went on merrily till half
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the night was worn, when they shifted for lodging in a little oak-wood
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: by the wayside.  There they lay not long, but were afoot betimes in the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: morning, and rode swiftly daylong, and lay down at night on the wayside
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: with the less dread because they were come so far without hurt.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: But on the third day, somewhat after noon, when they were come up above
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the tilled upland and the land was rough and the ways steep, there lay
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: before them a dark wood swallowing up the road.  Thereabout Ralph
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: deemed that he saw weapons glittering ahead, but was not sure, for as
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: clear-sighted as he was.  So he stayed his band, and had Ursula into
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the rearward, and bade all men look to their weapons, and then they
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: went forward heedfully and in good order, and presently not only Ralph,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: but all of them could see men standing in the jaws of the pass with the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: wood on either side of them, and though at first they doubted if these
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: were aught but mere strong-thieves, such as any wayfarers might come
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: on, they had gone but a little further when Michael knew them for the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: riders of Cheaping Knowe.  "Yea," said the Sage of Swevenham, "it is
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: clear how it has been: when they found that we came not that first
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: morning, they had an inkling of what had befallen, and went forward
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: toward the mountains, and not back to Cheaping Knowe, and thus outwent
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: us while we were fetching that compass to give them the go-by:
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: wherefore I deem that some great man is with them, else had they gone
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: back to town for new orders."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Well," said Ralph, "then will they be too many for us; so now will I
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: ride ahead and see if we may have peace." Said the Sage, "Yea, but be
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: wary, for thou hast to do with the guileful."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Then Ralph rode on alone till he was come within hail of those
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: waylayers.  Then he thrust his sword into the sheath, and cried out:
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Will any of the warriors in the wood speak with me; for I am the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: captain of the wayfarers?"
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Then rode out from those men a very tall man, and two with him, one on
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: either side, and he threw back the sallet from his face, and said:
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Wayfarer, all we have weapons in our hands, and we so many that thou
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and thine will be in regard of us as the pips to the apple.  Wherefore,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: yield ye!"  Quoth Ralph:  "Unto whom then shall I yield me?" Said the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: other:  "To the men of the King of Cheaping Knowe." Then spake Ralph:
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "What will ye do with us when we are yolden?  Shall we not pay ransom
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and go our ways?"  "Yea," said the tall man, "and this is the ransom:
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: that ye give up into my hands my dastard who hath bewrayed me, and the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: woman who wendeth in your company."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Ralph laughed; for by this time he knew the voice of the King, yea, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the face of him under his sallet.  So he cried back in answer, and in
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: such wise as if the words came rather from his luck than from his
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: youth:  "Ho, Sir King!  beware beware! lest thou tremble when thou
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: seest the bare blade of the Friend of the Well more than thou
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: trembledst erst, when the blade was hidden in the sheath before the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: throne of thine hall."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: But the King cried out in a loud harsh voice.  "Thou, young man, beware
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: thou! and try not thy luck overmuch.  We are as many as these trees,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and thou canst not prevail over us.  Go thy ways free, and leave me
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: what thou canst not help leaving."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Yea, fool," cried Ralph, "and what wilt thou do with these two?"
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Said the King:  "The traitor I will flay, and the woman I will bed."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Scarce were the words out of his mouth ere Ralph gave forth a great cry
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and drew his sword, set spurs to his horse, and gallopped on up the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: road with all his band at his back for they had drawn anigh amidst this
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: talk.  But or ever they came on the foemen, they heard a great confused
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: cry of onset mingled with affright, and lo! the King threw up his arms,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and fell forward on his horse's neck with a great arrow through his
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: throat.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Ralph drave on sword in hand, crying out, "Home, home to Upmeads!" and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: anon was amidst of the foe smiting on either hand.  His men followed,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: shouting:  "Ho, for the Friend of the Well!" And amongst the foemen,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: who were indeed very many, was huge dismay, so that they made but a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: sorry defence before the band of the wayfarers, who knew not what to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: make of it, till they noted that arrows and casting-spears were coming
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: out of the wood on either side, which smote none of them, but many of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the foemen.  Short was the tale, for in a few minutes there were no men
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: of the foe together save those that were fleeing down the road to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Cheaping Knowe.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Ralph would not suffer his men to follow the chase, for he wotted not
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: with whom he might have to deal besides the King's men.  He drew his
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: men together and looked round for Ursula, and saw that the Sage had
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: brought her up anigh him, and there she sat a-horseback, pale and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: panting with the fear of death and joy of deliverance.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Now Ralph cried out from his saddle in a loud voice, and said: "Ho ye
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: of the arrows of the wood! ye have saved me from my foemen; where be
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: ye, and what be ye?"  Came a loud voice from out of the wood on the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: right hand:  "Children, tell the warrior whose sons ye be!" Straightway
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: brake out a huge bellowing on either side of the road, as though the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: wood were all full of great neat.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Then cried out Ralph:  "If ye be of the kindred of the Bull, ye will
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: belike be my friends rather than my foes.  Or have ye heard tell of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: from out the wood, and stood before Ralph in the twilight of the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: boughs, and Ralph noted of him that he was clad pretty much like to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: their weapons peaceably, while Ralph hailed the new-comer as Lord or
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Duke of the Bulls.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Belike," quoth the said chieftain, "thou wouldst wish to show me some
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: token, whereby we may wot that thou art that Friend of the Well and of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: our kinsman concerning whom he sent us a message."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: which Bull Shockhead had given him at Goldburg; so he drew it out, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: thereof than he said: "Verily our brother's hand hath met thine when he
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: gave thee this.  Yet forsooth, now that I look on thee, I may say that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

text: his bidding without more words.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: As they spake thus together the road both above and below was become
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: black with weaponed men, and some of Ralph's band looked on one
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: another, as though they doubted their new friends somewhat.  But the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: he, "so far as we go, who are now their friends, there is no guile in
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: side of Ralph, while Ursula rode on his right hand.  The Duke and all
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

text: were foemen to try it.  The houses thereof were artless, the chiefest
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: of them like to the great barn of an abbey in our land, the others low
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and small; but the people, both men and women, haunted mostly the big
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: house.  As for the folk, they were for the more part like those whom
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: they had met afore: strong men, but not high of stature, black-haired,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: with blue or grey eyes, cheerful of countenance, and of many words.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Their women were mostly somewhat more than comely, smiling, kind of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: speech, but not suffering the caresses of aliens.  They saw no thralls
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: amongst them; and when Ralph asked hereof, how that might be, since
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: they were men-catchers, they told him that when they took men and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: women, as oft they did, they always sold them for what they would bring
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: to the plain-dwellers; or else slew them, or held them to ransom, but
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: never brought them home to their stead.  Howbeit, when they took
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: children, as whiles befell, they sometimes brought them home, and made
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: of their Gods, who were indeed, as they deemed, but forefathers of the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Folk.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Now Ralph, he and his, being known for friends, these wild men could
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: not make enough of them, and as it were, compelled them to abide there
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: three days, feasting them, and making them all the cheer they might.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: And they showed the wayfarers their manner of hunting, both of the hart
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and the boar, and of wild bulls also.  At first Ralph somewhat loathed
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: all this (though he kept a pleasant countenance toward his host), for
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: sorely he desired the fields of Upmeads and his father's house.  But at
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: last when the hunt was up in the mountains, and especially of the wild
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: bulls, the heart and the might in him so arose that he enforced himself
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: to do well, and the wild men wondered at his prowess, whereas he was
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: untried in this manner of sports, and they deemed him one of the Gods,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and said that their kinsman had done well to get him so good a friend.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Both Ursula and the Sage withheld them from this hunting, and Ursula
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: abode with the women, who told her much of their ways of life, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: stories of old time; frank and free they were, and loved her much, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: she was fain of such manly-minded women after the sleight and lies of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the poor thralls of Utterbol.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: back with the wild men, praising Ralph much for his frankness and open
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: hand.  As for the wild men, they exceeded in their sorrow for the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Ralph and Ursula, with the Sage and Michael-a-dale went their ways, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: all was smooth with them, and they saw but few folk, and those mild and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: lowly.  At last, of an afternoon, they saw before them afar off the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: towers and pinnacles of Whitwall, and Ralph's heart rose within him, so
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: that he scarce knew how to contain himself; but Ursula was shy and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: silent, and her colour came and went, as though some fear had hold of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: her.  Now they two were riding on somewhat ahead of the others, so
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Ralph turned to Ursula, and asked what ailed her.  She smiled on him
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and said: "A simple sickness.  I am drawing nigh to thy home, and I am
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: ashamed.  Beyond the mountains, who knew what and whence I was?  I was
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: fair, and for a woman not unvaliant, and that was enough.  But now when
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: I am coming amongst the baronages and the lineages, what shall I do to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: hold up my head before the fools and the dastards of these high
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: kindreds?  And that all the more, my knight, because thou art changed
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: since yester-year, and since we met on the want-way of the Wood
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Perilous, when I bade thee remember that thou wert a King's son and I a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: yeoman's daughter; for then thou wert but a lad, high-born and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: beautiful, but simple maybe, and untried; whereas now thou art meet to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: sit in the Kaiser's throne and rule the world from the Holy City."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: He laughed gaily and said:  "What! is it all so soon forgotten, our
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: deeds beyond the Mountains?  Belike because we had no minstrel to rhyme
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: it for us.  Or is it all but a dream? and has the last pass of the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: mountains changed all that for us?  What then! hast thou never become
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: my beloved, nor lain in one bed with me?  Thou whom I looked to deliver
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: from the shame and the torment of Utterbol, never didst thou free
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: thyself without my helping, and meet me in the dark wood, and lead me
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: to the Sage who rideth yonder behind us!  No, nor didst thou ride
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: fearless with me, leaving the world behind; nor didst thou comfort me
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: when my heart went nigh to breaking in the wilderness!  Nor thee did I
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: deliver as I saw thee running naked from the jaws of death.  Nor were
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: we wedded in the wilderness far from our own folk.  Nor didst thou
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: deliver me from the venom of the Dry Tree.  Yea verily, nor did we
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: drink together of the Water of the Well!  It is all but tales of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Swevenham, a blue vapour hanging on the mountains yonder!  So be it
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: then!  And here we ride together, deedless, a man and a maid of whom no
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: tale may be told.  What next then, and who shall sunder us?"
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Therewith he drew his sword from the sheath, and tossed it into the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: air, and caught it by the hilts as it came down, and he cried out:
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Hearken, Ursula!  By my sword I swear it, that when I come home to the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: little land, if my father and my mother and all my kindred fall not
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: down before thee and worship thee, then will I be a man without
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: kindred, and I will turn my back on the land I love, and the House
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: wherein I was born, and will win for thee and me a new kindred that all
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the world shall tell of.  So help me Saint Nicholas, and all Hallows,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and the Mother of God!"
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: She looked on him with exceeding love, and said:  "Ah, beloved, how
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: fair thou art!  Is it not as I said, yea, and more, that now lieth the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: sweet, all folk shall see this as I see it, and shall judge betwixt
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: thee and me, and deem me naught."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Beloved," he said, "thou dost not wholly know thyself; and I deem that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the mirrors of steel serve thee but ill; and now must thou have
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: somewhat else for a mirror, to wit, the uprising and increase of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: trouble concerning thee and thy fairness, and the strife of them that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: love thee overmuch, who shall strive to take thee from me; and then the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: of my father's home, and then shalt thou be learned of thyself, when
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: feeble and foolish before thee!  What shall I do then?"

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

text: and found us void of comfort, since we have lost our Lady.  But we see
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: in thee, that she hath loved thee and blessed thee, and thou hast slain
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: her slayer and his kindred.  And we see of thee also that thou art a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: good lord.  O the comfort to us, therefore, if thou wouldest be our
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Lord!  We will serve thee truly so far as we may:  yea, even if thou be
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: beset by foes, we will take bow and bill from the wall, and stand round
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: about thee and fight for thee.  Only thou must not ask us to go hence
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: from this place: for we know naught but the Plain of Abundance, and the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: edges of the wood, and the Brethren of the House of the Thorn, who are
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: not far hence.  Now we pray thee by thy fathers not to naysay us, so
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: sore as thou hast made our hearts.  Also we see about thy neck the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: same-like pair of beads which our Lady was wont to bear, and we deem
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: that ye were in one tale together."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Then was Ralph silent awhile, but the Sage spake to the elder: "Old
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: man, how great is the loss of the Lady to you?" "Heavy loss, wise old
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: man," said the carle, "as thou thyself mayst know, having known her."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "And what did she for you?" said the Sage.  Said the elder: "We know
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: that she was gracious to us; never did she lay tax or tale on us, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: whiles she would give us of her store, and that often, and abundantly.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: We deem also that every time when she came to us our increase became
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: more plenteous, which is well seen by this, that since she hath ceased
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: to come, the seasons have been niggard unto us."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: The Sage smiled somewhat, and the old man went on: "But chiefly the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: blessing was to see her when she came to us: for verily it seemed that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: where she set her feet the grass grew greener, and that the flowers
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: blossomed fairer where the shadow of her body fell." And therewith the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: old man fell a-weeping again.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: The Sage held his peace, and Ralph still kept silence; and now of these
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: men all the younger ones had their eyes upon Ursula.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: After a while Ralph spake and said:  "O elder, and ye folk of the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: People of Abundance, true it is that your Lady who is dead loved me,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and it is through her that I am become a Friend of the Well.  Now
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: meseemeth though ye have lost your Lady, whom ye so loved and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: worshipped, God wot not without cause, yet I wot not why ye now cry out
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: for a master, since ye dwell here in peace and quiet and all wealth,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and the Fathers of the Thorn are here to do good to you.  Yet, if ye
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: will it in sooth, I will be called your Lord, in memory of your Lady
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: whom ye shall not see again.  And as time wears I will come and look on
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: you and hearken to your needs: and if ye come to fear that any should
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: fall upon you with the strong hand, then send ye a message to me, Ralph
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: of Upmeads, down by the water, and I will come to you with such
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: following as need be.  And as for service, this only I lay upon you,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: that ye look to the Castle and keep it in good order, and ward it
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: against thieves and runagates, and give guesting therein to any
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: wandering knight or pilgrim, or honest goodman, who shall come to you.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Now is all said, my masters, and I pray you let us depart in peace; for
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: time presses."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Then all they (and this time women as well as men) cried out joyfully:
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Hail to our lord! and long life to our helper."  And the women withal
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: drew nearer to him, and some came close up to him, as if they would
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: touch him or kiss his hand, but by seeming durst not, but stood
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: blushing before him, and he looked on them, smiling kindly.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: But the old man laid his hand on his knee and said: "Lord, wouldst thou
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: not light down and enter thy Castle; for none hath more right there now
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: than thou.  The Prior of the Thorn hath told us that there is no
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: lineage of the Lady left to claim it; and none other might ever have
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: claimed it save the Baron of Sunway, whom thou hast slain.  And else
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: would we have slain him, since he slew our Lady."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Ralph shook his head and said:  "Nay, old friend, and new vassal, this
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: we may not do:  we must on speedily, for belike there is work for us to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: do nearer home."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Yea, Lord," said the carle, "but at least light down and sit for a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: while under this fair oak-tree in the heat of the day, and eat a morsel
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: with us, and drink a cup, that thy luck may abide with us when thou art
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: gone."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Ralph would not naysay him; so he and all of them got off their horses,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and sat down on the green grass under the oak: and that people gathered
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: about and sat down by them, save that a many of the women went to their
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: houses to fetch out the victual.  Meanwhile the carles fell to speech
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: freely with the wayfarers, and told them much concerning their little
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: land, were it hearsay, or stark sooth:  such as tales of the wights
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: that dwelt in the wood, wodehouses, and elf-women, and dwarfs, and such
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: like, and how fearful it were to deal with such creatures.  Amongst
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: other matters they told how a hermit, a holy man, had come to dwell in
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the wood, in a clearing but a little way thence toward the north-west.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: But when Ralph asked if he dwelt on the way to the ford of the Swelling
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Flood, they knew not what he meant; for the wood was to them as a wall.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Hereon the Sage held one of the younger men in talk, and taught him
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: what he might of the way to the Burg of the Four Friths, so that they
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: might verily send a messenger to Upmeads if need were.  But the country
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: youth said there was no need to think thereof, as no man of theirs
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: would dare the journey through the wood, and that if they had need of a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: messenger, one of the Fathers of the Thorn would do their errand,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: whereas they were holy men, and knew the face of the world full well.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Now in this while the folk seemed to have gotten their courage again,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and to be cheery, and to have lost their grief for the Lady: and of the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: maidens left about the oak were more than two or three very fair, who
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: stood gazing at Ralph as if they were exceeding fain of him.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: But amidst these things came back the women with the victual; to wit
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: bread in baskets, and cheeses both fresh and old, and honey, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: wood-strawberries, and eggs cooked diversely, and skewers of white wood
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: with gobbets of roasted lamb's flesh, and salad good plenty.  All these
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: they bore first to Ralph and Ursula, and their two fellows, and then
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: dealt them to their own folk: and they feasted and were merry in
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: despite of that tale of evil tidings.  They brought also bowls and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: pitchers of wine that was good and strong, and cider of their orchards,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and called many a health to the new Lord and his kindred.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Thus then they abode a-feasting till the sun was westering and the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: shadows waxed about them, and then at last Ralph rose up and called to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: horse, and the other wayfarers arose also, and the horses were led up
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: to them.  Then the maidens, made bold by the joy of the feast, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: being stirred to the heart by much beholding of this beloved Lord, cast
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: off their shamefacedness and crowded about him, and kissed his raiment
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and his hands: some even, though trembling, and more for love than
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: fear, prayed him for kisses, and he, nothing loath, laughed merrily and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: laid his hands on their shoulders or took them by the chins, and set
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: his lips to the sweetness of their cheeks and their lips, of those that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: asked and those that refrained; so that their hearts failed them for
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: love of him, and when he was gone, they knew not how to go back to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: their houses, or the places that were familiar to them.  Therewith he
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and his got into their saddles and rode away slowly, because of the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: thronging about them of that folk, who followed them to the edge of the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: wood, and even entered a little thereinto; and then stood gazing on
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Ralph and his fellows after they had spurred on and were riding down a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: glade of the woodland.

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

author: Morris, William

text: Ralph woke about sunrise, and looking up saw a man standing over him,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and deemed at first that it would be Richard or the Sage; but as his
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: vision cleared, he saw that it was neither of them, but a new comer; a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: stout carle clad in russet, with a great staff in his hand and a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: short-sword girt to his side.  Ralph sprang up, still not utterly
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: awake, and cried out, "Who art thou, carle?"  The man laughed, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: said: "Yea, thou art still the same brisk lad, only filled out to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: something more warrior-like than of old.  But it is unmeet to forget
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: old friends.  Why dost thou not hail me?"
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Because I know thee not, good fellow," said Ralph.  But even as he
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: spoke, he looked into the man's face again, and cried out:  "By St.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Nicholas! but it is Roger of the Ropewalk.  But look you, fellow, if I
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: have somewhat filled out, thou, who wast always black-muzzled, art now
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: become as hairy as a wodehouse.  What dost thou in the wilds?"  Said
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: that I am so much of that, either.  I have not come hither to pray or
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: all things have changed since my Lady passed away."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William
