title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Sage stirring, while Richard yet hugged his bracken bed, snoring.  So
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Ralph smiled, and without more ado told him all that had befallen him;
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and of Swevenham and Utterbol, and of his captivity and flight; and of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the meeting in the wood, and of the Sage (who there was), and of the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: journey to the Well, and what betid there and since, and of the death
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: of the Champion of the Dry Tree.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: But when he had made an end, Roger said:  "There it is, then, as I said
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: when she first spake to me of thee and bade me bring about that meeting
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: with her, drawing thee first to the Burg and after to the Castle of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Abundance, I have forgotten mostly by what lies; but I said to her that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: she had set her heart on a man over lucky, and that thou wouldst take
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: her luck from her and make it thine.  But now I will let all that pass,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and will bid thee ask what thou wilt; and I promise thee that I will
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: help thee to come thy ways to thy kindred, that thou mayst put forth
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: thy luck in their behalf."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Said Ralph:  "First of all, tell me what shall I do to pass unhindered
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: through the Burg of the Four Friths?"  Said Roger: "Thou shalt go in at
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: one gate and out at the other, and none shall hinder thee."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Said Ralph:  "And shall I have any hindrance from them of the Dry Tree?"
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Roger made as if he were swallowing down something, and answered: "Nay,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: none."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "And the folk of Higham by the Way, and the Brethren and their Abbot?"
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: said Ralph.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "I know but little of them," quoth Roger, "but I deem that they will
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: make a push to have thee for captain; because they have had war on
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: their hands of late.  But this shall be at thine own will to say yea or
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: nay to them.  But for the rest on this side of the shepherds' country
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: ye will pass by peaceful folk."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Yea," said Ralph, "what then hath become of the pride and cruelty of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the Burg of the Four Friths, and the eagerness and fierceness of the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Dry Tree?"
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Quoth Roger:  "This is the tale of it:  After the champions of the Dry
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Tree had lost their queen and beloved, the Lady of Abundance, they were
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: both restless and fierce, for the days of sorrow hung heavy on their
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: hands.  So on a time a great company of them had ado with the Burgers
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: somewhat recklessly and came to the worse; wherefore some drew back
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: into their fastness of the Scaur and the others still rode on, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: further west than their wont had been; but warily when they had the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Wood Perilous behind them, for they had learned wisdom again.  Thus
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: riding they had tidings of an host of the Burg of the Four Friths who
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: were resting in a valley hard by with a great train of captives and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: beasts and other spoil: for they had been raising the fray against the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Wheat-wearers, and had slain many carles there, and were bringing home
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: to the Burg many young women and women-children, after their custom.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: So they of the Dry Tree advised them of these tidings, and deemed that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: it would ease the sorrow of their hearts for their Lady if they could
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: deal with these sons of whores and make a mark upon the Burg: so they
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: lay hid while the daylight lasted, and by night and cloud fell upon
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: these faineants of the Burg, and won them good cheap, as was like to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: be, though the Burg-dwellers were many the more.  Whereof a many were
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: slain, but many escaped and gat home to the Burg, even as will lightly
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: happen even in the worst of overthrows, that not all, or even the more
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: part be slain.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Well, there were the champions and their prey, which was very great,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and especially of women, of whom the more part were young and fair: for
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the women of the Wheat-wearers be goodly, and these had been picked out
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: by the rutters of the Burg for their youth and strength and beauty.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: And whereas the men of the Dry Tree were scant of women at home, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: sore-hearted because of our Lady, they forbore not these women, but
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: fell to talking with them and loving them; howbeit in courteous and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: manly fashion, so that the women deemed themselves in heaven and were
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: ready to do anything to please their lovers.  So the end of it was that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the Champions sent messengers to Hampton and the Castle of the Scaur to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: tell what had betid, and they themselves took the road to the land of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the Wheat-wearers, having those women with them not as captives but as
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: free damsels.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Now the road to the Wheat-wearing country was long, and on the way the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: damsels told their new men many things of their land and their unhappy
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: wars with them of the Burg and the griefs and torments which they
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: endured of them.  And this amongst other things, that wherever they
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: came, they slew all the males even to the sucking babe, but spared the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: women, even when they bore them not into captivity.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "'Whereof,' said these poor damsels, 'it cometh that our land is
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: ill-furnished of carles, so that we women, high and low, go afield and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: do many things, as crafts and the like, which in other lands are done
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: by carles.' In sooth it seemed of them that they were both of stouter
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: fashion, and defter than women are wont to be.  So the champions, part
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: in jest, part in earnest, bade them do on the armour of the slain
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Burgers, and take their weapons, and fell to teaching them how to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: handle staff and sword and bow; and the women took heart from the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: valiant countenance of their new lovers, and deemed it all bitter
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: earnest enough, and learned their part speedily; and yet none too soon.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: For when the fleers of the Burg came home the Porte lost no time, but
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: sent out another host to follow after the Champions and their spoil;
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: for they had learned that those men had not turned about to Hampton
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: after their victory, but had gone on to the Wheat-wearers.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "So it befell that the host of the Burg came up with the Champions on
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the eve of a summer day when there were yet three hours of daylight.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: But whereas they had looked to have an easy bargain of their foemen,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: since they knew the Champions to be but a few, lo! there was the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: hillside covered with a goodly array of spears and glaives and shining
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: helms.  They marvelled; but now for very shame, and because they scarce
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: could help it, they fell on, and before sunset were scattered to the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: winds again, and the fleers had to bear back the tale that the more
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: part of their foes were women of the Wheat-wearers; but this time few
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: were those that came back alive to the Burg of the Four Friths; for the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: freed captives were hot and eager in the chase, casting aside their
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: shields and hauberks that they might speed the better, and valuing
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: their lives at naught if they might but slay a man or two of the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: tyrants before they died.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Thus was the Burg wounded with its own sword:  but the matter stopped
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: not there:  for when that victorious host of men and women came into
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the land of the Wheat-wearers, all men fled away in terror at first,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: thinking that it was a new onset of the men of the Burg; and that all
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the more, as so many of them bore their weapons and armour.  But when
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: they found out how matters had gone, then, as ye may deem, was the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: greatest joy and exultation, and carles and queans both ran to arms and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: bade their deliverers learn them all that belonged to war, and said
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: that one thing should not be lacking, to wit, the gift of their bodies,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: that should either lie dead in the fields, or bear about henceforth the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: souls of free men.  Nothing lothe, the Champions became their doctors
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and teachers of battle, and a great host was drawn together; and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: meanwhile the Champions had sent messengers again to Hampton telling
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: them what was befallen, and asking for more men if they might be had.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: But the Burg-abiders were not like to sit down under their foil.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Another host they sent against the Wheat-wearers, not so huge, as well
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: arrayed and wise in war.  The Champions espied its goings, and knew
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: well that they had to deal with the best men of the Burg, and they met
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: them in like wise; for they chose the very best of the men and the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: women, and pitched on a place whence they might ward them well, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: abode the foemen there; who failed not to come upon them, stout and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: stern and cold, and well-learned in all feats of war.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Long and bitter was the battle, and the Burgers were fierce without
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: head-strong folly, and the Wheat-wearers deemed that if they blenched
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: now, they had something worse than death to look to.  But in the end
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: when both sides were grown weary and worn out, and yet neither would
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: flee, on a sudden came into the field the help from the Dry Tree, a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: valiant company of riders to whom battle was but game and play.  Then
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: indeed the men of the Burg gave back and drew out of the battle as best
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: they might: yet were they little chased, save by the new-comers of the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Dry Tree, for the others were over weary, and moreover the leaders had
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: no mind to let the new-made warriors leave their vantage-ground lest
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the old and tried men-at-arms of the Burg should turn upon them and put
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: them to the worse.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Men looked for battle again the next day; but it fell not out so; for
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the host of the Burg saw that there was more to lose than to gain, so
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: they drew back towards their own place.  Neither did they waste the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: land much; for the riders of the Dry Tree followed hard at heel, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: cut off all who tarried, or strayed from the main battle.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "When they were gone, then at last did the Wheat-wearers give
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: themselves up to the joy of their deliverance and the pleasure of their
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: new lives: and one of their old men that I have spoken with told me
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: this; that before when they were little better than the thralls of the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Burg, and durst scarce raise a hand against the foemen, the carles were
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: but slow to love, and the queans, for all their fairness, cold and but
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: little kind.  However, now in the fields of the wheat-wearers
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: themselves all this was changed, and men and maids took to arraying
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: themselves gaily as occasion served, and there was singing and dancing
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: on every green, and straying of couples amongst the greenery of the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: summer night; and in short the god of love was busy in the land, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: made the eyes seem bright, and the lips sweet, and the bosom fair, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the arms sleek and the feet trim:  so that every hour was full of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: allurement; and ever the nigher that war and peril was, the more
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: delight had man and maid of each other's bodies.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Well, within a while the Wheat-wearers were grown so full of hope that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: they bade the men of the Dry Tree lead them against the Burg of the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Four Friths, and the Champions were ready thereto; because they wotted
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: well, that, Hampton being disgarnished of men, the men of the Burg
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: might fall on it; and even if they took it not, they would beset all
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: ways and make riding a hard matter for their fellowship.  So they fell
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: to, wisely and deliberately, and led an host of the best of the carles
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: with them, and bade the women keep their land surely, so that their
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: host was not a great many.  But so wisely they led them that they came
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: before the Burg well-nigh unawares; and though it seemed little likely
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: that they should take so strong a place, yet nought less befell.  For
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the Burg-dwellers beset with cruelty and bitter anger cried out that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: now at last they would make an end of this cursed people, and the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: whoreson strong-thieves their friends: so they went out a-gates a great
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: multitude, but in worser order than their wont was; and there befell
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: that marvel which sometimes befalleth even to very valiant men, that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: now at the pinch all their valour flowed from them, and they fled
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: before the spears had met, and in such evil order that the gates could
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: not be shut, and their foemen entered with them slaying and slaying
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: even as they would.  So that in an hour's space the pride and the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: estate of the Burg of the Four Friths was utterly fallen.  Huge was the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: slaughter; for the Wheat-wearers deemed they had many a grief whereof
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: to avenge them; nor were the men of the Dry Tree either sluggards or
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: saints to be careless of their foemen, or to be merciful in the battle:
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: but at last the murder was stayed: and then the men of the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Wheat-wearers went from house to house in the town to find the women of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: their folk who had been made thralls by the Burgers.  There then was
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: many a joyful meeting betwixt those poor women and the men of their
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: kindred: all was forgotten now of the days of their thralldom, their
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: toil and mocking and stripes; and within certain days all the sort of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: them came before the host clad in green raiment, and garlanded with
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: flowers for the joy of their deliverance; and great feast was made to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: them.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "As for them of the Burg, the battle and chase over, no more were
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: slain, save that certain of the great ones were made shorter by the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: head.  But the Champions and the Wheat-wearers both, said that none of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: that bitter and cruel folk should abide any longer in the town; so that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: after a delay long enough for them to provide stuff for their

text: wayfaring, they were all thrust out a-gates, rich and poor, old and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

text: young, man, woman and child.  Proudly and with a stout countenance they
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: went, for now was their valour come again to them.  And it is like that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: betide the peaceful folk whom they shall first fall on.  Yea, fair sir,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: thine hand heavy against them."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

text: Tree?  for I see that thou hast some grief on thy mind because of them."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Roger kept silence a little and then he said:  "I grieve because
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Hampton is no more a strong place of warriors; two or three carles and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: a dozen of women dwell now in the halls and chambers of the Scaur.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Here on earth, all endeth.  God send us to find the world without end!"
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

text: "What then," said Ralph, "have they then had another great overthrow,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: worse than that other?"  "Nay," said Roger doggedly, "it is not so."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "But where is the Fellowship?" said Ralph.  "It is scattered abroad,"
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: whom they had wooed in the Wheat-wearer's land: and some, and a great
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: alive after the Burg was taken; besides that many women also came with
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the carles from their own land.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "So that now a mixed folk are dwelling in the Burg, partly of those
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: are wedded to queans of the Wheat-wearers, and partly of men, chapmen
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and craftsmen and others who have drifted into the town, having heard
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: that there is no lack of wealth there, and many fair women unmated."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Yea," said Ralph, "and is all this so ill?"  Said Roger, "Meseems it
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: is ill enough that there is no longer, rightly said, a Fellowship of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the Dry Tree, though the men be alive who were once of that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: fellowship." "Nay," said Ralph, "and why should they not make a new
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: fellowship in the Burg, whereas they may well be peaceful, since they
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: have come to their above of their foemen?"
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Yea," said Roger slowly, "that is sooth; and so is this, that there in
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the Burg they are a strong band, with a captain of their own, and much
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: worshipped of the peaceful folk; and moreover, though they be not cruel
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: to torment helpless folk, or hard to make an end of all joy to-day,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: lest they lose their joy to-morrow, they now array all men in good
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: order within the Burg, so that it shall be no easier for a foeman to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: win that erst it was."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "What, man!" said Ralph, "then be of better cheer, and come thou with
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: us, and may be the old steel of the champions may look on the sun down
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: in Upmeads.  Come thou with me, I say, and show me and my luck to some
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: of thy fellows who are dwelling in the Burg, and it may be when thou
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: their beds cold for a while, that they may come help a Friend of the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Well in his need."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Roger sat silent as if he were pondering the matter, while Richard and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the Sage, both of them, took up the word one after the other, and urged
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: him to it.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: At last he said:  "Well, so be it for this adventure.  Only I say not
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: that I shall give up this hermitage and my holiness for ever.  Come
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: thou aside, wise man of Swevenham, and I shall tell thee wherefore."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Yea," said Ralph, laughing, "and when he hath told thee, tell me not
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: again; for sure I am that he is right to go with us, and belike shall
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: be wrong in his reason therefore."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Roger looked a little askance at him, and he went without doors with
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the Sage, and when they were out of earshot, he said to him: "Hearken,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: I would have gone with my lord at the first word, and have been fain
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: thereof; but there is this woman that followeth him.  At every turn she
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: shall mind me of our Lady that was; and I shall loath her, and her
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: fairness and the allurements of her body, because I see of her, that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: she it is that hath gotten my Lady's luck, and that but for her my Lady
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: might yet have been alive."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Said the Sage:  "Well quoth my lord that thou wouldst give me a fool's
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: reason!  What! dost not thou know, thou that knowest so much of the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Lady of Abundance, that she it was who ordained this Ursula to be
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: not knowing the mind of our Lady, and how she loved him in her inmost
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: heart."

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Roger hung his head and spake not for a while, and then he said: "Well,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: smooth my tongue for this while at least, and for what may come
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: hereafter, let it be.  And now we were best get to horse; for what with
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: little of noon.  Go tell thy lord that I am ready.  Farewell peace, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: into the fields about the Burg of the Four Friths; and even there was a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: look of a bettering of men's lives; though forsooth the husbandmen
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: there were much the same as had abided in the fields aforetime, whereas
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: they were not for the most part freemen of the Burg, but aliens who did
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: service in war and otherwise thereto.  But, it being eventide, there
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: were men and women and children, who had come out of gates, walking
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: about and disporting themselves in the loveliness of early summer, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: trusts the peace of the Burg overmuch since, when all is told, unpeace
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: is not so far from their borders."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: gleam of helms and weapons on the walls, and they saw a watchman on
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the Burg will not be won so easily; and if a few fools get themselves
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: slain outside it is no great matter."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: them to look at the newcomers, but not so as to hinder them, and they
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: them as though they had but few troubles weighing on them.  But the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: wayfarers were not unchallenged at the gate, for a stout man-at-arms
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: stayed them and said: "Ye ride somewhat late, friends.  What are ye?"
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: goes that there are alien riders come into the lands of Higham, and for
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: aught I know the said unpeace may spread further on.  Well if ye will
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: go to the Flower de Luce and abide there this night, ye shall have a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: let-pass to-morn betimes."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Then Ralph spake a word in Roger's ear, and Roger nodded his head, and,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: from all of us to live in the wilds."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "So it was, lad," said Roger, "but times change from good to bad and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: back again; and now am I of this good lord's company; and I shall tell
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: be that rideth with him to-morrow if unpeace be in the land.  Lo you,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: thee things of him that thou wottest not."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: there are tales going about concerning thee, some whereof are strange
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: enow, but none of them ill; and I deem by the look of thee that thou
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: shalt be both a stark champion and a good lord; and I deem that it
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: shall be my good luck, if I see more of thee, and much more.  Now if
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: thou wilt, pass on with thine other fellows to the Flower de Luce, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: out-a-gates this time otherwise than thou didest before."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

text: Ralph asked Hugh first if he wotted aught of Gregory their brother.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Hugh laughed and pointed to Higham, and said:  "He is yonder." "What,"
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: said Ralph, "in the Abbot's host?"  "Yea," said Hugh, laughing again,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "but in his spiritual, not his worldly host: he is turned monk,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: brother; that is, he is already a novice, and will be a brother of the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Abbey in six months' space."  Said Ralph: "And Launcelot Long-tongue,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: thy squire, how hath he sped?"  Said Hugh: "He is yonder also, but in
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the worldly host, not the spiritual: he is a sergeant of theirs, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: somewhat of a catch for them, for he is no ill man-at-arms, as thou
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: wottest, and besides he adorneth everything with words, so that men
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: hearken to him gladly." "But tell me," said Ralph, "how it befalleth
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: that the Abbot's men of war be so churlish, and chary of the inside of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: their town; what have they to fear?  Is not the Lord Abbot still a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: mighty man?" Hugh shook his head:  "There hath been a change of days at
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Higham; though I say not but that the knights are over careful, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: much over fearful."  "What has the change been?" said Ralph.  Hugh
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: said:  "In time past my Lord Abbot was indeed a mighty man, and both
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: this town of Higham was well garnished of men-at-arms, and also many of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: his manors had castles and strong-houses on them, and the yeomen were
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: ready to run to their weapons whenso the gathering was blown.  In
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: short, Higham was as mighty as it was wealthy; and the Abbot's men had
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: naught to do with any, save with thy friends here who bear the Tree
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Leafless; all else feared those holy walls and the well-blessed men who
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: warded them.  But the Dry Tree feared, as men said, neither man nor
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: devil (and I hope it may be so still since they are become thy
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: friends), and they would whiles lift in the Abbot's lands when they had
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: no merrier business on hand, and not seldom came to their above in
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: their dealings with his men.  But all things come to an end; for, as I
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: am told, some year and a half ago, the Abbot had debate with the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Westland Barons, who both were and are ill men to deal with, being both
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: hungry and doughty.  The quarrel grew till my Lord must needs defy
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: them, and to make a long tale short, he himself in worldly armour led
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: his host against them, and they met some twenty miles to the west in
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the field of the Wry Bridge, and there was Holy Church overthrown; and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the Abbot, who is as valiant a man as ever sang mass, though not
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: over-wise in war, would not flee, and as none would slay him, might
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: they help it, they had to lead him away, and he sits to this day in
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: their strongest castle, the Red Mount west-away. Well, he being gone,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and many of his wisest warriors slain, the rest ran into gates again;
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: but when the Westlanders beset Higham and thought to have it good
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: cheap, the monks and their men warded it not so ill but that the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Westlanders broke their teeth over it.  Forsooth, they turned away
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: thence and took most of the castles and strong-houses of the Abbot's
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: lands; burned some and put garrisons into others, and drave away a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: mighty spoil of chattels and men and women, so that the lands of Higham
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: are half ruined; and thereby the monks, though they be stout enough
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: within their walls, will not suffer their men to ride abroad.  Whereby,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: being cooped up in a narrow place, and with no deeds to hand to cheer
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: their hearts withal, they are grown sour and churlish."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "But, brother," said Ralph, "howsoever churlish they may be, and howso
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: timorous, I cannot see why they should shut their gates in our faces, a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: little band, when there is no foe anear them."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Ralph," said Hugh, "thou must think of this once more, that the Dry
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Tree is no good let-pass to flourish in honest men's faces; specialiter
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: if they be monks.  Amongst the brothers of Higham the tale goes that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: those Champions have made covenant with the devil to come to their
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: above whensoever they be not more than one to five.  Nay, moreover, it
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: is said that there be very devils amongst them; some in the likeness of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: carles, and some (God help us) dressed up in women's flesh; and fair
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: flesh also, meseemeth.  Also to-day they say in Higham that no
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: otherwise might they ever have overcome the stark and cruel carles of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the Burg of the Four Friths and chased them out of their town, as we
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: know they have done.  Hah! what sayest thou?"
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "I say, Hugh," quoth Ralph angrily, "that thou art a fool to go about
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: with a budget of slanderous old wives' tales."  Hugh laughed.  "Be not
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: so wroth, little lord, or I shall be asking thee tales of marvels also.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: But hearken.  I shall smooth out thy frowns with a smile when thou hast
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: heard this: this folk are not only afeard of their old enemies, the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: devil-led men, but also they fear those whom the devil-led men have
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: driven out of house and home, to wit, the Burgers.  Yet again they fear
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the Burgers yet more, because they have beaten some of the very foes of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Higham, to wit, the Westland Barons; for they have taken from them some
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: of their strong-holds, and are deemed to be gathering force."

author: Morris, William

text: Ralph pondered a while, and then he said:  "Brother, hast thou any
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: tidings of Upmeads, or that these Burgers have gone down thither?" "God
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: forbid!" said Hugh.  "Nay, I have had no tidings of Upmeads since I was
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: fool enough to leave it."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "What! brother," said Ralph, "thou hast not thriven then?"
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "I have had ups and downs," said Hugh, "but the ups have been one rung
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: of the ladder, and the downs three--or more.  Three months I sat in
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: prison for getting me a broken head in a quarrel that concerned me not.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Six months was I besieged in a town whither naught led me but ill-luck.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Two days I wore in running thence, having scaled the wall and swam the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: ditch in the night.  Three months I served squire to a knight who gave
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: me the business of watching his wife of whom he was jealous; and to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: help me out of the weariness of his house I must needs make love myself
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: to the said wife, who sooth to say was perchance worth it.  Thence
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: again I went by night and cloud.  Ten months I wore away at the edge of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the wildwood, and sometimes in it, with a sort of fellows who taught me
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: many things, but not how to keep my hands from other men's goods when I
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: was hungry.  There was I taken with some five others by certain
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: sergeants of Higham, whom the warriors of the town had sent out
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: cautiously to see if they might catch a few men for their ranks.  Well,
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: face this evening, fair sir."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: might not be ill."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: somewhat?" Said Ralph:  "Ask on."  "Fair Sir," said Hugh, "thou
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: seemedst grown into a pretty man when I saw thee e'en-now before this
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: if she be an earl's daughter she is a fair getting for an imp of

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

text: sweet tongue in thy mouth.  But tell me, what is she?"

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

author: Morris, William

text: else are we come hither."

author: Morris, William

text: Said the Elder:  "Will ye come with us as friends or as hirelings?  for
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: in any case we would have you by our sides, and not in face of us; and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale

text: They Come to Wulstead
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Thus went they, and nought befell them to tell of till they came anigh
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the gates of Wulstead hard on sunset.  The gates, it has been said; for
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: whereas Ralph left Wulstead a town unwalled, he now found it fenced
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: with pales, and with two towers strongly framed of timber, one on
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: either side the gate, and on the battlements of the said towers they
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: saw spears glittering; before the gate they saw a barrier of big beams
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: also, and the gleaming of armour therein.  Ralph was glad when he saw
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: that they meant some defence; for though Wulstead was not in the lands
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: of Upmeads, yet it was always a friendly neighbour, and he looked to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: eke out his host therein.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Wulstead standeth on a little hill or swelling of the earth, and the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: road that the company of Ralph took went up to the gate across the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: plain meadows, which had but here and there a tree upon them, so that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the going of the company was beheld clearly from the gate; as was well
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: seen, because anon came the sound of the blowing of great horns, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the spears thickened in the towers.  Then Ralph stayed his company two
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: bowshots from the barriers, while he himself, with his sword in his
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: sheath, took Ursula's hand and set forth an easy pace toward the gate.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Some of his company, and specially Roger and Stephen, would have letted
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: him; but he laughed and said, "Why, lads, why? these be friends."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Yea," quoth Roger, "but an arrow knoweth no kindred nor well-willers:
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: have a care, lord."  Said the Sage of Swevenham: "Ye speak but after
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: the folly of men of war; the hands and the eyes that be behind the bows
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: have other hands and eyes behind them which shall not suffer that a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Friend of the Well shall be hurt."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: So Ralph and Ursula went forth, and came within a stone's cast of the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: barrier, when Ralph lifted up his voice and said: "Is there a captain
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: of the townsfolk within the timber there?" A cheery voice answered him:
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Yea, yea, lad; spare thy breath; I am coming to thee."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: And therewith a man came from out the barrier and did off his headpiece
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and ran straight toward Ralph, who saw at once that it was Clement
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Chapman; he made no more ado, but coming up to Ralph fell to clipping
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: him in his arms, while the tears ran down his face.  Then he stood
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: aloof and gazed upon him speechless a little while, and then spake:
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Hail, and a hundred times hail! but now I look on thee I see what hath
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: betid, and that thou art too noble and high that I should have cast
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: mine arms about thee.  But now as for this one, I will be better
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: mannered with her."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Therewith he knelt down before Ursula, and kissed her feet, but
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: reverently.  And she stooped down and raised him up, with a merry
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: countenance kissed his face, and stroked his cheeks with her hand and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: said: "Hail, friend of my lord!  Was it not rather thou than he who
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: delivered me from the pain and shame of Utterbol, whereas thou didst
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: bring him safe through the mountains unto Goldburg?  And but for that
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: there had been no Well, either for him or for me."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: But Clement stood with his head hanging down, and his face reddening.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Till Ralph said to him:  "Hail, friend! many a time we thought of this
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: meeting when we were far away and hard bestead; but this is better than
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: all we thought of.  But now, Clement, hold up thine head and be a stout
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: man of war, for thou seest that we are not alone."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Said Clement:  "Yea, fair lord, and timely ye come, both thou and thy
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: company; and now that I have my speech again which joy hath taken away
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: from me at the first, I shall tell thee this, that if ye go further
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: than the good town ye shall be met and fought withal by men who are
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: over-many and over-fierce for us." "Yea," said Ralph, "and how many be
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: they?"  Quoth Clement: "How many men may be amongst them I wot not, but
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: I deem there be some two thousand devils."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Now Ralph reddened, and he took Clement by the shoulder, and said:
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Tell me, Clement, are they yet in Upmeads?"  "Sooth to say," said
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Clement, "by this while they may be therein; but this morn it was yet
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: free of them; but when thou art home in our house, thy gossip shall
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: belike tell thee much more than I can; for she is foreseeing, and hath
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: told us much in this matter also that hath come to pass." Then spake
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Ralph:  "Where are my father and my mother; and shall I go after them
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: at once without resting, through the dark night and all?"
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Said Clement, and therewith his face brightened:  "Nay, thou needest go
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: no further to look for them than the House of Black Canons within our
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: walls: there are they dwelling in all honour and dignity these two days
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: past." "What!" said Ralph, "have they fled from Upmeads, and left the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: High House empty?  I pray thee, Clement, bring me to them as speedily
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: as may be."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: "Verily," said Clement, "they have fled, with many another, women and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: children and old men, who should but hinder the carles who have abided
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: behind.  Nicholas Longshanks is the leader of them down there, and the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: High House is their stronghold in a way; though forsooth their stout
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: heads and strong hands are better defence."
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Here Ralph brake in:  "Sweetling Ursula, though thy feet have worn a
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: many miles to-day, I bid thee hasten back to the company and tell
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: await them; so let them hasten hither and come within gates at once.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: said, Clement?"  "Yea, forsooth," said Clement; but he could not take
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

author: Morris, William

text: Thus came they into the market-place of Wulstead nigh to Clement's
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: house, and there the company stood in ordered ranks.  Ralph looked
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: round about half expecting to see his gossip standing in the door; but
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Clement smiled and said: "Thou art looking round for thy gossip, fair
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: sir; but she is upon the north gate in war-gear; for we be too few in
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Wulstead to spare so clean-limbed and strong-armed a dame from our
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: muster; but she shall be here against thou comest back from the Austin
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Canons, wither forsooth thou mayst go at once if thou wilt let me be
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: master in the matter of lodging." Said Ralph, smiling:  "Well, Ring of
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Wulstead, since thou givest leave I will e'en take it, nor needest thou
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: give me any guide to the House of St. Austin, for I know it well.
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: Sweetheart," said he, turning to Ursula, "what sayest thou: wilt thou
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: come with me, or abide till to-morrow, when I shall show thee to my
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: kinsmen?"  "Nay," she said, "I will with thee at once, my lord, if thou
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: wilt be kind and take me; for meseemeth I also have a word to say to
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: thy father, and the mother that bore thee."

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: much people about the door thereof, what of the townsmen, what of the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: men of his own host.  He passed through these, and found Clement in his
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: chamber, and with him a half score of such company as was without, and
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: amongst them Roger and the Sage; but Stephen and Richard both were
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: amongst their men doing what was needful.  All men arose when Ralph
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: entered; but he looked around, and could see nought of his gossip
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: amongst them.  Then he sat down by Clement and asked if he had any
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: and sunset had skirmished with Nicholas and them that were holding the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: being both bold and of good sleight had mingled with the foe; and had
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William

text: heard the talk of them, and he said that they had no inkling of the
title: The Well at the World's End: A Tale
author: Morris, William
